-Phases out production of chemicals - such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons - that damage the stratospheric ozone layer by 2000. Requires recycling of chemicals after 1992. Also curbs use of some substitutes. PENALTIES

-Maximum $25,000 a day in civil penalty for violators and possible criminal prosecution of corporate executives in cases where they knowingly pollute and significantly endanger health. -Government may impose sanctions, including loss of highway funds or curbs on construction, if states and cities fail to meet air quality standards.

DOC.HEAD: `Privatized' School Aims to Change American Public Education
LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A new public school in a blighted neighborhood is being turned over to a corporation that will run it for profit, in its own unusual fashion: no grades, no desks and a phone in every classroom. ``We have an opportunity to change education in America, and we're going to use all the strength and love and energy we have to make it happen,'' Pat Parham, principal of the still-uncompleted South Pointe Elementary School, told an overflow crowd of about 150 teachers at a meeting last week. Educational Alternatives Inc., which operates private schools in Paradise Valley, Ariz., and Eagan, Minn., plans to open South Pointe with 550 students next fall and run it for five years. Dade County school officials approved the plan this summer. EAI Director Kathryn Thomas said the school will create an atmosphere that celebrates learning by reducing student-teacher ratios to 12-1, tossing out multiple-choice exams and letting students pursue personal goals at their own pace. South Pointe won't have desks, but it will have computers. Classroom telephones will let students call their parents during school hours to share their successes. ``What we've done is try to empower children,'' Thomas said. ``Learning becomes contagious when everybody is actively involved in the process.'' Some local educators expressed skepticism about such a program in an area where about 95 percent of the families qualify for public assistance, many students come from broken homes and drug abuse and violence are common. ``I hope it's not as idealistic as it sounds. This area is tough,'' said Lourdes Fernandez, who teaches second grade at another local elementary school. But Frank Petruzielo, Dade County's associate school superintendent, said there is no reason to believe that only traditional educational theories work. ``Everybody's got an idea and an opinion on how to improve public education,'' he said. ``This was a novel opportunity to let people put their money where their mouth is.'' EAI charges $4,500 tuition at its schools in Minnesota and Arizona. South Pointe, which is being built with Dade County funds, will get no additional public funding. That means EAI will have to pay for extra learning materials and make its profit from the $450,000 it hopes to raise privately. The school also has applied for a three-year, $230,000 Nabisco Foundation grant to face one of its biggest challenges: encouraging parents, many of whom speak no English and have little formal education, to get involved. ``We want our parents to learn how to be parents,'' Parham said. ``We're trying to hire a person to go into the homes and train the parents on how to work with their children.'' EAI also hopes to recruit ``student advocates,'' including senior citizens and people in business, to provide students with daily encouragement. ``We've got to be able to respond to all their survival needs. Without it we'll just be spinning our wheels,'' said Linda Lentin, the lead teacher at the school. Jana Diconstanzo, a single mother, says she is more than willing to give the new school a chance. She has her 5-year-old son, Francis, enrolled in a private pre-school 45 minutes from her home but plans to enroll him at South Pointe next year. She said other public schools in the area are too dangerous. ``This is going to be a real blessing to me,'' she said. ``I think they need something new down here.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Heads Up; Stocks Dip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the yen in Tokyo Friday, as share prices plunged again. The dollar closed at 129.73 yen, up 0.43 yen from Thursday's close of 129.30 yen. After opening at 129.85 yen, trading ranged between 129.63 yen and 129.95 yen. On the stock exchange, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average finished at 23,171.63 points, down 315.85 points or 1.34 percent from Thursday's close at 23,487.48 points. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was quoted at 84.82 points at 1 a.m. EST, up from Thursday's 84.47-point finish. Their yield was lower at 7.750 percent from 7.830. Currency trading was ``thin and lacked direction in the absence of major market-affecting news,'' said Noriaki Ebisui, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Spot trading totaled $6.85 billion, down from $8.18 billion Wednesday. ``Unless something dramatic happens, for example the United States cuts its interest rates substantially or war breaks out in the (Persian) Gulf, the dollar-yen rate will stay in the current range,'' he said. The dollar has been trading recently between 127 and 130 yen. Other dealers said many participants stayed on the sidelines amid Britain's political uncertainties, the gulf tensions and expectations of a possible easing in U.S. interest rates. Stock market traders said investors were selling shares because of the yen's weakness against the dollar, and many stepped off to the sidelines in the afternoon after the index's morning decline. ``There was little buying incentive in the market,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co.

DOC.HEAD: Bishops End Meeting With Worry Over Women and War
DOC.TEXT: War, women and the Bible occupied deliberations of U.S. Roman Catholics bishops in the closing session of their annual fall meeting. As the National Conference of Catholic Bishops ended its session Thursday, the bishops' presiding officer dispatched a hand-delivered letter to the White House telling President Bush that offensve military action in the Middle East at this point could violate church principles about war. The church leaders adopted standards for Bible readings in worship services that would not stereotype first-century Jewish attitudes toward Jesus and would be more inclusive of women. The bishops also signaled their determination to keep trying to produce a temporarily stalled pastoral teaching letter on women's role in the church and society. Bishop Joseph L. Imesch of Joliet, Ill., head of a committee that has worked on the letter for seven years, said it still is ``alive and well.'' The ``work continues,'' he told the gathering. ``I want to erase any doubt about the future of the committee or the pastoral letter.'' Possibilities were seen for action on it next year or the year after, but Imesch added wryly, ``If we aren't done by 1999, we all quit.'' Following widespread criticism that past drafts were inconsistent in upholding equal opportunities for women, but reaffirming their exclusion from the priesthood, action on the letter at this meeting was put off. The Vatican suggested that other national bishops' conferences be consulted about it. Imesch told reporters that ``it would be a miracle'' if the main stumbling block - the tension between the equality principle and church barrier to women's ordination - could be overcome. Asked if bishops as one of the few exclusively male organizations left in the country felt uncomfortable in trying to define the place of women, he said, ``There's a great deal of uncomfortability.'' He added much women's input has come through hearings across the country. In the floor discussion, Auxiliary Bishop Francis P. Murphy of Baltimore said the extensive discussion has ``raised consciousness in the church and the country and thrown light on the equal or unequal experience of women in the church and society.''' Meanwhile, Imesch confirmed reports that comments from the Vatican's doctrinal congregation had accompanied the suggestion to delay the letter, but the contents had not been released. Some other bishops, most of whom asked not to be identified, said they had heard the Vatican message criticizes the letter's defense of women's rights in regard to husbands. Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. Gumbleton of Detroit said he had heard some of it is ``so bad they don't want to see it let out.'' In the letter to Bush, Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, the conference president, said of the Persian Gulf crisis: ``We urge our government and our allies to continue to pursue the course of peaceful pressure and not resort to war.'' He said a military offensive now ``could well violate'' the church's age-old ``just war'' criteria, requiring that objectives justify the human costs, that it not target civilian areas and that resort to it comes only after all reasonable peace efforts have failed. The bishops also approved a document on observance next year of the 500th anniversary of the coming of Europeans to America, recognizing both good and bad results, and expressing determination for better ways in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Arab is Victimized by Both Arabs and Jews
DOC.TEXT: Imad Abu Sneineh is an Arab who no longer knows whom to fear most. The Palestinians are after him because his father sold property to a Jew, and now he has been knifed by a Jewish extremist. ``I never believed I would be stabbed by an Israeli,'' Abu Sneineh said Thursday as he recovered in the hospital. ``I thought to myself tens of thousands of times that I may be stabbed by an Arab, because my father sold his home to Ariel Sharon.'' In fact, the house in Jerusalem's Moslem Quarter was bought by a Jewish religious organization. Sharon, the hard-line former defense minister, moved in after Arab attackers killed two Israelis in the Moslem quarter December 1987. Jewish real estate purchases from Arabs are shrouded in secrecy, and it is not known whether Sharon owns or rents the house. Abu Sneineh, 31, lives across from Sharon with his wife and two young children but it doesn't win him any privileges. He says police stop and search him every day. Israelis say Arabs sell because they get good prices. But the leaders of the Palestinian uprising call them traitors. Abu Sneineh says he saw no money from the sale, but he no longer dares to pray at the Al Aqsa mosque on Fridays, now that he has been denounced as a collaborator in a leaflet put out by uprising leaders. He says friends have turned their backs and he wishes he could talk with Sharon. ``Maybe he would give us arms to protect ourselves from Arabs,'' he said. Sharon's spokesman could not be reached for comment. ``I go out in the morning and I don't believe I will return home these days,'' he said. ``I kiss my kids as if I was going and not coming back.'' On Wednesday, Abu Sneineh was outside the butcher's shop where he worked in the ultra-religious Bukhran Quarter of Jewish west Jerusalem, waiting for his Jewish employer to close up and drive him home. A religious Jew walked up and slashed him from shoulder to belly with a knife, he said. ``He always came to the store, to threaten Arabs, swore at the Arabs .. but I didn't believe he would do something like this,'' he said. ``I thought he wanted help, to ask prices. But he took out a knife and slashed me.'' The employer, Mordecahi Mizrahi, tried to shield Abu Sneineh and he too was hospitalized with stab wounds in his hands. Police say the man attacked Abu Sneineh after Mizrahi refused his demands that he fire the Arab. The assailant said he was against Arabs working in Israel, newspapers said. ``I worked for Israelis. I was their friend and they mine ... They stabbed me and slashed me. What did I do?'' Abu Sneineh said. But Abu Sneineh says it will not affect his good relations with Jews, but he doesn't think he will return to the butcher's shop. As he talked, he leaned out of the window at Hadassah-Ein Karem Hospital, smoking a cigarette and occasionally wincing from the pain of his wound. ``What am I supposed to think?'' he said. ``I hate my life.'' ``I don't even know why my father sold the apartment. He died, and with him his truth. But the Arabs don't let us forget his mistake,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Gulf Crisis Windfalls, Iran's Economy Still In Rut
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Every day after the evening television newscast, Iranians are told which of their numerous coupons they can exchange for modest rations of cooking oil, meat, rice and detergent. The 8-year war with Iraq which sapped Iran's resources ended in August 1988 and Tehran is earning a windfall from higher oil prices caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But shortages persist and the economy remains sluggish despite strenuous efforts by President Hashemi Rafsanjani to revitalize it. That's a major setback for Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, and his drive to consolidate power by improving conditions for the country's 55 million people. He's trying to liberalize the economy while improving relations with the West to attract badly needed investment and technology. His radical rivals bitterly oppose his strategy, alleging it deviates from the revolutionary ideals of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died last year. Earlier this week the government pushed a plan through Parliament to seek $17.5 billion in foreign loans, a move the House had resisted even during the war. The government is under continual pressure to alleviate shortages, boost output and free Iranians from the economic hardship they have endured since the 1979 Islamic revolution. Last month Hasan Al-Hoseyni, a member of Parliament from the city of Arak, complained that Iran's deplorable economic conditions have brought ``ever-increasing pressure to bear on society's weak and middle classes.'' He demanded action and declared: ``No other issue must overshadow this important task.'' The Farsi-language Bayan monthly said: ``The first problem facing the government in its attempt to improve the state of the economy and to lessen the pressures on the underprivileged masses is inflation.'' Iranian consumers know about inflation. Salaried workers, earning a monthly average of 70,000 rials ($1,000 at the official exchange rate), cannot keep up with runaway prices. In Tehran, a month's salary is hardly enough to pay the rent for a one-bedroom apartment, buy two meals for four at a good restaurant or even one car tire. Earlier this year, a survey by the Geneva-based National statistics organization listed Tehran, with a population of about 7 million, as the world's most expensive city. The center reported that living costs for an average urban family last year were 1.8 million rials ($26,000), more than double the average annual income. Borrowing, which accounts for about one-quarter of the current budget, soared along with prices, IRNA reported. It quoted Isshaq Jahangiri, deputy chairman of Parliament's Planning and Budget Committee, as saying borrowing had to be increased to supplement shortfalls in revenue. He gave no figures. Since the Persian Gulf crisis triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 sent oil prices shooting up, Iran has been earning an extra $33 million a day in precious foreign exchange. But Jahangiri said that windfall still falls short of the $15 billion in oil revenue projected in the budget. In a bid to revive the post-war economy, Rafsanjani has announced a record $30 billion budget for the current Iranian year, which ends March 21. The budget is the first phase of his $112 billion five-year plan. But four months before the end of the year, the budget has been revamped because most of its projections were not realized. Jahangiri said that a large chunk of the deficit was due to the government's inability to collect taxes, which were to account for 40 percent of revenue.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Flock to Help Willie Nelson Out of $16 Million Tax Jam
DOC.TEXT: Willie Nelson raised millions with his Farm Aid concerts. Now the country music star's fans say it's time to return the favor with ``Willie Aid'' and help Nelson out of a $16 million tax jam. Nelson, who with singer John Cougar Mellencamp founded the Farm Aid movement to save struggling farmers from foreclosure, had 22 of his properties in four states seized by the Internal Revenue Service last week. The IRS says Nelson owes $16.7 million in back taxes, interest and penalties for 1975-78 and 1980-82. ``If everybody'd just give a dollar, everybody who loves him and his music, we'd get it in no time,'' said Annetta White, co-owner of Austin's Broken Spoke dance hall, where Nelson was a frequent performer in the 1960s. Mrs. White and others are spearheading fund-raising drives to help Nelson, who has won five Grammys and whose platinum-selling albums include ``Stardust,'' ``Poncho and Lefty'' and ``Red-Headed Stranger.'' Among properties seized were Nelson's Pedernales Country Club and recording studio near Austin and his Pedernales Fishing Camp. Also seized were land and houses in Colorado, Alabama and Washington state, said IRS spokeswoman Silvia Tovar. Ms. Tovar said agency rules prohibited her from saying whether Nelson has paid any of the bill. She said no date had been set for auctioning the properties. Nelson, 57, reportedly was in Hawaii this week and not available for comment. Neither his lawyer nor his manager returned calls Thursday. Nelson has said a former business manager did not file the singer's tax returns and left his finances in a shambles. Mrs. White and her husband, James, are organizing a benefit dance Dec. 2 and contacting such performers as George Strait for items they might auction. James Hataway, a barber in nearby West Lake Hills, said he is opening a bank account for people who want to donate. ``I'm just a little guy, a fan who's got all of his records,'' he said. ``But I think we ought to help Willie out.'' In Waco, near Nelson's hometown of Abbott, auto parts salesman Dave Crowe proposed that fans join ``Willie Aid'' by mailing donations straight to the IRS. ``He's given of himself. Now he is sideways with the IRS through no fault of his own,'' Crowe said. In Washington, the National Coalition of IRS Whistleblowers accused the government of going after Nelson because of his celebrity. ``The IRS as a matter of fact takes a celebrity case each year and talks it up to put the fear of God in people,'' said director Lisa Lashawa. ``If the whole intention is to get the money owed, why not let him sell a couple of his properties?''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Says Japanese, American Blacks `Fellow Victims'
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson says the Japanese should regard black Americans as fellow victims of ignorant prejudice and invest some of their wealth in black enterprises. ``African-Americans have a special relationship with you as Third World people,'' Jackson said in a Thursday night speech to the Japan Commerce Association. He said many white Americans are upset with both blacks and Japanese. ``They are angry at the Japanese for `buying up America.' The same kind of stereotype they used to have of Jewish-Americans is now transferred in many ways to Japanese ... and they are now angry at blacks for sharing in the remaining jobs,'' he said. Jackson, a two-time unsuccessful presidential candidate, was elected last week to a ``shadow senator'' post from the District of Columbia. In the unpaid position, he will lobby Congress for District statehood. His invitation to speak to the Japan Commerce Association, an organization of Washington-based Japanese corporate representatives, follows a remark by Japan's Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama last September that prostitutes moving into a Tokyo neighborhood had the same effect as blacks moving into a neighborhood in America. Both Kajiyama and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu apologized, but many outraged blacks said Kajiyama should have been ousted from the Kaifu cabinet. Jackson said corporate Japan should show more sensitivity to the plural makeup of the United States - and to the spending power of the U.S. black community - by holding a ``summit'' with leading blacks on investment and economic development. Jackson said such meetings would be a better way to get results than insults and picketing of the Japanese Embassy. He said also that the Japanese should invest in the U.S. ``urban crisis,'' the problem of decaying and drug-ridden inner cities populated by many poor minority Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Behrens Sings Salome at Met Opera
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned
DOC.TEXT: Hildegard Behrens sang the title role in the Metropolitan Opera's first presentation of Richard Strauss' ``Salome'' on Thursday, saving her voice at the beginning so she could pour it out at the end and not so much dancing the dance of seven veils as twirling around. In many ways, this production of ``Salome'' works against the opera. It's a big, black-walled basement with a pit where John the Baptist is held. Upstairs, on balconies and in windowed rooms decorated with pagan frescos, are seen people in lavish party dress. The impact of the wickedness of Salome's mother, Herodias, is lessened because of the general decadence being conveyed. Helga Dernesch sang Herodias well and looked sophisticated in a chic gown and sleek blonde hairdo. Salome's adolescent sexual awakening, to an inaccessible man, isn't conveyed. Richard Cassilly was excellent as Herod. His voice often had an appropriate hollow tone. James Conlon was conducting the opera at the Met for the first time. At the beginning, Behrens sounded thinner than she does in Wagner operas and one wondered if Strauss' textured orchestration was drowning her out. Later, as her high notes pealed out, it became clear that she had been holding back. Ekkehard Wlaschiha sang John the Baptist with ringing tones. After he pushed Salome away during their first meeting, he began to sing with personality as well. When he sang from down in his pit, he sounded muffled, like Fafner the dragon in Wagner's ``Siegfried.'' Tenor Peter Zazaras, in his debut season at the Met, made a strong impression as Narraboth, the young man who loves Salome but stabs himself in horror at her excesses. Behrens wears the pink dress with fluffy sleeves of the production two years ago but doesn't lift off chiffon panels of the skirt one by one as her veils, which did look silly. She lifts off one panel, twirls around holding it, then takes off and flings the whole dress, leaving her in a white gown with short sleeves. Also, she falls on the floor at the end; guards don't rush in and crush her with their shields. The good thing about this ``Salome'' was the performance of the music.

DOC.HEAD: Everybody Wants a Piece of Garbo
DOC.TEXT: Fans longing to own a piece of Greta Garbo found no slouch hat, dark glasses or cigarette holder for sale at the third and last auction of her possessions. But plenty of bidders paid high prices Thursday for the porcelain and enamel boxes, leather-bound books and Louis XV chairs that once filled the reclusive actress' apartment. ``Thanks, Mom!'' cried Constance Ford, a New York actress, when she placed a winning bid of $2,250 at Sotheby's for a pottery figure of a clown. ``I figured mother and Garbo at the moment were having tea, and mother said, `Make sure she gets it,''' Ford said of her late mother. Neither she nor her mother knew Garbo, but ``I think everyone felt very close to her,'' said Ford. ``She was mystical and exciting and extremely gifted.'' On Tuesday, Garbo's most important painting, an 1889 portrait by Renoir of his nephew, sold for $7 million. Thursday's auction was not about great works of art; it was about the film legend and the elegant world she created in her apartment on Manhattan's East Side. A pair of Louis XV beechwood chairs went for $88,000. A two-drawer tulipwood parquetry commode sold for $68,750. Small paintings and little porcelain boxes that were estimated to sell for $100 to $200 went for 30 times that amount. An oil painting of a white terrier, valued at $600 to $800, sold for $18,700. French enamel snuff boxes sold for several thousand dollars. A porcelain scent bottle in the shape of a wizard, valued at $500 to $700, sold for $18,700. ``I think she would have wanted someone like me to have something, instead of the people who have all the bucks,'' said Sherry Ostrow of West Orange, N.J. ``I was going to buy the smallest possible item. I'm really very unhappy I'm going away empty-handed.'' The total for the three-day sale was $20.7 million. The pre-sale estimate was $16.9 million to $23.5 million. Garbo, who died April 15 at age 84, bought most of her paintings, furniture and other art objects on her walks incognito through Manhattan. In the art and antique shops she frequented, she was known as Mrs. Brown or simply G.G. The actress never hired a decorator for her apartment. She chose her own colors - mostly roses, salmons and greens - arranged her furniture and hung paintings herself. Other paintings sold earlier in the week included Renoir's ``Leontine and Coco Reading,'' for $5.7 million, and Bonnard's ``Corn Poppies,'' for $3.2 million.

DOC.HEAD: Wellstone Doesn't Hide Dislike For New Colleague
DOC.TEXT: Paul Wellstone's first meeting with Sen. Jesse Helms is likely to be a little tense. ``I have detested him since I was 19, and moreover I think he won against Harvey Gantt on a blatantly racist campaign. Period. It's true,'' said Wellstone, elected last week as Minnesota's junior senator. The Senate is something of a club and members rarely attack each other personally. Wellstone, a liberal Democrat, has spent the week opening friendships that will be critical to his success in the Senate. But he has made it clear in media interviews that he does not like Helms, the arch-conservative North Carolina Republican who last week defeated Gantt to win a fourth term. Gantt, the former mayor of Charlotte, is black. Wellstone first heard Helms while studying at the University of North Carolina in the 1960s and has ``despised him ever since,'' the new lawmaker said in an interview with the Philadelphia Inquirer last week. Helms, who has never met Wellstone, responded Thursday with some advice for the new senator: ``I hope that he will prove to be somewhat more stable. ... Otherwise he's going to have a difficult time in the Senate.''
DOC.HEAD: GOP National Committee Cutting Staff 25 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Republican National Committee is firing a fourth of its staff, but party officials say the reduction is a normal beginning for a non-election year. ``We gear up in the even years and we gear down in the odd years,'' said Mary Matalin, RNC executive director. The committee has about 270 fulltime employees. B.J. Cooper, communications director for the committee, said a comparable staff reduction occurred four years ago, after the 1986 midterm elections. Matalin and Cooper denied published reports the cutbacks were forced by a disappointing fund-raising year or were ordered by White House Chief of Staff John Sununu. ``We're 100 percent supportive of their effort to shift gears,'' said Ed Rogers, White House political director. ``There was no instruction to do anything out of here; it's part of a longstanding plan. The White House was informed of it on an FYI basis the day before yesterday.'' The RNC had an operating budget for 1990 of $26 million and raised more than enough to cover it. At the Democratic National Committee, spokeswoman Ginny Terzano said no immediate cutbacks are planned. But the DNC is a much leaner operation with only 100 fulltime employees. The Democrats raised just over $10 million in 1990, including a record $2.7 million Wednesday night at the party's annual gala.
DOC.HEAD: Warming Of Lake May Preview Greenhouse Effects In Canadian Lakes Region
DOC.TEXT: Canadian researchers say those wanting a glimpse of what would happen if the Earth warms from the greenhouse effect should look at Ontario, Canada. Portions of the province are plagued with increased forest fires, less snow, warmer lakes and fewer trout, they say, though not from the greenhouse effect. Lakes monitored for more than 20 years in northwestern Ontario have been slowly changing as temperatures rise, snowfall declines and fires ravage nearby forests, scientists at the Canadian Department of Fisheries and Oceans report today in the journal Science. While the study does not claim that the changes are due to the greenhouse effect, the group's leader, D.W. Schindler, said the changes could be a preview of what is to come if the Earth does warm up. ``This is by no means the only period that has warmed for a prolonged time or at the rate that we're seeing,'' Schindler said. ``Our point is ... to show what increasing warming and drying, which we would see with a greenhouse effect, would do to lakes and their watersheds.'' The greenhouse effect refers to global warming that is caused when the atmosphere is enriched with carbon dioxide and some other gases that affect the movement of solar radiation and heat. The so-called greenhouse gases allow sunlight to pass through the atmosphere and strike the Earth. But the gases can prevent heat from radiating back out into space, thus trapping thermal energy about the planet. An increase in carbon dioxide is related to the burning of fossil fuels, such as coal and oil.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up Slightly in Light Trading
DOC.TEXT: Uncertainties about the Middle East caused light trading on the foreign exchange and the stock market in Tokyo today, dealers said. The dollar rose slightly against the yen and share prices fell again. The dollar closed at 129.73 yen, up 0.43 yen from Thursday's close of 129.30 yen. After opening at 129.85 yen, it ranged from 129.63 yen to 129.95 yen. On the Tokyo stock exchange, trading was sluggish with volume on the first section at 300 million. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average finished at 23,171.63 points, down 315.85 points or 1.34 percent from Thursday's close at 23,487.48 points. But the subdued trading, totaling $5.97 billion in spot transactions, lacked direction in the absence of fresh market-affecting news, brokers said. Market players are still waiting on the sidelines for a change in the Persian Gulf situation, traders said. The dollar tends to be strong at times of international tension, while the yen is weakened. Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo, said some investors are waiting for a series of U.S. economic reports scheduled for release today. But many traders did not foresee a radical plunge in the dollar even if the Federal Reserve makes the long-anticipated move to lower interest rates. Hiroyuki Takabe, a dealer at Yasuda Trust and Banking, said the subsequent profit-taking may even encourage a rush to buy dollars, unless the federal fund rate - the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans - is lowered by more than .25 percent. Masunori Ishitobi, a researcher at Sanyo Securities Co., said the blue chip average was adjusting after a 1,041.87-point jump Tuesday, following the three-day weekend. Last week, the Nikkei shed 1,033.95 points in three trading days, dropping to a 22,931.80-point close last Friday. Yoshiyuki Nishiguchi, a dealer at Daiwa Securities Co., noted a consistent pattern recently for share prices to pick up in the earlier part of the week, then plunge as the trading week ended. Nishiguchi said market players turn cautious because ``there's a feeling that anything can happen over the weekend.'' In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 84.77 points at 3 a.m. EST from Thursday's 84.47-point finish. Their yield was lower at 7.760 percent from 7.830.

DOC.HEAD: 50th Anniversary of Sealing Of Warsaw Ghetto Observed
DOC.TEXT: Members of Poland's small Jewish community and other denominations have joined in marking 50 years since Nazi troops sealed off the Warsaw Ghetto. Representatives of the Jewish organizations and the Jerusalem-based Yad Vashem Holocaust institute laid flowers Thursday at the Umschlagplatz monument, a site from which tens of thousands of Jews were transported to death camps. Clergy and believers of different Christian denominations joined in prayers at the Ghetto wall, the so-called ``Wall of Tears.'' The ceremonies began on the eve of the anniversary and continue through Monday. The Warsaw Ghetto, which the Nazis used as a collecting center for Jews from all over Poland, was set up in October 1940. On Nov. 16, 1940 the Nazis sealed off the district, into which 400,000 people were packed, ravaged by hunger and disease. At least 250,000 were deported to the death camps in Treblinka and Auschwitz in July 1942, when large scale deportations began. Following the April 1943 uprising in the Ghetto, the Nazis killed the last survivors and razed the district.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Lockheed Employees Awarded $45.3 Million in Whistleblower Case
DOC.TEXT: Lockheed Corp. says it will appeal a jury's $45.3 million award to three employees who claimed they were wrongfully fired for questioning the safety of the defense contractor's mammoth C-5B cargo plane. A Superior Court jury made the award Thursday to Clyde W. Jones Jr., 62, Terrence F. Schielke, 50, and Thomas E. Benecke, 48. The three said they were dismissed in 1985 after questioning the structural stability of the plane, now being used to ferry troops to the Persian Gulf. ``We believe the punitive damages are an injustice and come as a result of appealing to the passions and prejudice of the jury,'' said Lockheed attorney Gordon Krischer. ``The evidence doesn't warrant this verdict.'' Krischer said the planes were checked by the Air Force and found to be safe. Former Lockheed Chairman Lawrence O. Kitchen testified the men behaved unprofessionally in going outside the company to obtain independent metallurgical tests on the C-5B. He said that Jones had already elected to retire before Lockheed officials learned of the employees' concerns. Schielke and Benecke were fired for circumventing company policies and audit procedures, Kitchen said. ``I just wonder what else is wrong with the rest of their airplanes,'' said juror Jackey Grundman. Each of the plaintiffs was awarded $15 million in punitive damages. Awards for compensatory damages and emotional distress totaled $202,065 for Benecke, $91,660 for Jones and $82,789 for Schielke. Eric Julber, who represented Benecke, said the award sends ``a message that you shouldn't fire people for raising safety concerns.'' ``The frames were cracked, warped, twisted,'' Schielke said Thursday. ``And instead of scrapping them they went ahead and used them because it would have put them so far behind schedule to scrap them that the Defense Department would not have bought the planes.'' Herbert Hafif, attorney for Jones and Schielke, said four planes built with defective mainframes are being used to ferry troops to Saudi Arabia. ``Our next move is to ask the Congress to investigate this,'' he said. Jones was a senior quality control inspector at Lockheed's Marietta, Ga., plant on loan to California installations in Burbank and Palmdale. Schielke was an auditor at Burbank and Benecke an auditor at Palmdale. Jones lives in Tennessee. Schielke lives in Lancaster, Calif., and Benecke in Thousand Oaks, Calif. Financial analysts said Lockheed can afford to cover the award. The Calabasas-based aerospace company has an estimated $100 million cash on hand and is expected to generate profits this year of $315 million, said securities analyst Lawrence M. Harris of Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Military Suspected In Killing Of 18 Found in Common Grave
DOC.TEXT: The government says the remains of 18 farmers found in a common grave last month may have been killed by members of the military. The interior minister, Gen. Jorge Torres Aciego, told reporters Thursday that the government ``would try to investigate to find out who was responsible, and will severly punish them ... whether it be the navy, army or the air force.'' Local farmers said they discovered the bodies in a common grave in the remote mountainous area of Chilcahuayco, 9 miles northeast of Ayacucho. The farmers said they recognized the bodies of relatives detained by the armed forces in an anti-terrorist operation in late September. Farmers reported the find to the Ayacucho district attorney on Oct. 17. Ayacucho, a departmental capital 230 miles southeast of Lima, is the birthplace of the Maoist Shining Path guerrilla movement, which began its war of insurgency 10 years ago. For the first time since December 1982, the government lifted the emergency zone status of the city of Ayacucho on Oct. 24, but the area around the city remains under military control. More than 20,000 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms to overthrow the democratically-elected government in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Opinion Poll Boosts Heseltine Hopes Of Replacing Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: Former defense secretary Michael Heseltine's bid to replace Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was boosted today by an opinion poll that showed support for a change in leadership. The survey showed that if Heseltine replaced Mrs. Thatcher as leader of the governing Conservative Party - which would automatically make him prime minister - the Tories would shoot to a 10-point lead over the opposition Labor Party. The poll, conducted by Market and Opinion Research International and published in The Times of London, showed that if Mrs. Thatcher remained party leader and prime minister, the Conservatives would trail Labor, their main challenger, by four points. The Tories have trailed Labor in opinion polls for the past 16 months. The next general election by law must be held by mid-1992. But the prime minister can call one any time before that. The British domestic news agency Press Association said the poll's findings ``represent an enormous boost for Mr. Heseltine's chances of wresting the leadership from Mrs. Thatcher.'' Heseltine, 57, on Thursday formally submitted his bid for the leadership of the Conservative Party. He will challenge the 65-year-old Mrs. Thatcher in a secret ballot Tuesday among the 372 Conservative legislators in the House of Commons. It is the first serious challenge to her leadership since she took office in 1979. To win Tuesday, a candidate needs 50 percent of the votes cast and have at least 15 percent more than the runner-up. A second ballot, if necessary, would be held on Nov. 27, and other candidates are free to come forward. The winner needs only to get a majority. The opinion poll was based on face-to-face interviews with 1,088 people after the close of nominations for the Conservative - or Tory - leadership on Thursday. Heseltine was the only nominated challenger. The poll showed 49 percent of the respondents would support the Conservatives if Heseltine became leader, compared with 39 percent for Labor and seven percent for the Liberal Democrats. The other five percent was split among smaller parties. If Mrs. Thatcher survives Heseltine's challenge, Labor would have 45 percent support; Tories 41 percent, and Liberal Democrats 10 percent, according to the poll. It did not state a margin of error. Another newspaper, The Independent, reported today that a survey of London-based Japanese investors showed 54 percent would be more inclined to buy shares in British companies if there were a new Tory leader. The survey was conducted by the securities house Nomura. Mrs. Thatcher, who won general elections in 1979, 1983 and 1987, said on Thursday she intends to fight for the job. She was responding to a Labor legislator who held up a 5-year-old newspaper in which she'd promised to quit in 1990. Heseltine, reported to be a millionaire, resigned his Cabinet post as defense secretary in 1986 in a Cabinet dispute over how to save the ailing Westland helicopter company. In an interview Thursday with Independent Television, he said he was inspired to challenge Mrs. Thatcher following speech in the House of Commons Tuesday by Sir Geoffrey Howe. Howe, who resigned as deputy prime minister on Nov. 1, criticized Mrs. Thatcher for her opposition among European Economic Community leaders to more rapid pace for European unity. Discord has been building in the Conservative Party for more than a year, partly over Mrs. Thatcher's attitude toward EC policies. Other problems include interest rates of 14 percent, annual inflation of 11.9 percent and a per-capita ``poll'' tax that sparked widespread rioting earlier this year. Heseltine has promised to order an immediate review of the tax if he wins. He has also pledged to introduce what he calls ``caring capitalism'' to replace Mrs. Thatcher's rigorous free-market policies which critics say benefit the rich at the expense of a growing number of the poor.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Promises Military Shakeup, Defends Central Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Gorbachev promising military shuffle, other details, quotes.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today promised a shakeup in the military leadership and defended his plan to rescue the collapsing economy and prevent rebellious republics from breaking away. It was not immediately clear why Gorbachev was calling for the shakeup and he did not elaborate in his speech to lawmakers in the Supreme Soviet legislature. He denied he had lost the support of the army, as one legislator implied after a meeting between the Soviet president and deputies serving in the military. The official Tass news agency said Gorbachev told legislators that there would be personnel changes in the higher commanding echelons of the armed forces and documents were being prepared for submission to the legislature. Gorbachev also said that in the near future, he would nullify decisions by union republics and local governments that denied soldiers and their families civil rights, particularly in the independence-minded Baltic republics. He was responding to legislatures in several republics that deny some civil rights to members of the Soviet military and curtailed the draft in regions seeking independence. The Soviet leader denounced what he called ``vile rumors'' that the country would suffer from cold and starvation during the upcoming winter and rejected the idea of a coalition government with the Russian Federation. ``No more defensive action; it is high time to launch an offensive,'' Gorbachev said, delivering a report to the Supreme Soviet at the demand of rebellious deputies. Gorbachev's report came as he was losing support from former loyalists. The current Moscow News, a weekly that has been a supporter of his reforms, urged him ``to either prove your ability to take decisive actions or resign.'' ``At your demand, you were given additional powers,'' the publication's founders said in an open letter to Gorbachev. ``Today, you can either use them for establishment a dictatorship or for deepening democratic perestroika. A dictatorship will lead you and the whole country to ruin.'' Gorbachev rejected accusations that the central government had no plans to combat the deteriorating economic and political situation and ethnic strife. ``We have a concrete program, and it must be fulfilled.'' Although the economic picture was bleak, Gorbachev rejected ``vile rumors that the country will be hungry and cold.'' He explained that the problem lay in the delivery system and that there was ample food in the country to meet reasonable demands. His speech came a day after Leningrad's City Council voted to join a growing list of Soviet cities rationing food. Bowing to demands by legislators for a report on his meeting with Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin last weekend, Gorbachev said their discussions were routine. He said sharing power with only the Russian Federation would be unfair to the other republics. ``In a coaltion government, if Russian leaders take over, it will mean discrimination against the other republics,'' Gorbachev said. Instead, he repeated his call for a country unified by a new union treaty spelling out the relationship between the central government and the republics. ``We don't need political leaders who stimulate separatism and nationalism, we need help to consolidate the country,'' Gorbachev said. Referring to his meeting with Yeltsin, the Soviet leader said, ``it was just routine. People said it was a sensation, but it was just regular work.'' The two leaders discussed the union treaty that would hold the 15 republics together in a single country and Gorbachev said he gave assurances that Russian economic interests would be ``taken into account'' in any agreement. All but one of the republics have declared some sort of sovereignty from the Kremlin and Gorbachev's plans for developing a market economy hinge on the republics staying in the union. The Supreme Soviet session today was attended by most leaders of the 15 republics, union leaders and members of Gorbachev's advisory council. There was no live television or radio coverage of Gorbachev's report. The Soviet leader agreed on Wednesday to address the legislature after delegates, angry about the slow pace of reform, abandoned their agenda on Wednesday and demanded a report on the state of the union and his meeting last weekend with Yeltsin. Many republics, especially Russia, are disregarding laws passed by the national legislature and decrees adopted by Gorbachev and the Council of Ministers, or Soviet cabinet. According to Tass, legislators at the Supreme Soviet became rebellious Wednesday and refused to discuss bills ``suggested from above'' until a new treaty on relations between the Kremlin and the republics is concluded.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

U.S. and Saudi troops conduct the second day ``Imminent Thunder'' military exercises Friday in Saudi Arabia near the Kuwait border. Military officials have released few details about the operation. About 1,000 U.S. troops and an unknown number of Saudi soliders are taking part in the six-day maneuvers. Also involved are about 1,100 aircraft and 16 ships, including the aircraft carrier USS Midway. Iraq has termed the exercises a ``provocative act'' because they are being held close to occupied Kuwait. --- Secretary of State James A Baker III was scheduled to meet with representatives of the 12-nation European Community on Friday to discuss the Persian Gulf and other issues. He scheduled talks with the foreign ministers of Romania, Finland and three African nations over the weekend. --- President Bush was scheduled to leave Friday evening for an eight-day trip to Europe and the Middle East. Part of the trip will be used to discuss the gulf with key allies and guage reaction to a possible U.N. Security Council resolution that would authorize U.N. force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Some diplomats say the resolution could come by the end of the month. Bush plans to join U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia on Thanksgiving Day. It would be the first presidential visit to front-line soldiers since 1967 in Vietnam. ---- Iraqi President Saddam Hussein suggested a peaceful solution is still possible and indicated he could release foreign hostages if Bush promised not to attack Iraq. In an ABC-TV interview aired Thursday, Saddam said Iraq favors a peace that it ``comprehensive, complete and final.'' But Saddam did not elaborate on the framework of a possible settlement, but noted that ``whoever hits us, we shall hit them back.'' --- The Soviet Union's top Middle East envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, said Thursday world leaders should not rule out talks on a possible Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait which include discussions on the Palestinian question. Primakov, in a speech in New York, said Saddam should be given the opportunity for a ``face-saving'' withdrawal from Kuwait. Saddam has earlier stressed linking talks on Kuwait to the question of Israel's occupation of lands claimed by Palestinians. --- The State Department said more than 100 Americans and their foreign-born family members are expected to leave Kuwait on Sunday aboard a U.S.-chartered Iraqi Airways flight. Most are women and children who had been eligible to leave for some time but decided only recently to depart, a spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0462 to fix category code
New Report Paints Nightmarish Picture of a Deadly Environment
DOC.TEXT: Water so foul that parents won't let their babies drink it. Soil so tainted that it can no longer be saved. Air so deadly that each breath is a step toward respiratory disease, and life expectancy is cut short. The haze-covered land once called East Germany is every bit the environmental disaster that it has long been believed to be, a new study says. The united German government's first comprehensive look at its new territory gives a bleak overview of the ecological wasteland left behind by the Communists, and the daunting challenge of repairing it. Right now, the east's environment poses ``a considerable health threat to the population,'' Environmental Minister Klaus Toepfer said in Berlin. About 10 million of the land's 16 million people have drinking water that is ``at times or permanently of harmful quality,'' he said. Toepfer said the government will spend $86 million this year toward cleaning up the land, but that a massive, long-term effort is needed to eliminate its myriad health hazards. ``We now have to build up an information network and draw up a list of priorities,'' he said at a news conference Thursday coinciding with the release of the 158-page report. Among the findings: About 1,000 of the former nation's 7,565 villages have drinking water so high in nitrates that infants are routinely given bottled water. Almost half of the rivers and lakes are so polluted that they no longer can be processed for drinking water. Only 3 percent of the rivers and 1 percent of the standing water, such as lakes and canals, are considered ecologically sound. Only 38 percent of the household sewage is treated before it is dumped into canals. Toepfer said that more than 40 percent of the ground is considered spoiled, and huge areas in industrial regions are so contaminated that the topsoil would literally have to be trucked away for the land to be salvaged. The report says eastern Germans are more likely to live shorter lives than their western countrymen. According to 1985 data, East German men had a life expectancy of 69.5 years, about 2.5 years below that of West German men. Women had a life span of 71.5 years, seven years below the average in the west. East Germany had the most productive industrial economy of the old East Bloc, but the former leadership paid virtually no attention to environmental concerns. Most of the cars - Trabants - had heavily polluting two-cycle engines. Wastewater went untreated. Farmers used fertilizers and pesticides at twice the rate as their counterparts in the West, the report says. Sewage and wastewater dumping and the use of inorganic fertilizers have created serious groundwater contamination, the report says. Perhaps no single factor has spoiled the air more than the use of brown coal, or lignite, which was mined in East Germany and is a major source of energy for industries and homes. Lignite is responsible for the heavy concentrations of sulfur dioxide and dust in the air, which has caused extremely high rates of bronchitis and asthma, particularly in children, the report says. The heavy industrialized southern cities of former East Germany are the hardest hit, with 20 percent higher rates of respiratory ailments than in the north, it said. Factories had few if any pollution controls, a major factor in the lack of interest among Western investors in taking over the vast majority of the former state-run enterprises. High lead content was found in vegetables and fruit grown in industrial areas, and in the blood of people living there. PCBs, heavy metals, dioxins and other toxic materials have been found in high quantities in air and water, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Entry Wins Solar Race
LaserPhoto ADE1
DOC.TEXT: A Swiss vehicle using newly developed solar cells crossed the finish line today about 250 miles ahead of the second-place entry in the 1,875-mile World Solar Challenge. Supporters rang cow bells as the ``Spirit of Biel'' crossed the line south of Adelaide on Australia's southern coast. The car, which resembles a pink-and-blue cockroach, took the lead on Sunday after leaving the starting line in the northern city of Darwin. The highly favored Honda entry from Japan was in second place late today and was not expected to finish until Saturday morning. Three cars - Japan's Hoxan Corp. and U.S. entries from University of Michigan and Western Washington University - were battling for third. The Swiss entry from Biel University averaged 40.1 mph and finished in an unofficial time of 46 hours, 23 minutes. That was 90 minutes off the record set by General Motors' Sunraycer in the inaugural race three years ago. The Biel car finished third in 1987 after it suffering a collision near Alice Springs, near the halfway mark. The Swiss was built at a cost of about $1 million, much of it raised by the 53,000 citizens of Biel. The car was powered by revolutionary silicon solar cells developed at the University of New South Wales in Australia by Professor Martin Green and Dr. Stuart Wenham. The laser-grooved cells turn the sun's rays into electrical energy at a 17 percent efficiency rate, four percent higher than others, university officials said. Biel team leader Fredy Sidler said the energy consumed by the car over six days was equal to less than 1{ gallons of gasoline. The winning team received a trophy of a globe topped by the sun. The 36-team entry list included 11 cars each from Australia and Japan, eight from the United States and one each from Canada, Switzerland, Germany, Denmark, New Zealand and Britain. There were only three official dropouts, although several cars were reported to have traveled only 125 miles. They have another five days to officially finish the race.

DOC.HEAD: Paramount Fires High-Priced Producers of `Top Gun'
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Pictures Corp. and the producers of such hits as ``Top Gun'' and ``Days of Thunder'' are going their separate ways. The studio and producers Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer agreed to split less than a year into their five-year contract because the ``environment for motion picture production has changed,'' said David Kirkpatrick, president of the Paramount Motion Picture Group. ``Our philosophy continues to focus on internal development and production control,'' Kirkpatrick said in a statement Thursday. Simpson and Bruckheimer declined to comment. The pair joined Paramount in February under a contract whose terms were not disclosed. Their latest movie, this summer's ``Days of Thunder'' starring Tom Cruise, cost about $63 million to produce, about $14 million over budget. The film grossed $80 million in the United States, but Paramount reportedly has yet to turn a profit. ``Days of Thunder'' was the first movie produced by Simpson and Bruckheimer since ``Beverly Hills Cop II'' in 1987. Before that, they produced a string of hits, including ``Flashdance'' in 1983, ``Beverly Hills Cop'' in 1984 and ``Top Gun'' in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Invites IAEA Inspection of Nuclear Facilities
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has invited international inspectors to verify it is not developing weapons at its nuclear research sites as tension in the Persian Gulf rises, an International Atomic Energy Agency spokesman said today. The United Nations agency inspects Iraqi and other nuclear facilities at six-month intervals, under the Non-Proliferation Treaty that prohibits the spread of nuclear technology for non-peaceful use. Iraq's representative to the IAEA, Rahim Al-Kital, told the agency's director-general, Hans Blix, three weeks ago that ``the doors were open'' for a routine inspection at the country's four nuclear research sites, spokesman Hans-Friedrich Meyer said. The last inspection was in April. Speculation had arisen that Baghdad might prohibit visits after the agency suspended technical assistance in line with U.N. sanctions following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. With the suspension still in effect, Meyer declined to say in a telephone interview whether agency inspectors would tour Iraq's two research reactors, storage and fuel producing facilities. Al Kital could not be reached for comment. The last inspection found no evidence Iraq was putting uranium at its nuclear facilities to military use, an agency statement said. Iraq has repeatedly denied allegations by Western media and Israel, which bombed Iraq's Tammuz-1 reactor in 1981, that it is developing nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Atomic Energy Agency Invited by Iraq for Inspections
DOC.TEXT: The International Atomic Energy Agency says Iraq has invited its inspectors to verify that Iraq's small stock of enriched uranium has not been made into an atomic bomb, The New York Times reported today. The move by Iraq as seen as a signal that it does not intend to use a nuclear weapon in the Persian Gulf crisis, the newspaper said. The uranium in question, a 27.6-pound, orange-size mass consisting of 93 percent pure uranium 235, was salvaged from Iraq's Osirak nuclear reactor after it was destroyed by an Israeli warplanes in 1981, the Times said. Iraq obtained the uranium from France in 1976 to operate the reactor on condition the fuel would be subject to inspection by international officials. There has been concern the high-purity uranium could be easily made into one primitive bomb, the Times reported. Such a bomb would have little military value but could be used for a sensational act of terrorism, the paper said. Iraq is a signer of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that binds signers to renounce the possession or use of nuclear weapons and to submit to regular inspections of its uranium by International Atomic Energy Agency officials. Such inspections have been carried out every six months and no violations have been detected, the Times reported. Hans Meyer, a spokesman for the agency in Vienna, told the newspaper that Iraq's ambassador to Austria, Rahim al-Qital, invited the agency to conduct a new inspection. Meyer would not disclose when the agency will inspect the fuel.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Briefly Loses Contact With Magellan
DOC.TEXT: NASA lost radio contact with Magellan again - this time for about 40 minutes - and also had to suspend the spacecraft's mapping of Venus for nearly a day to adjust its main antenna ever so slightly. The break in radio contact early Thursday was the third time contact with the craft was lost, and engineers still haven't found the cause, NASA said. After engineers re-established radio contact, they discovered the craft's main antenna was pointed slightly away from Earth. It cannot transmit its maps and radar images of Venus unless the antenna is pointed precisely toward Earth. Scientists spent much of Thursday readjusting the antenna, which was off a scant 1{ degrees, NASA said. It was not immediately why the antenna was out of alignment, NASA said. Magellan was launched from space shuttle Atlantis in 1989 on a $744 million mission to send maps and radar images of Venus back to Earth. It lost radio contact with NASA for 11 hours on Aug. 16, and 17 hours on Aug. 21.

DOC.HEAD: Protestors Leave Britain for Desert Peace Camps
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Seven peace campaigners headed for Iraq today to set up peace camps on the Saudi-Kuwaiti border to stand as voluntary human shields in the event of a U.S. attack. ``We are well aware of the consequences of our actions but this is a point of principle in the traditions of Gandhi,'' said Pat Arrowsmith, a 60-year-old peace campaigner who left with the group for Amman, Jordan. ``The military forces will have to cross our camps and may even kill us if they want to fight,'' she said. Miss Arrowsmith said Iraqi authorities told the group that it would be welcome. The campaigners hope to drive from Baghdad and select camp sites on both sides of the border between Iraqi-occupied Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, where U.S. and other forces have assembled. ``It is our intention to select sites in key points which will prevent the movement of war material and forces,'' said Miss Arrowsmith, adding that other peace protestors will join them once the camps were established. ``We don't know how many people will eventually be present, but it could be hundreds. It is a very strong peace movement,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Florida; Clear Skies, Fair Weather Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in Florida early today, while skies were clear across most of the rest of the nation and unseasonably warm weather continued. A cold front moving across the Great Lakes region threatened to bring rain to the upper Midwest today. A storm moving into Alaska was expected to bring several inches of snow there and snow and rain as far south as Washington, Oregon and Northern California. Highs were forecast in the 70s along most of the East Coast, 80s in the South and Southwest deserts, and 60s and 70s across the Midwest and West Coast. The high temperature for the nation Thursday was 90 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Trade Talks to Focus on Farm Subsidy Impasse, Gulf Crisis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leading U.S. and European Community officials opened talks today likely to focus on a farm subsidy policy dispute that has stalled world trade negotiations. The Persian Gulf crisis was also high on the agenda. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III headed the American delegation for a second meeting this year with officials of the 12-nation trading bloc. ``We hope ... that we will find at least a mechanism or process for moving forward the discussions,'' Baker told reporters Thursday aboard his flight to Brussels. Even before the meeting began, U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter made stops in Germany and France to urge some compromises. ``We've got a stalemate and we've got a problem,'' Mrs. Hills said Thursday shortly after her arrival in Brussels. It would be difficult to maintain international cooperation on issues ranging from the environment to the Persian Gulf crisis, ``if you are at each other's throats over trade issues,'' she said. The officials were expected to discuss the gulf and economic aid to Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. Those countries have been hard-hit by the international trade embargo imposed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Their agenda also included discussions on Eastern Europe. At issue in the trade talks is a demand by the United States and other agriculture-exporting countries that the EC make sharp cuts in its expensive farm subsidy programs. The community has so far offered to make only modest reductions. The dispute has threatened to scuttle the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, an ambitious four-year effort to revamp the world trading system and reduce barriers to trade in 14 other areas, including textiles, manufactured goods and services, such as banking and telecommunications. The talks, which began in 1986 in Punta del Este, Uruguay, are due to end with a final week of bargaining in Brussels starting Dec. 3. But the community's refusal to promise heftier subsidy cuts has raised doubts about whether the round can be completed successfully. Mrs. Hills warned that international tensions would rise if the Uruguay Round fails. ``We would be headed into a period of much greater friction,'' she said. The EC recently proposed to reduce subsidies on major farm crops by 30 percent over 10 years. Some of the cuts have already been made. The Bush administration has asked for cuts of 75 percent in farm income supports and 90 percent in export subsidies over a decade, beginning next year. The United States is pushing agriculture reform because it hopes that lowering trade barriers will enable its farmers to sell more goods on the world market. Other farm-exporting countries, like Argentina and Australia, also would like a chance to export more. The EC, however, contends it needs its array of agriculture supports to protect its 10 million farming community, many of whom have small operations. Industrialized nations spent $251 billion on agricultural subsidies last year, according to estimates from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The community accounted for $97.5 billion and the United States $67.2 billion. EC members are Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain, Spain and Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies today in quiet early European trading. Gold prices were higher. Dealers said markets were calm ahead of the release of U.S. trade figures for September and the U.S. consumer price index for October. The data could set the tone for the dollar in the next few weeks, traders said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.43 yen to a closing 129.73 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 129.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Thursday: -1.4785 German marks, up from 1.4765 -1.2510 Swiss francs, down from 1.2515 -4.9927 French francs, up from 4.9890 -1.6685 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6650 -1,115.50 Italian lire, up from 1,112.50 -1.1643 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1617 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9565, compared with $1.9590 late Thursday. London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $380.30 per ounce at midmorning, up from $379.25 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $380.20, up from 378.60 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.08 to close at a bid $380.11. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.12 a troy ounce, from Thursday's $4.16.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Warns Country Could Break Up or Succumb to Dictator
DOC.TEXT: Premier Ante Markovic says Yugoslavia faces dictatorship or disintegration unless its quarrelsome republics agree to his liberal economic and political reforms. Markovic told Parliament on Thursday that the country's crisis ``has reached such proportions that the country's existence is drastically in question.'' His reforms, including privatization of the economy and the lifting of import and foreign investment restrictions, have angered the hard-line leadership of Communist-led Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic. Serbia's state-run press has accused Markovic of being a Western agent and of wanting to turn Yugoslavia into a ``banana republic.' The non-communist governments in the western republics of Slovenia and Croatia, which advocate transforming Yugoslavia into a loose association of near-independent states, are wary of the Croatian technocrat's insistence on keeping Yugoslavia united as a federation. Last month, Serbia undermined Markovic's reform by unilaterally abolishing Yugoslavia's common market and introducing duties on goods from Slovenia and Croatia. The two independent-minded republics recently have changed their constitutions, setting the stage for possible secession from the current federation of six states and two provinces. Markovic said ``unconstitutional policies'' of Slovenia, Croatia, and Serbia ``inevitably led to the worsening of political tension in Yugoslavia and most directly jeopardize the country's existence.'' He accused the republics of carrying out policies which ``evidently lead to ... the breakup of the country or the introduction of dictatorship.'' He did not elaborate. ``We must face the fact that we are seen from abroad as one of the most crisis-ridden regions in Europe, while foreign leaders consider that Yugoslavia is on the brink of breakup and civil war,'' Markovic said. He said only a united and democratic Yugoslavia would be accepted into an all-European political and economic system. Markovic, prime minister since March 1989, introduced reforms last December that have throttled runaway inflation and pulled Yugoslavia from the brink of bankruptcy. The reforms won praise from Western creditors, but side-effects were a sharp drop in industrial output and closure of many unprofitable companies. That threatens to push up unemployment, already a hefty 19 percent. Initial optimism that Markovic's popularity could overcome the growing political crisis evaporated in the face of continued feuding between politicians and ethnic groups. Markovic said Yugoslavia would need $2.5 billion more from foreign creditors next year in order to implement his policies. Yugoslavia already owes $16 billion to Western banks and governments. Markovic criticized Serbia for illegally withholding $250 million in contributions for the federal budget.

DOC.HEAD: Recovery Efforts Difficult, Lengthy Probe Seen
DOC.TEXT: Authorities investigating a jetliner crash that killed all 46 people aboard, including seven Americans, say it could be several months before the cause of the disaster is fully known. Officials Thursday cited pilot error and technical failure as possible causes of the Wednesday night crash as the Alitalia DC-9 approached Zurich international airport en route from Milan, Italy. Radar data showed the plane was flying about 990 feet too low, Alitalia and Swiss officials said there was no explanation yet for the low altitude. Zurich airport spokesman Andreas Meier said radar data ``suggest the pilot misjudged his altitude.'' Alitalia officials on Italian television speculated the plane's electronic navigation system failed. Swiss transporation department spokesman Ulrich Sieber said investigators may need several months to compile and publish their report on the inquiry. At least seven Americans were aboard the plane, according to the airline and U.S. Embassy officials. The embassy in Bern identified the American victims as Karol Forman, Paul Vaughan and William Briggs of New York state; John Stuckey and Jerry Bass of North Carolina; Robert Anderson, an American resident of Switzerland, and Stephen Ritter of North Carolina. No hometowns were given. The embassy had no further details early today. The nationalities of four victims were still undetermined, the airline said. Pope John Paul II offered condolences to the victims' families. The plane crashed into a steep wooded hillside, broke up and was gutted by fire. Zurich police official Eugen Thomann said all victims likely died on impact. Witnesses said the pilot seemed to gun the plane's engines just before impact about 12{ miles northeast of central Zurich. Some witnesses reported seeing fire and hearing explosions while the plane was still in the air. Rain on Thursday hampered investigators inspecting the debris. About 300 rescue and police officials recovered bodies and cleaned up. Since victims were burned beyond recognition, positive identification could take weeks, Zurich police spokesman Hansrudolf Suter said. Police said the the jet's two flight recorders, or ``black boxes,'' were found Thursday and will be sent to an English lab for evaluation. One recorder tracks flight data and the other tapes cockpit conversation. Meier said terrorism was not ruled out, but stressed there was no immediate indication the plane was a target. Alitalia said the two-engine DC-9, built in 1974, was last inspected 10 days before the crash.

DOC.HEAD: They Smile, They Dance, They Lip Sync - and That's All
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11-12 pvs, bgng, `In a statement...' with five grafs to UPDATE with Pilatus quotes; ADDS 2 grafs at end with quotes from reported real singer.
DOC.TEXT: Milli Vanilli, the dreadlocked pop duo whose debut album sold 7 million copies, could become the first act to be stripped of a Grammy after it was learned they didn't sing a single note on the record. ``If there's been a substantial, fraudulent, misrepresentation of the entity, I think there is a high likelihood that the academy would have to take some action,'' said Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. The academy administers the Grammy Awards. He said the academy's action could include taking back the group's 1989 Grammy. He said no one has ever been stripped of a Grammy in its 33 years. Frank Farian, the German producer who turned a pair of anonymous pretty boys into an international phenomenon, revealed in an interview this week that hunky dudes Fab and Rob - Robert Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan - were actually the fabulous bunko boys. Farian said the bare-chested vocalists once described by The New York Times as ``exotically sexy'' did nothing more than look good and lip sync for videos and TV and concert appearances while others did all the singing. ``The record company never knew that. I never told them anything,'' said Farian. ``Later on, after the record was out, there were some people who raised some questions.'' The Vanillis won a Grammy for Best New Artist and Rob and Fab became international stars. ``Girl You Know It's True'' and ``Blame It On the Rain'' were both huge hit singles for the band. At the MTV awards, the boys boasted they were better than Elvis or Bob Dylan. Farian would not say who the real singers were but added that they will appear on his next album - not a Milli Vanilli album. He said Wednesday he was forced to go public with the revelations when the boys told him they wanted to sing on the follow-up to ``Girl You Know It's True.'' ``I said, `No. I don't go for that.' Sure, they have a voice, but that's not really what I want to use on my records,'' said Farian. In a statement Thursday, the two said they ``have been ready, willing and able to record our own vocals and have been prevented by Frank Farian from doing so.'' And in an interview with the Los Angeles Times, Pilatus called Farian a ``control freak'' who ``would not allow us to enter the studio.'' ``He's a white German guy who has a big complex about black artists,'' said Pilatus, a black native of Germany. ``The last two years of our lives have been a total nightmare. We've had to lie to everybody,'' he said. ``We are true singers, but that maniac, Frank Farian, would never allow us to express ourselves.'' ``We were afraid for two years that this day would come,'' Pilatus said. ``We've cried about it sometimes ... But deep inside, we wanted it to happen.'' Pilatus said he and Morvan planned to sing on their next album. The revelation didn't bother Arista, the label that raked in the cash when ``Girl You Know It's True'' topped the charts. ``Seven million albums? Embarrassing?'' asked Roy Lott, vice president for operations. ``I don't mean the end justifies the means. But we sold 7 million albums.'' According to Farian, the idea to hire Rob and Fab as front men for the band came to him when the pair arrived at his studio in Germany shortly after the recording of ``Girl You Know It's True.'' ``It suddenly clicked in my mind, and it was kind of evident: I had the music, there were the people who wanted to perform outside,'' said Farian. ``And I said, ``Hey, let's put that together and make a great record out of it.''' Lott said the label is unconcerned about the dupe, and it plans to distribute Farian's new album. As for Rob and Fab, their future's a bit more uncertain. ``We are purely their distributor. We do not have a specific deal with Rob or Fab,'' Lott said. The Los Angele Times said sources have suggested that a Dallas native, Charles Shaw, was one of the singers on the Milli Vanilli albums. In a telephone interview from Germany, Shaw told the Times, ``once you hear me sing and then you have the Milli Vanilli record in your hand, even if I told you it wasn't me singing, you wouldn't believe me.'' ``Do I resent that Milli Vanilli made so much money and all I got was studio fee? In the beginning I was very, very upset ...,'' Shaw said. ``But I put it to the side, and at the present moment I plan to succeed on my own.''

DOC.HEAD: National Council of Churches Demands U.S. Pull Out of Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The National Council of Churches has demanded that the United States pull its troops out of the Persian Gulf and work for a peaceful settlement of the Iraq-Kuwait crisis. The only troops that should stay in the region are those whose presence is requested by the United Nations, the council said in a resolution adopted unanimously Thursday at the group's convention. ``We stand at a unique moment in human history, when all around us seemingly impregnable walls are being broken down and deep historical enmities are being healed,'' the council said. ``And yet, ironically, at such a moment our own nation seems to be poised at the brink of war in the Middle East.'' The council also called on Iraq to release all foreign citizens held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait and to withdraw its troops from Kuwait. It said President Bush and the Congress should use every means to reach a peaceful settlement, including direct negotiations with Iraq. The council represents about 42 million Americans from 32 denominations, including many of the nation's largest mainstream Christian churches. Also Thursday, the group decried family violence as sin and called on Christian communities to actively protect women and children from victimization. At the same time, the council confessed that past ``inaction by church leadership has sustained the injustice of family violence.'' Family violence is an epidemic in Western, post-industrial societies, where it is considered a birthright by some men, the statement said. In some cases, it said, ``even interpretations of scripture'' support the notion of males' right to control and chastise others.

DOC.HEAD: China To Devalue Yuan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD details, rates. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: China announced today that it will devalue its currency nearly 10 percent beginning this weekend, the country's second devaluation in less than a year. The State Administration of Exchange Control said the 9.57 percent devaluation will be effective Saturday, according to the official Xinhua News Agency. As usual, Xinhua waited until after the close of the banking day to make the announcement, and officials could not immediately be reached for comment. Xinhua quoted the State Administration of Exchange Control as saying the devaluation is part of the effort to ``deepen the country's economic and monetary reform and accelerate economic development.'' The last devaluation took place in December 1989 and was by 21.2 percent. Currently, the old buying price is 4.71 yuan to the dollar, and the selling price is 4.73 yuan. After the devaluation Saturday, it will cost 5.21 yuan to buy one dollar, and the selling price will be 5.24 yuan. Countries usually devalue their currency to make their products cheaper on world markets and improve their trade balance. However, China has been enjoying a large trade surplus due to stringent import controls. China's currency, which is not convertible on world money markets, is widely believed to be overvalued. The new rate is still slightly below that used on the black market.

DOC.HEAD: Suspected IRA Bomber Ends 37-Day Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: A suspected IRA bomber reportedly had his first meal today after 37 days on a hunger strike. The Home Office, which oversees Britain's prisons, refused to confirm that Desmond Ellis had eaten, but said no prisoner in the London prison system was on a hunger strike. Desmond's father, Noel Ellis, said his son would end his strike today.
