Speaking during a break outside the chamber, Leningrad Mayor Anatoly Sobchak said Gorbachev's speech ``was not what we need. What we need are extraordinary measures.'' During his speech, Gorbachev lowered his voice to a near-whisper when he began discussing a coalition with Yeltsin, his chief political foe. Calling his Sunday meeting with Yeltsin simply ``routine,'' he rejected the idea of giving the Russian leader more national power and hinted at the dangers of Russian nationalism. ``In a coalition government, if the Russian government gets any more power, it will mean discrimination against the other republics,'' Gorbachev said. After Gorbachev's speech, the white-haired Yeltsin told legislators that the first task of the proposed anti-crisis committee would be to take an inventory of all the food in the country and distribute it where necessary. ``The crisis we are experiencing now is still a crisis of a totalitarian state, which is reflected in the paralysis of power,'' Yeltsin said. ``The center is sliding down to confrontation with the republics, and first of all, with Russia.'' Emerging later during a recess, Yeltsin said the committee would not work with Ryzhkov. ``But we might form a coalition with Gorbachev,'' he told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: Quotes From Gorbachev Address to Supreme Soviet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, `On role...' to CORRECT typo. Pickup 6th, `We have...'
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's address today to the Supreme Soviet legislature as translated by The Associated Press:

ON GOVERNMENT REORGANIZATION - Now about the structure of the union government. It should be decisively changed even before the signing of the union treaty. First of all, this question is reflected in the union treaty and is solved fundamentally. You'll see it yourself when in several days you get a draft concept of the treaty. First of all, we should get rid of outdated, clearly useless strucures. Suggestions in this respect should be submitted in the next 10 days. We should finish with the formation of new bodies created in connection with transition to a market economy - I mean an interregional committee on economic reform, an anti-monopoly committee and others. The reorganization of the government should be accompanied by a renewal of its members. Those who are most competent should be brought into government.

ON PARALYSIS OF POWER - Now everybody is talking about the crisis of power. The center is getting a flow of ultimatums to take decisive measures on improving the situation in the country. We should ask ourselves bluntly, what is the matter? Why, instead of a totalitarian power, there has come a vacuum of power. This is where the matter lies. We should clarify the question.

ON ROLE OF COMMUNIST PARTY - In the past, we could describe the mechanism of power in practically one word: the party. It infiltrated practically everything, both the state organizations and public structures. Any decision of the CPSU was regarded as an order not subject to discussion. It was a tough, in its own way logical, authoritative system which, however, was not only incompatible with democratic principles, but, as we know, led to colossal losses and flaws as far as the social progress of the country is concerned. We have consciously dropped it, and there is no way backwards. But, moving away from an old structure of power, we have not yet created democratic mechanisms that would meet the new tasks. When a decision is taken by the president, where is that mechanism that would work as in the past?

ON SHARING OF POWER - The largest part of the existing contradictions and misundertandings, paralyzing the activity of administrative bodies on all levels, has resulted from the absence of a clear and precise demarcation in competence between the union republics and central power. We don't need political leaders who stimulate separatism and nationalism. We need help to consolidate the country.
ON IMPENDING CHANGE IN MILITARY COMMAND LEADERSHIP - We cannot discredit the army because we need them now to maintain stability in the country.

DOC.HEAD: Freight Train Hits School Bus; Two Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes from principal; driver among the dead; other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A freight train struck a school bus at an unguarded crossing today, killing two and injuring 21, authorities said. Frantic pupils from a nearby school had to be restrained from going to the site. Bob Stier, transportation supervisor for the Alexandria public schools, said those killed were the bus driver and a student, one of about 25 on the bus. ``It is just horrendous,'' said Sheila Olson, principal at the Miltona Science Magnet School, where the bus had just dropped off passengers before heading for the high school in Alexandria, 10 miles to the south. ``I still can't believe it happened. It's just not real.'' Seven of the injured were in stable condition at Douglas County Hospital in Alexandria with fractures and internal injuries, said Bill Flaig, hospital administrator. ``It looks like they're going to be here for a while,'' he said. Fourteen people were treated and released after the 7:30 a.m. accident, Flaig said. Ms. Olson said the accident scene was visible from the school and teachers had to restrain some children from going to the site. Some of them were ``very upset'' because they had just gotten off the bus and some had older brothers and sisters still aboard, she said. ``The kids, many were crying, wanting their parents, and you just feel so helpless,'' she said. ``You just don't know what to do.'' The cause was not immediately known, a sheriff's dispatcher said. ``The front end of the bus got hit,'' Stier said. ``It was a flat-nosed bus and (the train) hit the side where the driver was.'' ``The bus got spun around, then the front end of the bus hit a light pole,'' Stier said, adding that the train did not derail. John Bergene, spokesman for the Minneapolis-based Soo Line Railroad, said there were no injuries on the train. The maximum speed at the County Road 14 crossing is 40 mph, Bergene said, but the train's speed when the collision occurred was not yet known. There are yellow warning signs and stop signs at the crossing, but no flashing signals, he said. Stier said the bus driver was in his 60s and had been driving school buses for about 10 years. The bus was owned by the school district, he said. Ms. Olson said the district has brought in a team of counselors to help comfort the children. The Rev. Nancy Larson, a Lutheran minister from Carlos, was among those trying to help. ``I just simply stood in the halls as students were walking back and forth between their rooms and just shared hugs with some of the children who were in tears and very frightened by it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Publishes Ad Appealing for Iranians' Release
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper advertisement published Friday appealed for information on four missing Iranians whose fate has been linked to some of the Western hostages held by pro-Iranian extremists. The half-page ad, signed by relatives of the missing Iranians, appeared in the leading Beirut newspaper An-Nahar. ``We came to collect the pieces of our hearts,'' it said. The relatives arrived in Lebanon Tuesday. The ad carried pictures of the Iranians, who disappeared in the Christian enclave during Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon. Christian warlord Samir Geagea said in a TV interview Tuesday that the Iranians were killed after their abduction by right-wing militiamen under the command of his pro-Syrian rival, Elie Hobeika. Iran has interceded on behalf of Western hostages held in Lebanon, and it has said it would help secure the relese of the remaining 13 in return for information about the Iranians. Mohsen Musavi, charge d'affaires at the Iranian embassy, was one of those abducted. His wife, Maryam, said at a news conference Thursday that the Iranians were alive. ``The latest information we received ascertains that all four Iranians are still alive in the Laqlouq prison of the Lebanese Forces Christian militia headed by Samir Geagea,'' Mrs. Musavi said. ``We got this information from newly freed prisoners from Laqlouq jail who came to our embassy in Nicosia,'' Cyprus, she said. Laqlouq is a ski resort in the mountains of Kesrouan province about 40 miles northeast of Beirut. The region is a Lebanese Forces militia stronghold. Sheik Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, the most influential Shiite Moslem cleric, said Thursday that the fate of the four missing Iranians should be revealed ``because this is a tragedy as inhuman as the detention of the (Western) hostages.'' Fadlallah is the spiritual guide of the Iranian-backed Hezbollah, or Party of God, which is the umbrella for underground factions holding most of the Westerners missing in Lebanon. Fadlallah has made appeals for the release of hostages in the past. They appear to have had no tangible impact on the kidnappers of the Western hostages, despite his influence on religious matters. However, when the self-styled Organization of Islamic Dawn released former American hostages Robert Polhill and Frank Reed last April, it said the releases were due, among other things, to the ``behests of senior religious leaders.'' The remaining Western hostages are six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. The longest held is American Terry Anderson, 43, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Who Projected New Madrid Quake Talks of Other Things
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0527 to CORRECT cycle designator to PM
DOC.TEXT: Iben Browning has incurred the wrath of geologists and seismologists for projecting a 50-50 chance for a major earthquake on the New Madrid Fault zone in early December. He may soon be getting in trouble with economists. During a presentation Thursday to a St. Louis business group, the New Mexico scientist said it appears that conditions are right for the world to fall into a depression in 1992. ``For climatological reasons, we will reach the bottom of the depression about the end of 1992. ... I expect (it) will be the most severe since 1776, more severe than the 1930s,'' Browning said. Among other things he said: - That high tidal forces have affected such things as the size of the wheat crop in the Soviet Union and the rise of Nazism before World War II. - That volcanoes cause acid rain, not coal-burning factories and power plants. - That the temperature of ice in Greenland affects the world economy. One thing he didn't spend much time talking about was his projection that strong tidal forces could touch off a major earthquake in the Midwest about Dec. 3. He also had nothing to say about the overwhelming criticism it has prompted. ``That would be a waste of time. I'd rather just stick to my work,'' said Browning. Although he referred to his projection as a ``guesstimate,'' he said he was confident in his reasoning and thought people should listen to what he has to say. Browning's projection has created a stir in parts of the Midwest where residents have bought survival kits and earthquake insurance. The New Madrid Fault runs from Marked Tree, Ark., north to Cairo, Ill., and affects parts of Missouri, Arkansas, Tennessee, Illinois and Kentucky. In 1811 and 1812, three major quakes caused widespread devastation along the fault, rattled chimneys as far away as Boston and knocked residents of Nashville and Cincinnati to the ground. Earthquake experts say there's a good chance of another quake in the region eventually, but have dismissed Browning's theories of the chances of one being triggered by tidal forces. Browning, 72, of Tijares, N.M., is chief scientist for Summa Medical Corp., an Albuquerque biotechnology research and development company. He has a doctorate degree in physiology and bachelor's degrees in physics and math. He has studied climatology on his own and publishes ``The Browning Newsletter'' on world climates.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Deciding Whether to Give Noriega Government-Paid Lawyer
With PM-CNN Tapes, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with defense filing. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, U.S. District...'. Should stand for PMs; hearing not scheduled until 1:45 p.m. EST. Earlier note saying hearing was set for 9 a.m. was erroneous.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for Manuel Noriega headed for federal court today for a hearing on whether the deposed Panamanian dictator should be appointed a government-paid defense attorney, and also sought to have the charges thrown out. Noriega's private defense team, led by Fran Rubino, had claimed the U.S. government has sabotaged its work by freezing Noriega's assets, leaving no money for legal fees. In what Rubino said may be one of his last acts in the Noriega case, he filed a motion today to dismiss the charges, accusing the government of a conspiracy to deny Noriega's rights to a fair trial and effective legal counsel. The motion accuses the government of misconduct by taping Noriega's prison phone calls with his attorneys. Cable News Network reported last week that it had obtained tapes of such calls. The defense motion also accuses the prosecution of illegally freezing his funds, and says an unidentified government witness attempted to entrap the attorneys two months ago by soliciting a bribe to change his testiony. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler on Tuesday set a deadline of today for Noriega's lawyers and the prosecution to work out a payment plan. Otherwise, he said, he will declare Noriega indigent and appoint an attorney on the U.S. payroll. If declared indigent, Noriega would be allowed two attorneys paid a maximum of $75 an hour and investigative expenses of a few thousand dollars. By contrast, the Justice Department has 30 lawyers on the case and is prepared to spend up $30 million to prosecute Noriega on charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from Colombian cocaine smugglers, Rubino said. The tight budget for indigent defendants makes it nearly impossible for government-appointed attorneys to compete, said Yale Kamisar, a law professor at the University of Michigan. ``You need investigators, you need experts ... to challenge the government, to put them to the test,'' he said. Meanwhile, Cable News Network has asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn Hoeveler's ruling of last week prohibiting the broadcast of taped jailhouse telephone conversations between Noriega and his lawyers. On Thursday, the FBI, which is investigating how CNN obtained the government tapes, seized tapes and papers that had been stored in a CNN reporter's hotel room. The network claims the material was improperly removed from the hotel room by security guards and has demanded the FBI return it. Soon after the United States invaded Panama last December, the Justice Department asked other countries to freeze 27 bank accounts holding about $20 million in purported ill-gotten gains allegedly controlled by Noriega. Hoeveler ordered about $6 million freed in June, but prosecutors said the foreign governments then confiscated the money on their own. Also at issue is $5.8 million in cash found by U.S. troops in Noriega's offices in Panama. Prosecutors said that upon surrender Noriega denied the money was his and that it was then turned over to the Panamanian government. Rubino said Noriega never disavowed the money.

DOC.HEAD: Time, PBS' `NewsHour' To Join Forces in Experiment
DOC.TEXT: Time magazine has agreed to provide PBS' ``The MacNeil-Leherer NewsHour'' with periodic documentary reports and occasional reports from Time correspondents, officials said Friday. The experiment will begin immediately, said Chris Ramsey, a spokesman for the one-hour Public Broadcasting Service show. ``NewsHour'' now has 11 correspondents worldwide, with contributions from reporters at PBS stations around the United States. Under the agreement, Time will supply the program with documentary reports co-produced with ``NewsHour,'' and will provide Time correspondents for live interviews when breaking news warrants. The test will be coordinated by Gregg Ramshaw, a Washington-based producer for ``NewsHour,'' and Barrett Seaman, deputy chief of correspondents for the magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Mozambican Refugees Being Sold As Slaves In South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Young refugees from the civil war in Mozambique are being sold in South Africa for use as slave laborers, concubines or sacrifice in magic rituals, two newspapers reported Friday. The Weekly Mail and The Sowetan, both anti-apartheid newspapers, reported that the Mozambican refugees were being sold in the Johannesburg region for about $140 each, to both whites and blacks. The reports said some slaves were killed during ``muti'' or magic rituals. The Weekly Mail said one of its reporters purchased two slaves, Jorge Mthembu, 17, and Immanuel Kambule, 18, for $80 each. The youths did not know they had been sold as slaves, it said. Reporter Phil Molefe wrote that he bought the teen-agers from a dealer near the Mozambican border. The Weekly Mail said it decided to buy slaves ``to prove that the traffic in human beings exists.'' ``They are now at my mercy. If they refuse to work, demand pay or threaten to run away I can call the police and have them arrested as illegals and deported,'' Molefe wrote. Police officials had no comment on the reports. Refugees fleeing the war in Mozambique are smuggled over the border by men claiming they will get them jobs in South Africa. Once in South Africa, the refugees are sold to farmers, businessmen or men who want wives or concubines. Many of the female slaves are between 14 and 17-years-old, the reports said. They are sold as wives or concubines and some are beaten if they refuse to sleep with their purchasers, they said. ``Young girls who refused to be sold to local men as wives were reported to have been taken to the bush - and it was not known what happened to them,'' the Mail reported. Male slaves are used to work in shops, businesses or on farms, and are purchased by whites and blacks, the reports said. The Weekly Mail said white farmers use the refugees as laborers, often providing only food or clothing and no wages. Farmers frequently call police and have them returned to Mozambique as illegal refugees when they are no longer needed, it said. Some slaves reportedly were sold for magic and killed in rituals in the black homeland of KaNgwane near Mozambique, The Sowetan reported. ``It is easy to kill them. They have no identification and no family. Their origins are unknown and, sad as it is, nobody will miss a refugee,'' aid worker Rachel Nsimbisi was quoted as saying. The Weekly Mail said refugees were willing to accept almost any conditions rather than return to Mozambique, where right-wing guerrillas are fighting the leftist government. ``Most of the fugitives are unwilling to return to Mozambique because even the most adverse conditions in South Africa - including slavery and forced labor - are preferable to life amid the devastation caused by war,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Says it Obtained CNN Tapes; Network Demands Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The box...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with FBI visiting CNN office. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `William Hinshaw...'. SUBS 20th graf, `The box...', to remove now-redundant first reference to Fernandez.
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network is demanding the FBI return a box of recordings and papers related to the government's taping of Manuel Noriega's jailhouse phone calls. The material was taken from a hotel room where a CNN reporter stayed. Both an FBI official and CNN President Tom Johnson said today they didn't know if the recordings were audio tapes or videotapes, or if they were the phone calls between Noriega and his lawyers that are at the center of a legal battle before the U.S. Supreme Court. ``We just know that there were notes, work papers and tapes'' related to CNN's coverage of the Noriega story, Johnson said. ``But in the process of working in an operation like this, you could have all sorts of tapes, including (taped) air checks.'' The box of material was given to the FBI on Thursday by security guards at the hotel. CNN claimed the box was improperly removed from the room of reporter Marlene Fernandez and that the FBI obtained it without a warrant. CNN reported today that an FBI agent showed up at the CNN Washington bureau looking for Fernandez and a producer, Kathy Slobogan. Neither was present. Bureau officials told the agent that CNN would cooperate with the FBI, but would not allow ``fishing expeditions'' through CNN offices, the network said on a midday newscast. William Hinshaw, head of the FBI bureau in Atlanta, said today that after a Thursday night meeting with CNN officials, he agreed to seal the box and not take inventory of its contents until the Justice Department orders him to do so. The FBI previously said agents would go through the box today. Hinshaw said he didn't know what materials were in the box. He said he did see some cassettes in the box, but was uncertain if they were audio or video cassettes, although he said ``one I saw appeared to be a (audio) cassette.'' The network has asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn a federal judge's order, issued last week, barring it from airing recordings of conversations between Noriega and the fallen Panamanian dictator's legal team. In addition, a hearing was scheduled in Miami this afternoon to determine whether Noriega, whose assets have been frozen by prosecutors, should be declared indigent and appointed a government defense attorney. Lead defense attorney Frank Rubino, saying it might be one of his last acts in the Noriega case, today filed a motion to dismiss the charges against Noriega, accusing the government of engaging in a conspiracy to deny ``his right to a fair trial and the effective assistance of counsel.'' The motion accuses the government of misconduct by taping Noriega's prison phone calls with his lawyers as well as illegally freezing his funds. It also says an unidentified government witness attempted to entrap the attorneys two months ago by soliciting a bribe to change his testiony. Noriega is being held in a Miami jail, awaiting trial on charges of taking $4.6 million in payoffs to protect the cocaine trade. The FBI is investigating how CNN obtained seven tapes of his jail cell phone conversations. FBI spokesman Scott Nelson in Washington said Thursday that agents obtained the box without a warrant. ``We were made aware of the tapes and merely picked them up for analysis,'' he said. Johnson said he protested the FBI's action ``in the strongest terms'' to agency officials in Washington. CNN general counsel Steve Korn said today he'd written Joseph Whitley, the U.S. attorney in Atlanta, ``demanding the return of the tapes and that the materials in the box not be reviewed or duplicated.'' The New York Times today quoted an unidentified CNN official as saying the actual Noriega recordings were not in the box. ``The FBI did not get the main course,'' the official said. The box was removed Monday from a room that had been occupied by Fernandez, who has been working on the Noriega story. Her room was at the Omni Hotel, which is owned by CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting, and is part of a complex that also houses CNN's offices. Hotel manager Bill Thompson said hotel security officers thought Fernandez had checked out when they removed a box containing papers and at least one videotape. CNN's Johnson said today that Fernandez, who has been covering the Noriega story, ``had not checked out of the room. But apparently there was a mistake'' by the hotel that led to her room being cleared out. After taking the box from the room, the hotel's security guards saw that some of its contents were CNN property, he said. They turned the material over to Turner security officers from whom the FBI took the box, he said. He and Korn said it still unclear how the FBI was notified about the box. ``I don't know who called who,'' Korn said. Turner Security, which provides security for the CNN Center complex, ``had a discussion with the FBI inquiring about stolen government property and Turner Security told them they had a box that might fit that description,'' CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said Thursday. CNN denied the material in the box was stolen. Haworth said Turner Security - a subsidiary of CNN's parent company, Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. - did not tell appropriate CNN officials it had the box. CNN said agents took the box over the objections of a network attorney who was present. Korn said the attorney ``asked for a warrant and was not given an answer, and certainly not given a warrant.'' Meanwhile, CNN lawyers on Thursday asked Supreme Court Justice Anthony Kennedy to set aside a judge's order barring broadcast of the phone conversations. Kennedy, who handles such emergency matters from Florida, referred the case to the full court. There was no word on when it might act. CNN is challenging an order issued by U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler in Miami on Nov. 8 that bars it from broadcasting the tapes until Hoeveler can determine whether the broadcasts would violate Noriega's rights. CNN refused to give up the tapes but agreed not to air any attorney-client recordings until the Supreme Court decides the matter. The network contends Hoeveler's order is an unconstitutional prior restraint on free speech. Federal prison officials say inmates' phone calls routinely are monitored, except when prisoners say they are talking to their lawyers. But CNN said it has tapes that include conversations between Noriega and his defense team.

DOC.HEAD: Two at the Wheel Arrested on Drunk Driving Charges
DOC.TEXT: One car rammed a police cruiser but authorities charged two women, saying they were intoxicated when one of them mistakenly put the car into reverse and the other stepped on the gas pedal. Police said the two shared the controls Thursday night because neither of them could operate the manual shift alone. Terry Walters, 35, was in the driver's seat operating the clutch, brake and gas pedals, police said. Amy Denise Weckman, 23, was negotiating the gear shift from the passenger seat. Both were charged with drunken driving, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Martinsburg City Council Tables Panhandling License
DOC.TEXT: City Council postponed debate on a proposed ordinance that would require panhandlers on city streets to obtain a $25 license every six months. Some council members wanted to vote on the panhandling measure separately, but it was included in a package of legislation. City Attorney J. Oakley Seibert told council members Thursday that the proposed ordinance was clearly unconstitutional. Council member George Karos said he was concerned about who would be required to obtain a panhandling license. He said he was opposed to such groups as the Salvation Army and Little League baseball players paying such fees. Mayor Tony Senecal said he'll continue to push for the ordinance, which will be discussed at the Nov. 29 council meeting.

DOC.HEAD: New Prime Minister Wins Confidence Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Prime minister's name is pronounced CHAN'dra SHAY'kur. Both names are used on second reference.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar won a parliamentary vote of confidence Friday and appealed for an end to the sectarian conflict that brought down his predecessor's government. The vote came after seven hours of acrimonious debate between supporters of the new government and lawmakers who questioned its legitimacy because of the political deals made to form it. ``The country cannot afford confrontation. We cannot go on fighting with each other,'' Chandra Shekhar told the lower house of Parliament. The 522-member house voted 269-204 in Chandra Shekhar's favor, formally endorsing his taking over as head of the government. Fifteen legislators abstained and the rest were absent. More than 390 people have been killed across India in the past four weeks in Hindu-Moslem riots and in clashes with police over a Hindu fundamentalist group's plan to build a temple at a site now occupied by a mosque. Chandra Shekhar said he would hold talks with the Hindu World Council to stop its campaign to demolish the mosque in the holy Hindu city of Ayodhya, 310 miles east of New Delhi. ``Even if they do not want to talk to me, I will go on talking to them,'' he said. ``I shall talk to every citizen of India, but there will be no compromise on the unity and integrity of India.'' Chandra Shekhar replaced his longtime rival, V.P. Singh. Singh's minority government fell apart when a right-wing Hindu party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, withdrew its support last month, angered by Singh's opposition to the temple construction plan. Chandra Shekhar belonged to Singh's Janata Dal party, but broke away two days before Singh lost a vote of confidence and resigned as prime minister Nov. 7. The temple campaign led to Hindu-Moslem riots in scores of towns and villages across India. The strife touched the capital for the first time on Wednesday when at least six people were killed in clashes. A seventh person died of stab wounds on Friday. Hindus make up 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Moslems comprise 12 percent. Chandra Shekhar's Janata Dal-Socialist party, a breakaway faction of Janata Dal, claims to have 68 sworn followers, or barely 10 percent of seats in the lower house of Parliament. But he joined with his longtime rival, ex-Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, to win enough votes for a majority. Gandhi's Congress Party and its allies have 210 seats. Chandra Shekhar defended the alliance and appealed for a ``new political climate.'' ``At this moment we should try to agree to work together,'' he said. But the alliance was denounced across the political spectrum. ``It is a mockery and debasement of democratic norms ... a two-headed monster with no body and limbs,'' said Somnath Chatterjee of the Left Front, an alliance of communist and socialist parties. Lal Krishna Advani, leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, accused Chandra Shekhar of abandoning the voters who ousted Gandhi's Congress Party from power in general elections less than a year ago. ``This government lacks political legitimacy,'' Advani said. So far, the government is composed of only Chandra Shekhar and his deputy prime minister, Devi Lal. Other Cabinet ministers are likely to be named within three days. There are doubts as to how long the new government will last. Analysts say Gandhi will withdraw his support whenever he thinks the Congress Party is ready to contest elections.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Married Almost 70 Years Die Within Four Hours of Each Other
DOC.TEXT: A man and woman only a week away from their 70th wedding anniversary died within four hours of each other at a nursing home. Daisy Ruth Smith, 89, had been in poor health but had been up and around before her death, said the Rev. Dexter Blevins, a funeral director who presided over the couple's funeral. Her 91-year-old husband, John ``Price'' Smith, died of natural causes four hours after his wife on Nov. 6. The couple married Nov. 15, 1920.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega: U.S. Trying to Win Permament Dominance in Middle East
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Daniel Ortega accused Washington Friday of using the military buildup in the Persian Gulf to win permanent dominance in the Middle East, and he likened it to the invasions of Grenada and Panama. The former Nicaraguan president criticized the United States for backing U.N. resolutions in support of occupied Kuwait, while doing little to enforce resolutions calling for Israel to withdraw from occupied territories. ``How come for them human rights apply to some people but not the others?'' asked Ortega, who arrived Wednesday on a four-day visit. ``There have been scores of (U.N.) resolutions on Israel's occupation of Palestinian land. These resolutions should be implemented too if there is to be a comprehensive settlement in the region.'' The official Iraqi News Agency reported earlier that Ortega supported Saddam Hussein's proposal for a simultaneous settlement of his invasion of Kuwait and the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories. Washington has rejected that linkage. The United States leads a multinational force of more than 350,000 troops arrayed against Iraq since its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Speaking of the U.S. gulf deployment, Ortega said: ``My country has suffered from the same policy when they tried to undermine the Sandinistas.'' Washington supported the Contra rebels who fought Ortega's leftist Sandinista government throughout most of the 1980s. Ortega was defeated in February elections by a presidential candidate supported by the United States. Referring to the 1983 U.S. invasion of Grenada and the 1989 invasion of Panama, Ortega said: ``The invasion of Grenada and the intervention in Panama are also other examples of the policy of hegemony.'' On Friday, Ortega met with Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz and National Assembly Speaker Sadi Mehdi Saleh, the Iraqi News Agency reported. It said Saleh told Ortega that Iraq wants the gulf crisis resolved peacefully. ``But if the forces of evil attempt to ignite war, then Iraq will be forced to fight back,'' the agency quoted Saleh as saying. It said that during his two separate meetings with Saleh and Aziz, Ortega expressed support of Iraq in its drive to ``liberate the region from American hegemony.'' Ortega met on Thursday with Saddam. Baghdad television said they discussed Third World countries that are ``trying to combat U.S. hegemony.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Sentence: Wine Country Mass Murderer Should Die For Seven Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to add detail, background. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A jury today sentenced mass murderer Ramon Salcido to die in the gas chamber for the 1989 wine country slayings of seven people, including his wife and two of their children. Salcido, 29, showed no reaction when an interpreter told him the jury's verdict. One juror wept as the sentence was being read. Judge Reginald Littrell sent formal sentencing for Dec. 17. He has the power to reject the death penalty decision and impose the only other alternative, life in prison, but such a move is rare in California. The jury received the penalty phase of the case Tuesday afternoon. The same panel had found him guilty of six counts of first-degree murder, one count of second-degree murder and two counts of attempted murder. Defense attorney Marteen Miller said the verdict would be appealed to U.S. District Court. The Mexican-born Salcido, who fled to his home town of Los Moches after the April 1989 slayings, was convicted of shooting or slashing to death his wife, Angela, his 4-year-old and 22-month-old daughters, Sofia and Teresa, his mother-in-law, Marion Richards, her 12-year-old and 8-year-old daughters, Ruth and Maria, and Tracey Toovey, 35, the winemaster at Grand Cru winery in Glen Ellen. The jury also convicted Salcido of attempting to murder his 2-year-old daughter, Carmina, who was found slashed next to the bodies of her sisters in a garbage dump, and Kenneth Butti, his supervisor at the winery. The defense never disputed that Salcido was the killer and during its concluding remarks to the jury called the killings ``unspeakable, horrendous, terrible crimes.'' However, Miller contended his client was high on cocaine and alcohol during the violence and described him as ``crazier than a toad'' the night of the slayings. He had sought a verdict of second-degree murder or manslaughter because he said the drugs had put Salcido in a ``psychotic depression'' when the rampage began. He also said Salcido did not cooperate with his defenders. ``He was told not to wear suit and he comes into court with a suit and wearing cowboy boots,'' Miller said. Salcido's trial was moved from Sonoma County to San Mateo County because of the extensive news coverage of the case. Littrell is a Sierra County Superior Court judge who was assigned to the case.

The United States helped organize ``sleeper'' guerrilla units in Western Europe in preparation for a possible Soviet invasion, but it had nothing to do with those cells after the 1950s, say current and former U.S. officials. Their comments contradict secret testimony obtained by The Associated Press in Rome Friday that instructors of the Italian anti-Communist network, codenamed Gladio, took part in a 1972 training exercise at a U.S. base in Germany. In the testimony, a military intelligence official who supervised Gladio in the 1970s also said the United States funded construction and a first arms shipment for a Gladio training base set up on the island of Sardinia in the 1960s. ``Gladio was a purely Italian operation. We had no connection with it'' or with other individual country networks, said one U.S. official. Former CIA director William Colby said he did not recall having any direct contact with the groups when he headed the CIA from 1973 to 1976. Speaking in an interview from Moscow, where he was attending a seminar, Colby said he helped set up such networks in Scandinavia in the early 1950s. The comments of Colby and others came amid revelations flooding Europe about the existence of anti-Soviet resistance networks in at least 15 countries - from France in the west to Turkey in the east. The operation was first exposed last month in Italy, where it was codenamed Gladio for the short swords used by Roman gladiators. Most of the cells appear to have been disbanded starting in the 1970s, although press reports say the network's controlling body still formally exists in Belgium. The CIA was aware the network was being maintained, but was not involved in its running, officials said. The idea of establishing an underground resistance network was conceived by several members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said Colby. But Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti said the idea was first broached by the United States, which approached Italy in 1951. He said the whole West European network came under NATO control only in 1959. In his 1978 memoirs, Colby said the CIA set up the Office of Policy Coordination in the late 1940s to plan ``for the not unlikely possibility of a Soviet invasion of Western Europe.'' ``The OPC wanted to be in a position to activate well-armed and well-organized partisan uprisings against the occupiers,'' he said in the book entitled ``Honorable Men - My Life in the CIA.'' An official familiar with the U.S. role, who asked not to be named, said the idea should be viewed in the context of the anti-Communist fears of the late 1940s and the Cold War of the early 1950s. With Eastern European countries falling under Soviet control one by one, with Soviet-backed North Korea invading the south, and with the anti-Communist witchhunt in the United States orchestrated by Senator Joseph McCarthy, ``it made complete sense,'' he said. With the lesson of Europe's failure to throw off Nazi occupation during World War II fresh in their minds, U.S. officials were determined to be prepared in advance against a Soviet threat. The CIA undertook ``a major program of building throughout West European countries ... clandestine infrastructures of leaders and equipment trained and ready to be called into action as sabotage and espionage forces when the time came,'' Colby wrote. Colby, who had parachuted into Norway in 1944 to link up with Norwegian resistance fighters and help them organize sabotage activity against the Nazis, was picked to set up anti-Communist networks in Scandinavia. Colby was sent to Stockholm in 1951 and for the next two years he organized ``stay behind'' networks in the four Scandinavian countries. In two of them he worked freely with the intelligence agencies; in the two others, his contacts with the intelligence agencies were limited and he had to rely more on his own contacts, Colby wrote. While he didn't identify the countries that offered him more freedom, Colby strongly indicated they were Norway and Denmark, which were members of NATO. Sweden, which is militarily neutral, and Finland are not. Colby said the operatives he recruited were civilians. One was a journalist; another an American graduate student studying in Scandinavia; a third, an American of Scandinavian descent who had returned to his native country to run a farm. In the interview, Colby said he did not know about the network's weapons caches which have been described by various European newspapers in recent days. ``I don't know about weapons caches. If they existed, they were kept secret.'' Colby said he did not have anything to do with setting up the Gladio network in Italy, although he was posted by the CIA to Rome in 1953. His task there, Colby recounted in his book, was to funnel several million dollars and U.S. expertise to strengthen the centrist political parties against the growing influence of the Italian Communist Party. Moscow was giving the Italian Communists some $50 million a year, he said, and ``it was unthinkable'' the United States would let Italy fall under Soviet control.

DOC.HEAD: Document: Gladio Leaders Trained at U.S. Base in Germany
DOC.TEXT: Officials involved in a secret European resistance network underwent training at a U.S. base in West Germany in the 1970s, according to confidential documents obtained Friday. The documents also disclosed that French and British officials involved in the network visited a training base built with U.S. money to train Italian members of Operation Gladio, as the resistance network is known. The documents sum up secret judicial testimony by Italian officials and indicate a higher level of European coordination in the anti-Communist network than had been revealed. They also were the first official corroboration of reports that the guerrilla organization existed in Britain. Also Friday, the German government announced that a branch of the secret organization still exists in that country, and will be dissolved. The guerrilla groups were formed throughout Europe after World War II by secret services to create a resistance movement or gather intelligence in the event of a Warsaw Pact invasion. They were made up of civilians and coordinated at least in part by NATO, according to officials who were involved. Some groups received CIA funds, they say. An Italian parliamentary committee that oversees secret services on Friday held a second day of closed hearings on Operation Gladio. Premier Giulio Andreotti, who first disclosed the existence of the network last month, testified. Two Venice judges, Carlo Mastelloni and Felice Casson, have been investigating whether the network was linked to a series of terrorist bombings in Italy from 1969 to the early 1980s, when the Communists, Italy's No. 2 party, came to the brink of power. A military intelligence official who supervised the operation from late 1971 to 1974 told Mastelloni that eight to 10 instructors of the guerrillas went to the main U.S. base in West Germany in 1972. There, they took part in a ``simulated exercise'' of enemy occupation, said Gen. Gerardo Serravalle. A summary of his secret testimony was obtained by The Associated Press from a parliamentary source. According to the testimony, U.S. intelligence officials invited the Italians back for another training exercise in 1974. Serravalle said an Italian training base was established on the island of Sardinia in the 1960s under a secret NATO accord. The United States provided money for construction and for the first arms shipments, which included pistols and magnesium and plastic explosives, according to the testimony. Serravalle said Italian and British Gladio organizers exchanged visits in 1972 and 1973, and that ``similar visits were made by two French officials'' to the Italian base in 1974. The British government has refused to confirm the existence of a domestic resistance network. On Friday, Defense Secretary Tom King told reporters he had never heard of Gladio. French officials have said they had such a group but that it withered away years ago. Serravalle said he attended meetings in Paris, London, Brussels and Luxembourg of European officials involved in the network. His former superior, Gen. Fausto Fortunato, testified that during his tenure, from 1971-74, the NATO committee overseeing the resistance groups included France, Britain, Germany, Italy, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands.

DOC.HEAD: Asylum-Seekers to Be Assigned to Eastern Germany
DOC.TEXT: Germany, swamped by immigrants and newcomers from all parts of the world, will assign 20 percent of all asylum-seekers to the formerly Communist east starting in December, officials said Friday. West Germany long was popular with refugees because of its generous social benefits and liberal asylum laws crafted after World War II. These now apply in former East German territory since unification on Oct. 3. The 11 states in western Germany complain they cannot cope with the growing numbers of asylum-seekers. They have demanded that Bonn put some of the burden on the five new states in eastern Germany. The number of asylum-seekers in Germany is expected to top 200,000 this year. Fewer than 4 percent of the applicants are ever expected to be granted refuge, but processing their applications can take years. Although asylum-seekers are not allowed legally to work, they are eligible for welfare benefits, including government-subsidized housing while their cases are being decided. The Interior Ministry said Friday that each of the five new states, Saxony, Brandenburg, Mecklenburg-Lower Pomerania, Saxony-Anhalt, and Thuringia, must count on receiving 8,000 asylum applicants a year starting Dec. 1. Although the western states say they can no longer cope, the new eastern states face far more serious financial difficulties in absorbing the newcomers. The Economics and Social Science Institute of the German Trade Union says the local governments face a shortage of more than $66 billion to run their communities over the next four years. The eastern state of Saxony already has registered 31 refugees from Romania, Poland, India, Lebanon, Iraq and Turkey, but could house them only in huts on the edge of town. The new states in eastern Germany also lack social counselors and translators to help the asylum seekers adapt. The liberal asylum laws were drafted in West Germany after World War II in light of the extermination of Jews, gypsies and foreigners in Nazi death camps. Parliament has been reluctant to change the law on asylum to avoid charges of intolerance. Foreigners entering Germany can immediately approach police and demand asylum. They cannot be shipped back to any area of conflict or spot where they could face political persecution. Many asylum-seekers are economic refugees. An influx of asylum-seekers in eastern Germany could cause strains with the local population, which already faces uncertainty because of the post-Communist economic crisis. Raised in a tightly controlled society, eastern Germans generally are less tolerant to foreigners than their counterparts in the west, where the notion of a multicultural society is heavily promoted. The German government contends that with the opening of borders in Europe, a Europe-wide solution is needed for the asylum problem. Bonn advocates additional economic aid, especially for the emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, to encourage potential asylum-seekers to stay home. Germany is especially worried about the possibility of a mass influx of Soviet citizens fleeing economic chaos and hunger at home once Moscow liberalizes travel laws.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest More Than 340 In Anti-Abortion Protests
DOC.TEXT: Police on Friday arrested more than 340 anti-abortion activists who tried to block entrances to two abortion clinics. The protests organized by the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue snarled morning commuter traffic near the clinics close to the downtown area. District of Columbia police, wearing riot gear, carried some demonstrators onto waiting buses. ``We will continue to save children, no matter what the courts have to say,'' Operation Rescue spokesman Pat Mahoney said. ``The sanctity and dignity of human life is what matters and we will be here.'' Police spokesmen were not immediately able to provide the charges placed against the demonstrators. Some protesters carried signs reading ``O Great God: Close Down This Killing Center!'' and ``Legalized Abortion is Legalized Murder.'' ``We fight abortion and we fight abortion until we die,'' said Martha Allen, one of dozens of activists who lined a sidewalk across the street from one clinic. She and others on the sidewalk were not arrested because they did not directly impede access to the clinic. Randall Terry, the head of Operation Rescue, said as many as 1,000 people were expected to participate in the Washington area demonstrations Friday and Saturday. Members of the local branch of the National Organization for Women and the Washington Area Clinic Defense Task Force held counter-demonstrations at the sites. ``We're here because women's constitutional rights to health care, to abortion, are denied when people blockade health care facilities,'' said Hannah Olanoff, of NOW. ``We're here because we want to see the law upheld.'' At one of the clinics, a woman held a small banner up to a second-story window, reading, ``This clinic is open.'' Members of the pro-abortion rights groups said they were prepared to escort women past the demonstrators. ``We're going to keep this clinic open,'' said Sarah Enten, a member of the clinic defense task force. Federal judges in the district, Virginia and Maryland have issued permanent injunctions against Operation Rescue, Terry and several of its other leaders to prevent them from blocking entrances or exits to clinics and from organizing protests to blockade clinics.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Bill Stirling's two dogs might ave a bone to pick with their master, who is raising the pets to be strict vegetarians like himself. ``People are curious and amused at first because it is contrary to the popular myth that dogs need to have meat to thrive,'' Stirling said. Stirling's household is bound to set the public straight. He said he feeds his dogs carrots, celery, lettuce and new-age commercial dog food that contains no animal products. Sterling says Glenda, a large malamute, and Emily, a Hungarian sheep dog, ``are absolutely thriving, in perfect physical health.'' Despite being carnivores, dogs can eat like rabbits and ``be healthy on a vegetarian diet if it is done properly,'' said Aspen veterinarian Scott Dolginow. Stirling said he and his wife, Katharine Thalberg, also avoid leather in their wardrobes to maintain their vegetarian principles. Stirling and Thalberg promoted Aspen's proposed ban on fur sales last February. Voters decisively defeated the ordinance. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Ron Reagan, son of the former president, is getting his own syndicated late-night talk show, a spokesman for the as-yet untitled weeknight series said Friday. The show, to be based in Los Angeles and co-produced by MCA-TV and Fox Television Stations Inc., will be shown on the seven TV stations owned by Fox, and syndicated to other stations. Each one-hour program will offer topical talk, comedy and contemporary music in what the show's producers called a ``thematically-driven format.'' Reagan, 32, left ABC's ``Good Morning America'' last summer after four years as a contributing reporter. --- CLEVELAND (AP) - The emir of Bahrain is receiving medical care at the Cleveland Clinic, according to a official of the Persian Gulf country's embassy in Washington. The unidentified official told The Plain Dealer newspaper that Sheik Isa bin Salman Al Khalifa, 57, flew to Cleveland from Bahrain on Wednesday for a routine checkup. The Cleveland Clinic is widely known for its coronary expertise and past treatment of leaders from the Middle East. A State Department official said the Arab leader suffered a heart attack Oct. 14. Hospital officials on Friday refused to confirm the sheik's visit. Bahrain is supporting the U.S. effort to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The Khalifa family has ruled the country since 1782. Sheik Isa became emir in 1961. --- NASHVILLE, Tenn. (AP) - Country singer Carlene Carter is planning a sentimental journey with her father, Nashville crooner Carl Smith, on a cable television program. Carter will perform the song ``You Are the One,'' which Smith originally recorded in 1956 - the year she was born. Carter brought back the tune this year by recording it for her hit album ``I Fell in Love.'' Smith, 63, who has not performed publicly for five years, also will sing on the ``Nashville Now'' variety program Monday on The Nashville Network. He will perform his 1971 song ``Red Door.'' Susan Sizemore, a spokeswoman for the show, said Friday there are no plans for them to sing together. Carter's mother is country music veteran June Carter Cash, now married to country star Johnny Cash.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Named King of Doublespeak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The White ...' with three grafs to UPDATE with Mobil comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's waffling on taxes and refusal to use the word ``invasion'' in describing events in Panama won him the 1990 Doublespeak Award on Friday from the National Council of Teachers of English. The group cited the president's pledge of ``no new taxes'' and his later call for ``tax revenue increases'' as well as his statements on maternity leave and foreign policy as the reasons for naming him. The citation calls attention to statements by officials that are ``grossly deceptive, evasive, euphemistic, confusing or self-contradictory,'' said William Lutz, chairman of the organization's Committee on Public Doublespeak. Second place went to Mobil Corp. for calling one of its trash bags ``photodegradable'' even while they're buried in landfills. And third place went to Rep. Newt Gingrich, the House minority whip, for supporting and then opposing tax increases. Before opposing Bush on the tax increase, the Georgia Republican defended the president's stand on raising taxes by saying, ``He very explicitly didn't say, `Raise taxes.' He said, `Seek new revenues.''' The White House issued no response to the ``award'' Friday and a telephone call to Gingrich's office elicited no immediate response. Mobil spokesman John Lord said the company never claimed the bags would degrade in landfills. He said the company contended that an environmentally safe additive speeded decomposition when the bags were exposed to sunlight. He said Mobil had added the reference to ``degradability'' because of marketing pressures but later deleted the word because of ``mounting confusion.'' Bush's doublespeak included statements about maternity leave, the teachers group said. During his campaign, he said, ``We ... need to assure that women do not have to worry about getting their jobs back after having a child or caring for a child during a serious illness.'' But after his election, Bush vetoed the bill for parental and medical leave. A White House statement said the president ``has always been opposed to the federal government mandating what every business in this country should do.'' Lutz of Rutgers University also cited two examples of foreign policy: the U.S. response to the June 1989 massacre in Beijing and the December invasion of Panama. After the Tiananmen Square killings, Bush announced suspension of U.S. ``participation in all high-level exchanges of government officials'' with China. Two weeks later, Bush secretly sent National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft and Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger to China, Lutz said. Bush called the trip a ``contact,'' not an ``exchange,'' and resumed negotiations for arms sales to China. Lutz also said Bush refused to refer to the U.S. mission in Panama as an invasion, saying he ``deployed forces'' in Operation Just Cause. But at a Dec. 21 news conference, Bush said: ``You could say, `How come you didn't tell me that you were going to invade the - send in those troops down into Panama?''' The group also awarded Charlotte Baecher, author of ``Selling America's Kids: Commercial Pressures on Kids of the '90s,'' the committee's 1990 George Orwell Award for Honesty and Clarity in Public Language.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Sentencing for Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: The sentencing of Michael Milken, former head of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s junk bond department, will take place Wednesday, the judge announced Friday. Milken, 44, pleaded guilty in April to six felonies. He faces a maximum sentence of 28 years in prison. The sentencing originally had been set for Oct. 1, but was postponed so that U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood could hear evidence to help her decide Milken's sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Scraps Ground-to-Ground Missiles
DOC.TEXT: Hungary, which has urged the Warsaw Pact to disband, said Friday it is unilaterally scrapping its Soviet-made ground-to-ground missiles, all capable of carrying nuclear warheads. The Defense Ministry, which made the announcement, also gave figures on the number of such missiles in other Warsaw Pact nations and said Hungary's destruction of the weapons will be completed by the spring. The decision, made at Thursday's Cabinet session, was taken to reflect the reduction of East-West tensions and changes within the Warsaw Pact, a government statement said, alluding to the pact's de-facto termination as a Soviet-led military organization. Hungary has made it clear that it believes the Warsaw Pact no longer serves a useful purpose, so it was not surprising that it became the first member to unilaterally scrap its missiles. Col. Gyoergy Keleti, a Defense Ministry spokesman, repeated the government stance that Hungary plans to leave the military part of pact next year if it is not dissolved by then. Hungarian officials said on Thursday that the six-nation pact had agreed to terminate its military role by July. The army's 24 SCUD-B tactical missiles have a range of 180 miles. Its 107 FROG-7 missiles can travel 50 miles. Hungary's 27 mobile launchers also will be dismantled, and the 3,200-strong missile unit of soldiers will be retrained for other duties, Keleti said. He told reporters that the Soviet Union had 1,200 of the two kinds of missiles; Czechoslovakia 75; Romania 50; Bulgaria more than 70, and Poland 80. NATO and Warsaw Pact negotiators reached agreement in Vienna on Thursday on cutting conventional arms in Europe. Keleti told reporters that Hungary had been allotted 835 tanks, 1,700 armored vehicles, 840 artillery pieces, 180 fighter planes and 108 combat helicopters under the overall Warsaw Pact ceiling. Keleti, reacting to recent Soviet statements that the withdrawing Red Army ``no longer'' has nuclear weapons in Hungary, said the Soviets in the past had denied having nuclear weapons in their Hungarian arsenal. Under troop cuts that began last year, Hungary's armed forces will number 80,000 by December, down from 106,800.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Deny Wrongdoing in Keating Five Hearing
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston actively solicited contributions from savings and loan owner Charles H. Keating Jr. at times when Keating wanted help with federal banking regulators, the Senate Ethics Committee's special counsel charged today. Cranston denied any wrongdoing. ``I engaged in no unethical conduct,'' he told the committee. ``You know that I broke no law.'' Cranston, who is ill with prostate cancer, made his first appearance in two days of hearings. He spoke after two other members under investigation, John McCain, R-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio, issued similar declarations of innocence. Still to be heard were Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Don Riegle, D-Mich. All five are under investigation for their links to Keating, whose Lincoln Savings and Loan failed at an estimated cost to taxpayers of $2 billion. Earlier, committee counsel Robert S. Bennett outlined his case against Cranston. ``On approximately four separate occasions Senator Cranston accepted or solicited several hundred thousand dollars from Mr. Keating'' for his campaigns or voter registration drives to which he was closely associated, Bennett said. ``Each of these four occasions was linked by time and circumstance to a request by Mr. Keating for assistance'' with federal bank regulators, Bennett said. When his turn came, McCain told the committee: ``I know I acted ethically and properly and in compliance with all applicable standards of conduct, including my own.'' And Glenn testified that, ``at no time did I ask for special treatment for anyone and at no time did I trade favors or perform actions in return for money.'' Cranston told the committee that, ``You know that I pocketed no money - that there was no personal gain for me or any member of my family. ... I never recommended, much less demanded, that any government official do anything improper or grant any constituent any special favor.'' ``Yes, I was persistent in expressing my concerns about the way bureaucrats were dealing with this large business in my state,'' he said, referring to Lincoln, which was chartered in California. ``I believed that its failure, if it came to that ... would be a catastrophe for countless constituents of mine.'' The day's hearing began on a dramatic note when Cranston's lawyer asked that one of the six committee members, Sen. Jesse Helms, be barred from judging the California Democrat. Helms, speaking under oath, stoutly denied the charge by Cranston attorney William W. Taylor III that he had already made up his mind in the case. He refused to step aside and the hearings continued. Bennett pointed to Cranston's own words, in a deposition taken by Ethics Committee lawyers, in which the senator freely acknowledged Keating's access to him was ``in part because of his substantial contributions.'' ``During his deposition, Senator Cranston said, `A person who makes a contribution has a better chance to get access than someone who does not,''' Bennett recounted. Bennett said Keating made a $100,000 contribution to a voter registration project associated with Cranston on March 3, 1987, less than a month before Cranston and other senators met with top bank regulator Edwin Gray on behalf of Keating. That fall, Keating gave another $250,000, and six days later Cranston called Gray's successor, Danny Wall. Bennett cited a memo to Cranston from one of his fund-raisers, who said Wall's appointment was ``good news'' for Keating. The same memo said, ``You should ask Keating for $250,000.'' At the time, Keating was seeking to have bank regulators waive a rule limiting risky investments by Lincoln. Bennett depicted Cranston as aggressively seeking contributions from Keating. ``It was very clear Senator Cranston solicited contributions and sought contributions from Mr. Keating,'' Bennett said. Bennett drew repeated expressions of irritation from Ethics Chairman Howell Heflin, who suggested Bennett was singling out Cranston when many senators request contributions from donors. At one point, when Bennett insisted he was being evenhanded, Heflin interjected, ``Selectively.'' Heflin reminded Bennett he was not a prosecutor but was there to assist in collecting facts. Bennett replied: ``I'm not tilting the facts, Mr. Chairman. The facts tilt.'' The panel is looking into any connections between $1.3 million in donations Keating made to the five men or their favored causes, and their efforts to intervene with federal regulators looking at the savings and loan. Bennett was expected to finish his presentation when the panel reconvened today, but Taylor first sought to have Helms recuse himself. He cited reports from Helms' recent, successful re-election campaign in which the North Carolina Republican had referred to Cranston as ``the leading water carrier'' for Keating. ``It appears to me that a reasonable person would conclude that Senator Helms has not only made up his mind about the issue but that he has already said so,'' said Taylor. Helms acknowledged making the remarks, and said he did so after his Democratic opponent in the campaign received a contribution from Cranston's political action committee. ``Senator Cranston injected himself into that campaign, and I was entitled to try to eject him. I make no apology for what I said because it was true,'' Helms said. ``Neither Senator Cranston's partisanship nor mine will play any role in my decision,'' Helms said. ``If the weight of evidence shows that Senator Cranston has indeed brought discredit upon the Senate I will vote accordingly. If the evidence shows otherwise, I will base my decision upon that.''

DOC.HEAD: Tree-Mendous: Rockefeller Center Getting Spruced Up
LaserPhoto NY26
DOC.TEXT: It was a balmy 71 degrees, but the scent of Christmas was in the air Friday as a 75-foot-high Norway spruce was hoisted into place at Rockefeller Center. The Christmas tree, the 58th erected in front of the skating rink and above the gilded sculpture of Prometheus, will be the main attraction for millions of holiday revelers. During the next two weeks, crews will decorate the huge spruce with 20,000 multi-colored lights that will blink to life Dec. 3 at a ceremony led by Liza Minnelli. This year's tree was donated by Charles Cenci of Norwalk, Conn., in honor of Cenci's father, who planted the tree in his front yard 61 years ago when it was 6 inches tall. ``I figured a lot of people would enjoy it,'' Cenci said Thursday as crews prepared to cut it down. Cenci's sister, Shirley, said their father would have been proud to see the tree become one of New York City's holiday centerpeces. ``I almost cried about 10 times today,'' Ms. Cenci said as she searched the ground for fallen branches to place in a basket to adorn her parents' graves at Christmas. The Rockefeller Center Christmas tree tradition began in 1931, when construction workers, grateful for employment during the Depression, erected a small tree to celebrate the holiday. This year's evergreen was put in place on one of the warmest mornings in weeks, 71 degrees and one degree below the 1928 record for the date, the National Weather Service said.

DOC.HEAD: Challenger For Republican Party Post Charges Financial Mismanagement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf prvs with two grafs of comment from NRCC
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Guy Vander Jagt's challenger for the top House Republican campaign post is charging financial mismanagement of the multimillion-dollar committee and raising questions about payoffs to its employees. The challenger, Rep. Don Sundquist of Tennessee, has challenged Vander Jagt in a letter to account for money the National Republican Congressional Committee has raised and spent over the past decade. Copies of the letter were circulated to all House Republicans on Thursday. Sundquist's letter to the Michigan congressman notes that the NRCC raised $28.5 million in the two-year election cycle leading up to the Nov. 6 voting, finished the period $2.5 million in debt and funneled only 7 percent of the money directly to candidates. ``I have serious concerns about the financial management of the committee,'' wrote Sundquist, R-Tenn. Sundquist's letter posed 16 detailed questions to Vander Jagt, including whether the committee has rules against its employees receiving ``commissions, royalties, dividends, consulting fees, expensive gifts, the use of vacation homes or other rewards'' from committee consultants or vendors. Gary Koops, a spokesman for the NRCC, said the committee is audited annually and all its contributions and spending are documented in reports filed with the Federal Election Commission. ``If he were serious about getting answers, he'd go look at those reports,'' Koops said of Sundquist. He said Vander Jagt has helped build the organization rom one with a $750,000 budget in 1975 to a $15-20 million annual operation now, with 1.3 million active donors. The toughly worded challenge came just a week after House elections in which the Republicans lost a net of nine seats and sank to their lowest level of strength in the chamber since 1982. Sundquist asked that Vander Jagt, R-Mich., reply to the questions by Nov. 27 so lawmakers can know the answers before they vote for NRCC chief. Vander Jagt has held the post for 14 years. The 167 Republicans in the 102nd Congress that convenes in January will meet at the Capitol in early December to choose their leaders for the coming two years. The race for chairman of the NRCC is the hottest of those contests. Sundquist began contacting colleagues a week before the elections and asking them to support him for the post. The move came on the heels of a highly publicized snit between the White House and Ed Rollins, Vander Jagt's chief operative at the committee, over an NRCC memo telling Republican House candidates it was OK to oppose President Bush's stand on the federal budget. A supporter of Vander Jagt, House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich, sought to portray Sundquist's challenge as inspired by the White House as a vendetta against Rollins, but Sundquist has denied it. ``There was never a meeting, note, conversation or contact with the White House,'' said Sundquist spokesman Ralph Perrey. ``This effort is coming from House members who are concerned about the way the committee has been run.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Suspected In Hiker Deaths Agrees to Extradition
DOC.TEXT: A man accused in the deaths of two hikers who were shot and stabbed as they slept in a remote area of the Appalachian Trail has agreed to return to Pennsylvania to face charges. Paul David Crews of Loris, S.C., a suspect in at least one other murder, waived extradition from West Virginia Thursday. ``I gave him the options; he made the decision,'' said Jerome Dambro, the public defender appointed to represent Crews. ``He decided it was his best interest to face the charges in Pennsylvania.' Authorities suspect Crews in the Sept. 13 slayings of Geoffrey Logan Hood and Molly LaRue near Duncannon, Pa. Ms. LaRue, 25, of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Hood, 26, of Signal Mountain, Tenn., were hiking along the 2,160-mile trail, which runs from Maine to Georgia. They were found dead in their sleeping bags. Crews was arrested Sept. 21 in Harpers Ferry. Authorities said he was wearing one of the hiker's boots and carrying one of their backpacks. He told police that his name was David ``Casey'' Horn and signed that name to his extradition papers. But FBI officials in Florida identified him as Crews, who also is sought in the 1986 slashing death of Clemmie Jewel Arnold of Bartow, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Landlords Not Criminally Liable in Deadly Fire
DOC.TEXT: Three landlords of a building that housed a social club where 87 people were killed in a March arson fire are not criminally liable for the blaze, a prosecutor has decided. Bronx District Attorney Robert T. Johnson made the announcement Thursday after a hearing for Julio Gonzalez, who was charged with 178 counts of murder, arson and related crimes. During the court appearance before state Justice Burton B. Roberts, Gonzalez's lawyer, Richard Berne, repeated his plan to use the an insanity defense. Gonzalez was accused of splashing gasoline inside the club's entrance March 25 before lighting it and causing the blaze. Immediately after the fire, much discussion focused on whether the building's landlords could be charged in connection with the fire. But Johnson said an extensive investigation had determined that Alex DiLorenzo, whose corporation owned the property, and Jay Weiss and Morris Jaffe, leaseholders and managing agents, were not criminally liable. The prosecutor said defects and safety violations ``contributed substantially'' to the harm caused by the fire. He said the three landlords took at least some steps ``however ineffectually'' to try to fix the violations, including demanding that the club be closed and attempting to evict the tenant who was staging them. ``Thus, there is insufficient proof that their behavior rises to the level of criminal conduct,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Czechoslovak Ties Honored On Eve of Bush Visit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT spelling of `prelude.'
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovaks on Friday excitedly awaited President Bush's arrival on a history-making visit coinciding with the first anniversary of the ``Velvet Revolution'' that toppled communist rule. On the eve of its first-ever U.S. presidential visit, Prague officially renamed its railway station in honor of President Woodrow Wilson, who encouraged a much earlier Czechoslovak push for independence. The simple ceremony, said Praque Mayor Jaroslav Koran, was a fitting prelude to a presidential visit that would ``complete the magic circle'' of U.S.-Czechoslovak relations. ``As if with a message from our ancestors,'' he said, ``the president will visit for the first time ever.'' Within the citadels of power in the post-Cold War Prague government and among the populace at large, excitement - even exhileration - was in the air. ``It's perfect,'' 24-year-old medical student Tomas Sklenar said of the timing of Bush's visit. ``American democracy is the greatest ideal,'' exulted Karel Kren, who also is studying medicine. In anticipation of Bush's arrival Saturday, Czechoslovaks donned buttons showing a smiling U.S. president with the inscription, ``Thank You!'' American flags fluttered in the breeze, mounted on elegant buildings alongside Czechoslovakia's national flag of matching red, white and blue. ``It's good he's coming on Nov. 17,'' said Zdenek Matejovsky, a 32-year-old waiter, who waived the American flag and then impishly hid his face behind a mask of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush's trip comes at a period of substantially improved relations between Washington and Prague. Only a week ago, the president signed legislation extending most-favored-nation trade status. Bush at the time called the measure ``an important milestone not only in U.S.-Czechoslovak relations, but also in re-integration into the global economy and the community of free nations.'' Earlier this fall, in a meeting in New York with Czech President Vaclav Havel, Bush announced he was lifting travel restrictions on Czechoslovakia's diplomats in the United States. Three months earlier, U.S. officials said that Prague had agreed to accept U.S. Peace Corps volunteers. Bush hosted Havel at the White House, and the playwright and former prisoner under the communist regime, addressed a joint meeting of Congress. On Friday, Czechoslovak officials restored Wilson's place in this country's history, cementing ties that stretch back to when Wilson helped his friend Tomas G. Masaryk gain Czech and Slovak independence from the crumbling Austro-Hungarian Empire. Wilson recognized Masaryk's ``de facto government'' set up in U.S. exile before independence. Masaryk, a philosopher and acknowledged role model for Havel, became the first head of the new state in 1918. Prague's main railway station was named after Wilson in gratitude for his help. His name was dropped after the communists seized power in 1948, but remained customary for Prague residents. ``Wilson's station has never stopped being Wilson's station ... even when frightened (Communist) rulers tried to wipe out all reference to the connections of our history with the ideals of American democracy,'' Koran said at the renaming ceremony. Czechs and Slovaks, like many other East Europeans, looked to America as a model of democracy during their four decades of authoritarian communist rule. The turbulent history of this century has given Czechoslovaks added reason to admire America. Caught on the crossroads of Europe, the two Slav nations have traditionally looked both East and West in their effort to win and preserve independence. Embittered by Stalinist repressions in the 1950s and the Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed communist-led reform in 1968, Czechoslovaks have lost any love for the Soviets, who liberated the country from the Nazis at the end of World War II. The betrayal of the 1938 Munich agreement by which Britain and France allowed Nazi Germany to annex one-third of Czechoslovakia's territory soured relations with the British and French. Nazi occupation fanned Czech hatred of the Germans, who historically sought to dominate the Czech lands. After World War II, Czechoslovakia brutally expelled about 2.5 million ethnic Germans. These clouded relationships with other Western nations adds to the respect for America which found voice on the streets of Prague Friday. ``I know that in America he's not very popular with the budget deficit and some other problems,'' Sklenar said, but Mr. Reagan (former President Ronald) could not come here, so it's perfect that Mr. Bush does.'' The Czechoslovaks have said that Bush asked to attend Saturday's anniversary. ``We are happy!'' a banner draped from a balcony proclaimed.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Speeding up Shift to Bigger Tanks for Desert Shield
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps is beefing up its ground assault strength in Saudi Arabia by equipping a reinforcement unit with new M1-A1 battle tanks, officials said Friday. The two Marine tank battalions already in the Persian Gulf area are equipped with 1960s-designed M60 tanks, which are lighter and not as well protected. The Marines decided shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 to speed up a previously planned switch from the M60 tanks to the M1-A1, the most modern U.S. battle tank, said Lt. Col. Ron Stokes, a Marine Corps spokesman. Similarly, the Army recently began substituting M1-A1s held in storage in Europe for its older M1 tanks deployed in Saudi Arabia, and it is expected to have more than 1,000 of the top-of-the-line tanks in the area by the end of the year. Iraq has about 3,500 tanks in and around Kuwait, according to the Pentagon. However, only about 600 are believed to be the modern, Soviet-designed T-72 model. Strokes said the 2nd Tank Battalion, now being trained on the M1-A1 in the United States, will deploy to the gulf with 58 of the modern tanks as part of a huge wave of Marine reinforcements for Operation Desert Shield over the next several weeks. The approximately 45,000 Marines in Saudi Arabia and afloat on amphibious assault ships have about 140 M60 tanks. There are no immediate plans to switch those to M1-A1s. The Marines had been scheduled to start getting M1-A1s next February or March, but the gulf build-up led Marine Corps leaders to speed up the transition, Stokes said. Besides being shielded with better armor than older tanks, the M1-A1's 120mm gun provides greater firepower and its ``overpressure'' system provides more protection against attack from chemical, biological or nuclear agents.

DOC.HEAD: Skeletal Remains Found in Field Were Those of Missing Woman
DOC.TEXT: Skeletal remains found in a farm field were those of a missing Missouri woman, and a man charged in the slaying of another woman was tied to both deaths, officials said. The remains found Sunday in the northeast Kansas field were identified Thursday as those of Patricia Diane Rose, 31, of St. Joseph. An autopsy showed she died of blows to the head, said St. Joseph police spokesman Sgt. Jim Connors. The body of Crystal Lynn Simmons, 33, also of St. Joseph, was found in the field Monday about 400 yards from the remains of Ms. Rose. Ms. Simmons also died of blows to the head, officials said. Marvin L. Irvin, 41, was charged with murder in Ms. Simmons' death.
