Authorities said he probably also will be charged with a second count. ``We have both physical and witness evidence that would link (Irvin) with Ms. Rose,'' said Dwight Scroggins, the Buchanan County, Mo., prosecutor. The farm where the women were buried is near property once owned by Irvin's family. Authorities say Irvin also was a suspect in the disappearance of another St. Joseph woman, Micki Jo West, 19, who has been missing since 1979. Irvin was held without bond in Buchanan County on a parole violation charge in Iowa. He was convicted in 1988 of threatening a Jefferson, Iowa, woman. Irvin's attorney sought a gag order Thursday to prevent St. Joseph police and prosecutors from commenting on the case to the media. ``We think it's endangering our client's right to a fair trial,'' said Buchanan County public defender Timothy D. Ernst. ``There are allegations of other crimes ... he has not been charged with.'' A hearing on the gag order was set for Wednesday in Buchanan County. Patricia Rose's sister, Vickie Fadden, said her family was relieved that their waiting was over. ``I feel that we are lucky that they found her,'' Fadden said. ``We don't have to worry about her like the family of Micki Jo West must have for all of these years.'' Police said they would continue searching for other remains.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran Governors Help New Governors at Seminar
DOC.TEXT: Twelve new governors are learning the ins and outs of their offices from their veteran colleagues during a National Governors' Association seminar. ``It's the nuances of how you deal with your schedule, how you involve your spouse, how you use state facilities, how you deal with security,'' Washington Gov. Booth Gardner explained to reporters Friday. The organization held its first seminar in 1968 and has held one every two years since. This session began Thursday and continues through Sunday. ``They seem excited,'' Gardner said while the closed-door training sessions were conducted. ``My view is governors today are more and more coming in with a broader background and a greater realization that a government is a service organization.'' He added that new governors coming from the private sector must learn to include constituents in the decision-making process. ``When you realize that you represent the entire public,'' he said, ``you owe it to the entire public to allow them access to government and an opportunity to be heard.'' The seminar's host, Kentucky Gov. Wallace Wilkinson, said he missed out on a seminar because he was elected in 1987, during an off year. Wilkinson urged the new governors to ``retain that vision that you communicated so well'' while campaigning. Gardner stressed the importance of a good relationship between a governor and the legislature. He said a legislative liaison is ``perhaps the most important hire they can have after a scheduler. ``Anything you want to do in terms of vision or planning is dependent on your ability to access successfully with the legislatures and get legislation passed,'' he said. Governors-elect attending the meeting are from Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Kansas, Massachusetts, Michigan, Nebraska, Ohio, Oklahoma, Oregon, Rhode Island and Vermont.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Extends Freeze on Most Military Building Projects
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney extended a freeze on most military construction on the same day that President Bush empowered him to bypass Congress for authority to start building projects related to Operation Desert Shield. The Pentagon announced Friday that Cheney had extended the construction freeze before it expired at midnight Thursday. It applies to all military building projects except those related to Desert Shield and those required for certain base closings. Cheney first imposed the freeze Jan. 24 in light of planned changes in the structure and size of U.S. military forces and because of expected base closings. The extended freeze is effective until April 16, 1991. In a statement, Cheney said it was necessary because of ``continuing changes in the world situation'' and limits on defense funds. On Thursday, Bush invoked emergency powers authorizing Cheney to undertake construction projects in the Persian Gulf without advance approval from Congress. The Pentagon has not said how many construction projects it plans in the gulf, where more than 230,000 U.S. troops are deployed and about 200,000 more are being sent in response to Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee and chairwoman of the subcommittee on military installations and facilities, criticized the Bush administration for holding up projects already approved by Congress while bypassing Congress to start others. ``On the same day the secretry is deciding to cancel all military construction worldwide for another five months,'' Bush authorized the use of $6 billion in military construction funds for Persian Gulf projects ``without permitting any congressional oversight,'' she said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Horse Advertisement Banned On Grounds It's Too Shocking
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have banned an animal welfare group's advertisement showing a dead horse dangling by its neck from a meat hook on the grounds that it is too shocking. The double-page advertisement of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals appeared in The Times of London, The Independent and other newspapers on Thursday. Its aim was to win support for preventing the export of horses for slaughter to other European nations in 1992, when the 12-nation European Common Market is to abolish trade barriers. After the ad was banned by the Advertising Standards Authority, it was run Friday by the London-based Guardian newspaper, with a blank space where the picture of the horse had been. The caption read: ``Unfortunately the photograph that should accompany the text opposite was withdrawn at the request of the Advertising Standards Authority.'' A spokesman for the watchdog group said it ordered the ban because the ad ``was likely to cause unnecessary offense and distress to the public.'' Horse meat is virtually never eaten by Britons, but it is a regular part of the diet among French and other continental Europeans. The text with the advertisement read: ``The continentals love freshly butchered horse meat. When are we going to supply it? ``Sadly, we are going to supply it after 1992. Because in 1992, it will once again become legal to transport live British horses to the continent for slaughter.'' The ad said the export was banned 30 years ago on the grounds of cruelty to animals. Earlier this year, the animal protection group shocked many newspaper readers with advertisements showing a pile of dead dogs to try to win support for a dog registration scheme to reduce the number of strays. The Advertising Standards Authority did not criticize that ad. But Caroline Crawford, the authority's spokeswoman, said it intervened in the latest case because ``this particular advertisement, we felt, was likely to cause unnecessary offense and distress to the public at large.'' Gavin Grant of the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals countered that the ``seriousness and importance of the subject matter unarguably warranted such an approach.'' ``Three-quarters of a million live British animals, including sheep, already travel for more than a day without food and water, often arriving exhausted, battered or dead ... The prospect of horses joining that is appalling,'' Grant told British Broadcasting Corp. radio.

DOC.HEAD: Former Press Aide Says Governor Often Depressed
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton undergoes wild mood swings and at times becomes so depressed that he cancels his day's schedule, said an ex-aide who Caperton fired earlier this week after a shoving match. G.C. Morse, a former press aide, said Caperton ``has some problems but I don't know exactly what they are.'' ``All I know is that they are causing great harm to the state and himself. There are some dark things happening,'' Morse was quoted as saying in Friday's The Herald-Dispatch of Huntington. Morse said Caperton's ``mood swings are incredible. ... There have been days when he came into his office and decided he didn't want to do anything, so his schedule would simply be wiped off.'' Caperton's communications director, Bob Brunner, dismissed Morse's comments as coming from ``a bitter and disillusioned ex-employee'' who ``is trying to taint an entire administration with his own ineptitude.'' Morse, 41, and Caperton, 50, shoved one another Wednesday after Morse was fired from a $58,000-a-year job as a position paper writer for the Division of Energy. Morse, a distant cousin of the governor's, said he challenged Caperton on reasons the governor was giving for firing Larry George, the former energy commissioner, and that prompted the pushing. The incident ended when a state trooper grabbed Morse. George said he was dismissed as energy commissioner in a disagreement over the duties of the No. 2 man in the Division of Energy, William Willis. Caperton described Willis as a personal friend who has his wholehearted support. Caperton hired Morse in January to replace press secretary Steve Cohen. Morse was ousted in August over a conflict in philosophy with the governor. Morse transferred to the Division of Energy. Caperton, a millionaire businessman, defeated Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. in the 1988 election to win his first term. Caperton and his first wife, Dee, ended their 23-year marriage in a messy divorce last fall. In May, Caperton married Rachael Worby, conductor of the Wheeling Symphony Orchestra. Morse said the changes are affecting Caperton's actions, including a recent trip, and his opinions. ``I think there's something to the fact that he got all the way to San Francisco last weekend on his trip to Japan, then turned around and came back,'' Morse said. ``I know it was reported he was physically ill, but when I saw him (Wednesday) morning, he certainly didn't look ill to me.''

DOC.SECOND: Wasps Sent Out To Sting Cabbage-Munching Caterpillar
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of tiny wasps were unleashed on a Texas field this week as growers look for new ways to control a pesticide-resistant caterpillar that leaves cabbage heads ``so full of holes they look like lace.'' Four species of wasps, some smaller than the head of a pin, were sprinkled across a commercial field of cabbage in the Rio Grande Valley on Thursday. If successful against the caterpillars, growers may see the benefits of using the wasps on other crops such as broccoli, cauliflower and kale, said Don Nordlund, a research entomologist at the USDA's Agricultural Research Service in Weslaco, Texas. Because consumers also want more pesticide-free produce, ``we may be able to start convincing growers to switch to this approach after this first crop,'' Nordlund said Friday. He said caterpillars of the diamondback moth - the cabbage patch's worst insect enemy - are resistant to almost all available insecticides. Insects have been used to control pests on the Valley's citrus and sugar cane crops, but Nordlund said wasps have never been tested on a commercial cabbage crop in Texas. Growers showed little interest when wasps were tried elsewhere in the early 1970s, and the diamondback moth has since become resistant to pesticides. According to entomologist K. Duane Biever of the Agricultural Research Service's fruit and vegetable research unit in Yakima, Wash., the wasps lay eggs inside the caterpillars. ``The larvae that hatch from those eggs feed off their caterpillar host, eventually killing it,'' he said. The wasps, however, do not sting people or animals. Biever said the nipping and gnawing pests cause more than $35 million in damage annually to cabbage crops nationwide. The caterpillars leave cabbage heads ``so full of holes they look like lace,'' said M.A. Maedgen Jr., president of Biofac, the Texas company that supplies the wasps.

DOC.HEAD: Stormie's Cause of Death: Heart Rejection
DOC.TEXT: Sudden heart rejection caused the death of 13-year-old Stormie Jones six years after she became the world's first heart-liver transplant recipient, doctors said Friday. The autopsy results surprised Stormie's doctors, who said heart rejection was rare so many years after a transplant. ``I've never seen it occur or reported in the literature,'' said Dr. F. Jay Fricker, Stormie's cardiologist at Children's Hospital. ``No one expected to see any rejection in Stormie,'' he said. ``After all, we had a track record of more than six years of never seeing any heart rejection. So why would we suddenly see it now?'' Stormie died Sunday at Children's Hospital, where she had her historic operation Feb. 14, 1984, after being rushed from her home in White Settlement, Texas, with a sore throat and fever. She is to be buried Saturday in her hometown. Fricker said it would take doctors months to determine, if at all, what caused the sudden rejection. Doctors would not speculate about whether FK-506, an experimental anti-rejection drug Stormie began receiving last November, a second liver transplant underwent last February or treatment for recurring hepatitis had anything to do with the rejection. ``She was on the appropriate medications at the appropriate dosages,'' said Dr. Jorge Reyes, a liver transplant surgeon. ``But, obviously, if she developed a rejection she broke through these medications. ``Each patient ... metabolizes drugs at different rates, and their immune systems can be stimulated to different degrees,'' he said. ``Particularly patients like Stormie, who had another process ongoing - hepatitis, you have to balance it even further. It's not an easy thing to do.'' Stormie last had a heart checkup 11 months ago by her doctors in Dallas and was scheduled to undergo another within the next few months, Fricker said. The checkup showed no abnormalities, he said. The girl needed the transplant because of hypocholesteremia, a rare genetic disorder that prevented her body from processing cholesterol. Her sister, Misty, suffers from a milder form of the disease. For five years after her first transplant, Stormie had few major medical problems. Her setbacks began in October 1988, when she returned to Pittsburgh for surgery to remove a bile duct obstruction. She underwent a mild episode of liver rejection in November 1989 and began receiving FK-506, which is being tested at the University of Pittsburgh, instead of the traditional anti-rejection drug cyclosporine. A bout with hepatitis in February slowly damaged her liver, requiring a second liver transplant. But post-surgery studies showed no evidence of heart problems, Fricker said. Stormie began rejecting the second liver in May and was treated with an increased FK-506 dosage. A month later, she received medication to combat yet another bout of hepatitis. Recent flu-like symptoms were the only indication something was wrong. ``If she had gotten here earlier, we would have suspected some heart dysfunction ... and instituted appropriate treatment,'' Fricker said. Still, Reyes said he considered the double transplant a success. ``When you think ... that she lived for almost seven years, then I think this was an inherent success because she had the opportunity to live, to share things, not only with her family, but the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs 8 Environmental Protection Measures
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday signed into law a bill barring U.S. mineral activities in Antarctica for the time being, although his administration opposes a permanent ban. The Antarctic Protection Act of 1990 was one of eight measures Bush signed Friday that are intended to also protect the environment in the Florida Keys, Louisiana, New Jersey, the Nevada desert and coastal regions, as well as provide money for global warming research, clean up the Great Lakes and provide grants for environmental education. The Antarctic law will ban indefinitely U.S. mineral activities in the region until a new international minerals agreement is approved by Congress. That agreement would first have to be worked out by an international conference. Bush's action came three days before the start of a conference in Chile where 24 countries will take up the future of Antarctica. Environmental groups have urged the president to commit the United States to joining other nations, including France, Australia and New Zealand, that want to make a permanently protected world park in the frozen continent. U.S. officials say they oppose the permanent ban, urging instead an international compact for a limited moratorium on oil drilling and other minerals development. They said a long-term moratorium was the preferred middle ground between those nations wanting to block mining forever and those, like the United States, unwilling to rule it out. Environmentalists claim that the indefinite ban merely gives industry time to prepare the technology for eventual development and mining. But the White House touted Bush's action on Friday as ``advocating a forceful environmental protection agreement to supplement the Antarctic Treaty'' that has been in effect since 1959. ``Clearly, all of us must work together to preserve America's natural beauty,'' Bush said at a ceremony on the South Lawn of the White House to sign the Antarctic bill and seven others. He also signed measures to: -Establish the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, designating 2,600 square miles off the keys as a national marine sanctuary. -Establish national wildlife refuges in the 18,000-acre Bayou Cocodrie in Louisiana and the 7,500-acre Walkill River area of New Jersey, and fund additional marine research programs and stepped up enforcement by the Environmental Protection Agency. -Designate 83,100 acres in southern Nevada's Mojave Desert as the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation area. -Nearly triple the size of the Coastal Barrier Resource System by adding 818,000 acres to the system along the atlantic, Gulf of Mexico and Great Lakes coasts. The measure also limits federal funds for development within the coastal barrier areas and requires that any federal property in the coastal barrier regions be transferred to the system. -Provide grants and training to teachers for environmental education and create an office of environmental education at the Environmental Protection Agency. -Fund research on the global warming trend. The administration, bucking many of its allies, contends there is insufficient scientific data to confirm that the earth is slowly warming due to gaseous emissions. Rather than committing itself to a reduction of those gases, the administration is putting more money into research. -Assist in the cleanup of toxic pollution in the Great Lakes and Lake Champlain.

DOC.HEAD: Velayati: Iraqi Leaders Did Not Rule Out Kuwait Withdrawel
DOC.TEXT: Iran's foreign minister said Friday after returning from Iraq that Saddam Hussein had not ruled out withdrawing from Kuwait. The Iranian official, Ali Akbar Velayati, spoke in an interview with Tehran television a day after returning from a two-day visit to Baghdad. He met twice with his Iraqi counterpart, Tariq Aziz, and once with Saddam. The lack of a joint communique by the nations, foes during the 1980-88 gulf war, indicated the talks were chilly. Asked about the effects of the U.N. economic sanctions, Velayati said ``the Iraqi government itself did not try to conceal that the sanctions have after all affected them.'' He did not elaborate. Velayati said it seemed Baghdad had not decided whether it would keep Kuwait. ``One cannot say with certainty that it will go either way, staying in Kuwait, and putting into practice the annexation of Kuwait, or the withdrawal from Kuwait,'' he said in the television interview, monitored in Nicosia. Velayati said he stressed that Iran believes international borders are inviolable. ``We did not prevaricate. Although we preserved the positive trend of our talks, we stressed to them our principle ... that as the Islamic republic we recognized, and still recognize, Kuwait as an independent country.'' ``We believe that Kuwait's independence must be returned to it,'' he said. Iran and Iraq remained enemies until August, when Saddam unexpectedly agreed to Iran's conditions for a formal settlement of the 1980-88 war. Analysts said he was seeking to pacify his eastern flank to focus on the standoff with the U.S.-led multinational forces deployed in the gulf region after Iraq seized Kuwait. Iran and Iraq reopened embassies in each other's capitals last month.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Threatens Firings, Yeltsin Demands Gov't Resignation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs to RECAST, minor editing. Picks up graf 5 pvs, `Yeltsin had...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOS2,4,LON1
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said he would fire government and military officials blocking his reform plans and his chief rival demanded the resignation of the central government to rescue the economy and hold the Soviet Union together. Gorbachev spoke with hardly any applause to an angry Soviet legislature that demanded an accounting of where his reforms were going. Rival Boris Yeltsin, president of the Russian federation, then took the floor to urge that Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov resign. The Gorbachev-Yeltsin power struggle showed the two leaders were still far from resolving their differences and ending the paralysis of power in the Soviet Union. Yeltsin had said after a private meeting wth Gorbachev on Sunday that the two leaders would form committees to work out a power-sharing agreement, creating hope for a unified effort to end the country's economic crisis. But Gorbachev told the Supreme Soviet legislature that Sunday's meeting was merely ``routine,'' and he refused to give the Russian leader more national power. Dropping his usually robust voice to a near-whisper in the cavernous chamber, Gorbachev said, ``In a coalition government, if the Russian government gets any more power, it will mean discrimination against the other republics.'' Yeltsin sat stone-faced through Gorbachev's speech. He later took the floor and demanded that Gorbachev agree within two weeks to form a new ``extraordinary anti-crisis committee'' that would govern in place of Ryzhkov and his Council of Ministers. The committee, which would amount to a new Cabinet, would include representatives of all 15 republics. It would take immediate steps to provide more food for the country, buying it from the West if necessary, Yeltsin said. ``The economic and political crisis in the country has come to a head,'' he told the 542-member Supreme Soviet. ``The people's patience has ended, and an explosion could occur at any time.'' Facing a disintegrating economy and secessionist movements in several republics, the lawmakers abandoned their agenda on Wednesday and demanded that Gorbachev report to them on the state of the union - and on his relations with Yeltsin. Yeltsin was dropped from the Communist Party Politburo in 1987 after criticizing Gorbachev's reforms as too slow. He has been the president's chief political rival for more than a year, and consistently ranks above Gorbachev in public opinion polls. The two agreed in August to cooperate on economic reforms. But the agreement collapsed and their power struggle intensified last month, when Gorbachev won the Supreme Soviet's approval for a compromise economic reform plan. The Russian parliament, headed by Yeltsin, vowed to push ahead with a more radical plan to switch to a free market in 500 days, starting Nov. 1. Since then, Gorbachev's national government and the Russian parliament have issued conflicting orders that have effectively stopped either from advancing their programs. Yeltsin was elected earlier this year as president of the Russian republic, which includes two-thirds of the Soviet land mass, about half its 285 million people and huge mineral wealth. But the Kremlin still controls the nation's finances and its economic and military policy. Gorbachev's 90-minute address received a generally cool reception in the legislative hall, which was packed with visiting military and republic leaders. Soviet television broadcast the speech in full, but did not carry Yeltsin's remarks. Gorbachev admitted that the country faces critical shortages at the start of winter, but he insisted the government has adequate plans to maintain supplies. He lashed out at ``disruptive forces that hinder the consolidation of society and the country's exit from the crisis.'' He told the lawmakers he would replace some military and government officials who were blocking his economic reforms. He said the plan to ``get rid of outdated, clearly useless structures'' would be submitted to the legislature within 10 days. Gorbachev did not spell out the changes but said they had the approval of Ryzhkov - indicating that the embattled prime minister would not be among those replaced. Gorbachev also promised changes ``in the top echelon of the armed forces command.'' He rejected persistent rumors of a military coup and, pounding the lectern, said people were spreading rumors to discredit the army. ``We cannot discredit the armed forces because we need them now to maintain stability in the country,'' he said. Gorbachev's plans for developing a market economy hinge on the republics remaining in the union, and he has proposed a treaty that would give them a degree of autonomy while leaving national economic and military power in Kremlin hands. Nearly all the republics and many smaller regions have declared some form of sovereignty from the Kremlin. The Baltic states, Georgia and the Ukraine have said they will not sign the union treaty. ``The president cannot be just on his own, just as you cannot settle many questions without his participation and without his powers,'' Gorbachev pleaded. ``Let's act together.'' A few deputies applauded that statement, but they did not clap at the end. Gorbachev left the floor without answering questions, and deputies took microphones to complain that he had not addressed their concerns about the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Indictment Casts `Another Shadow' on Missouri Legislature
DOC.TEXT: A state representative charged in an alleged check-kiting scheme became the fourth Missouri legislator this year to be indicted on federal charges. A grand jury in Kansas City on Thursday indicted four-term Rep. Henry Rizzo, D-Kansas City, who ran unopposed for re-election last week and easily won. His brother, John T. Rizzo, and a former business associate, Raymond E. Agee, also were indicted. U.S. Attorney Jean Paul Bradshaw, a Republican, said Rizzo's indictment on 17 felony counts of fraud was unrelated to his work as a legislator. Rizzo, 37, disagreed. ``I guess it's the year of the politician,'' he said Thursday after being released on a signature bond. ``I think this was ... brought because I am a Democrat and an elected official.'' Bradshaw said Rizzo and his co-defendants face identical charges of writing bad checks from May to August 1989 on accounts from two defunct businesses they managed. Rizzo said he is innocent. ``It was a business. It went out of business, and we did the best we could with it. It was a bad situation but it was certainly not criminal,'' he said. Earlier this year, two other Democratic lawmakers, Rep. E.J. ``Lucky'' Cantrell of St. Louis and Sen. Ed Quick of Kansas City, were tried by Bradshaw's office on felony labor corruption charges. Quick was acquitted. Cantrell, who was found guilty of conspiring to steal union money, has appealed and is awaiting sentencing. Federal prosecutors in St. Louis won three federal felony drug convictions during the summer against Rep. Dewey Crump, D-Maryland Heights. He is due to be sentenced Nov. 30. Cantrell and Crump lost re-election bids Nov. 6. Quick's seat is not up for election until 1992. House Speaker Bob Griffin, D-Cameron, said Rizzo's indictment wouldn't help the Legislature's image. ``It's not the greatest year we've ever had,'' he said. House Ethics Committee Chairman Doug Harpool, D-Springfield, said Rizzo's indictment was ``still another shadow'' over the Legislature. A House member convicted of a felony faces expulsion upon sentencing. Harpool said his committee also can recommend that the House suspend a member while a criminal investigation is pending. ``I want to handle it consistent with what we did in the Crump and Cantrell cases,'' Harpool said. ``It might be appropriate to get a complaint and to educate ourselves on the issues surrounding the allegations.'' The Ethics Committee opted to defer disciplinary action against Crump and Cantrell until their trials were over.

Baker said there could be no rewards for aggression, and no partial solution to the gulf crisis. He spoke in Brussels, Belgium, on the first leg of a 12-day foreign trip that will include talks on the gulf crisis. --- Oil prices fell below $30 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders decided that the outbreak of war could take some time. The market was off $1.87 at $29.25 a barrel. --- Seven peace activists headed for Iraq and planned to set up peace camps on both sides of the Kuwaiti-Saudi border. They said they hoped to prevent fighting from breaking out. ``We are well aware of the consequences of our actions, but this is a point of principle in the traditions of Gandhi,'' said Pat Arrowsmith, a 60-year-old peace campaigner. The group included activists from Britain, India, Belgium and Ghana. They said they would be joined by others once the camps were established. --- The Imminent Thunder six-day exercise in eastern Saudi Arabia includes a mock U.S. Marine amphibious invasion with air cover and close air and naval support of ground forces, although no live ammunition was to be used. Defense analysts said the 1,100 combat aircraft taking part were a reminder to Iraq that the allies have double its air power. --- President Bush was scheduled to leave Friday evening for an eight-day trip to Europe and the Middle East. Part of the trip will be used to discuss the gulf with key allies and guage reaction to a possible U.N. Security Council resolution that would authorize U.N. force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Some diplomats say the resolution could come by the end of the month. Bush plans to join U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia on Thanksgiving Day. ---- Iraqi President Saddam Hussein suggested a peaceful solution is still possible and indicated he could release foreign hostages if Bush promised not to attack Iraq. In an ABC-TV interview aired Thursday, Saddam said Iraq favors a peace that it ``comprehensive, complete and final.'' Saddam did not elaborate on the framework of a possible settlement, but noted that ``whoever hits us, we shall hit them back.''

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Keating-Senators, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Friday's opening statements as senators under investigation for allegedly unethical conduct in the savings and loan debacle denied accusations against them. Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz.: ``Charlie Keating was a political friend and supporter from 1981 to 1987. When he came to see me in March of 1987 and asked me to do something I thought was improper, I said no. ... When he asked me to negotiate for him, I said no. The only thing I said I could do was to inquire whether American Continental Corp. and Lincoln Savings were being treated fairly. ... ``On April 9th, I joined other senators in Senator DeConcini's office to meet with these San Francisco regulators. ... ``I learned at this meeting that Lincoln's complaints of bad treatment from the regulators were unfounded and that there would be a criminal referral to the Justice Department against Lincoln ... I neither solicited nor accepted any campaign contributions from Mr. Keating or American Continental employees. My relationship with Mr. Keating was ended, over and there's nothing more. ``I know I acted ethically and properly and in compliance with all applicable standards of conduct, including my own.''

Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio: ``There are no facts as yet unrevealed. There are no surprises in store for you. ... When these hearings are over, my conduct will no longer be the subject of speculation, of gossip and of innuendo. ... ``The truth is that at no time did I pare my principles or compromise my convictions. At no time did I ask for special treatment for anyone. And at no time did I trade favors or perform actions in return for money. I acted honorably, I behaved honestly and I have neither tainted my own reputation nor tarnished the reputation of this body. ... ``I believe that a crucial part of my job as a U.S. senator is to ensure that federal regulators and bureaucrats are treating people fairly. ... ``I will, and in the case of Lincoln did, ask for fair treatment. But I will not, and in the case of Lincoln did not, ask that a specific action be taken or that rules or regulations be interpreted simply to benefit a particular individual or company. ... I have never accepted contributions from anyone who so much as implies even indirectly that their contribution is linked to a request for my assistance. ... ``In 1984, Mr. Keating apparently arranged for contributions to help retire my presidential campaign debt, and in that same year I sent letters to the Bank Board, asking that it delay implementation of the so-called ``direct investment rule'' until Congress could fully consider the issue. ``But when I signed those letters, neither I nor my assistant who staffed this issue knew of Mr. Keating's contributions.''

DOC.HEAD: Heseltine Continues Attacks on Local Tax in Campaign Against Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: The man who hopes to take Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's job away from her took his attack on her government's unpopular local tax to Scotland on Friday. Mrs. Thatcher spent the day in Northern Ireland, where she visited British troops in a visit her office said was planned a month ago. ``I believe we shall win and I hope we shall win well,'' she told reporters who asked about the leadership battle. Conservative Party members of the House of Commons will vote Tuesday on whether to retain Mrs. Thatcher as head of the party or to replace her with former Defense Minister Michael Heseltine. If she loses, she also must give up the prime minister's post. Heseltine continued to attack the local tax imposed by her government, saying it could cost the Conservative Party the next general elections, which must be held by mid-1992. A tactical question about the leadership vote arose when Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said he support Mrs. Thatcher but refused to rule out the possibility that he might jump into the race if it isn't settled on the first ballot. Front-page stories in The Independent and The Daily Telegraph on Friday said that a substantial number of Conservative Party lawmakers would prefer that Hurd take over as prime minister. He would have the opportunity to run only if the first round is inconclusive. To win in the first round, Mrs. Thatcher or Heseltine needs 15 percent more votes than the other. If all 372 Tory lawmakers vote, it takes 214 votes to win. If the second-place candidate gets at least 159 votes, there would have to be a second ballot on Nov. 27, and other candidates would be free to enter. Heseltine said in an interview with BBC Radio that it stood to reason then that if people believe Hurd is the best candidate, the lawmakers must vote for Heseltine to open the way for a second round of balloting. Addressing a rally in the Scottish town of Lanark, Heseltine declared that the per-capita local tax supported by Mrs. Thatcher could lead to defeat for the Conservative Party in the next general election. The so-called poll tax is set by local governments, with a single charge for rich and poor. It replaces the property tax, and for many households it has meant a higher tax burden. Heseltine's contention that he has a better chance than Mrs. Thatcher of leading the party to victory was supported by a poll published Friday in The Times of London. The poll, by Market and Opinion Research International, showed the Conservatives trailing Labor by 4 points with Mrs. Thatcher as leader, but vaulting 10 points ahead of Labor with Heseltine. The survey was based on 1,088 interviews conducted on Thursday. Polls earlier in the week also showed that the general public prefers Heseltine, but Conservative voters overwhelmingly support Mrs. Thatcher. The only voters who will settle the leadership issue, however, are the 372 Conservative members of the House of Commons.

DOC.HEAD: Rioters Rampage in Paris after Peaceful Student Protest
LaserPhoto PAR8
DOC.TEXT: Rioters seizing their chance from a student protest smashed shop windows, vandalized cars and battled police on Friday after a park sit-in ended peacefully in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower. Riot police hurled tear gas grenades and charged rock-throwing hooligans, who began their rampage as 3,500 high school students concluded their demonstration on the Champs de Mars. Twenty policemen were slightly injured and about 48 people were arrested, police said. The troublemakers scattered into surrounding neighborhoods, breaking three store windows, pillaging a dry-cleaning shop and damaging 25 cars, overturning two of them, police said. There was nowhere near the violence that took place last Monday, when hundreds of young toughs on the fringes of a 100,000-strong student march looted shops, destroyed 190 cars and fought pitched battles with police. That melee injured 234 officers. Leaders of the two main student movements subsequently decided to hold a sit-in on Friday instead of a potentially more violent march. Students hoisting banners with the names of their schools filed quietly into a park. Few actually sat down on the grass, wet from rain. They are demanding more teachers, smaller classes, more innovative instruction, repairs to facilities and better security on schoolgrounds. The sit-in area bordered high-priced apartment homes and monuments. ``I can't say I'm very happy at the choice of place for this demonstration, but the forces of order appear to have taken all the right precautions,'' Mayor Jacques Chirac said before the event. Police closed 10 subway stations in the area and flooded the region with thousands of helmeted officers. Earlier Friday, about 600 protesting students in Calais blocked loading of freight and passengers onto two ferries bound for Britain, delaying the ferries' departure for an hour. About 300 students in Montchanin in central France occupied the train station and held up a high-speed train running from Paris to Lyon for an hour. Premier Michel Rocard has freed up $1 billion in emergency funds to improve the high schools. The wave of demonstrations began a month ago after a student was raped in a school lavatory in St. Ouen, a tough working-class suburb north of Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Women March To Protest Economic Crisis in Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of women, many banging empty pots with spoons, marched to government headquarters Friday to protest growing food shortages, power blackouts and inflation. ``We are staying hungry in the dark,'' read one slogan they carried during the half-mile march. Others read ``For Normal Life'' and ``Food for Our Children.'' Parliamentary leaders meanwhile postponed a vote on a package of economic reforms to which embattled Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov has tied his political future. The package includes steep price increases for food to help lower the budget deficit. Lukanov told parliament Thursday he will resign unless the measures are passed. But with shelves empty and food, electricity and gasoline already rationed, many leaders worry that an austerity plan in wintertime will heavily burden this nation of 9 million people. Lukanov, Finance Minister Belcho Belchev and other leaders in the 400-seat Grand National Assembly agreed after three hours of discussions to postpone the budget vote until next Thursday. Earlier, parliament passed by acclamation a separate measure allowing ethnic Turks, forcibly renamed under Communist rule, to restore their original names, the state news agency BTA reported. Under Communist President Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's 1.5 million ethnic Turks could not use their language or openly practice their Moslem faith. Zhivkov was ousted one year ago. The Communists renamed themselves Socialists and began pursuing economic and social reforms. In June 10 elections, the Socialists won 211 parlaimentary seats to 144 for the Union of Democratic Forces, the main opposition alliance. But 16 Socialist deputies have defected since then. The budget package passed a preliminary vote Thursday with 184 for, 135 against and eight abstentions. But Lukanov wants broad backing for his package, so the final vote was postponed to give the opposition time to amend the draft, said Ginyo Ganev, deputy chief of parliament. The program includes sweeping privatization, state spending cuts and price increases for 21 basic consumer products. The opposition favors more government spending instead of higher food prices to raise revenue. Lukanov says the budget deficit will soar to $570 million if the measures aren't passed, aggravating economic ills that include a $11 billion foreign debt.

DOC.HEAD: Orchestra Marks 90th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: The party favors were there, the cake was decorated and the audience members could leave Friday's 90th birthday concert for the Philadelphia Orchestra saying they had sung at the Academy of Music. The audience's part of the program was the old favorite ``Happy Birthday.'' The orchestra's part was a little more highbrow - Beethoven's ``Symphony No. 5'' and Tchaikovsky's ``Piano Concerto No. 1,'' plus selections from the works of Goldmark, Weber, Berlioz and Wagner. The program was the very the orchestra followed in its first concert, on Nov. 16, 1900. But the nostalgia was not shared by everyone who can still remember the old days and recount such accomplishments as the world premieres, the first electrical recording by an American symphony, the first stereo recording by an American symphony, the first radio broadcast in 1929 and the first television broadcast in 1948. ``It kills me to be a spectator,'' said Isadore Schwartz, 75, who was a violinist with the orchestra from 1945 until his retirement in 1985. ``My fingers itch. They want to play. I love my music and I love the orchestra more than anything. I just can't sit out there while they play without me, not even now,'' said Schwartz, who is also president of the retired musicians group. He still had a birthday wish, even though he didn't plan to attend the anniversary concert. ``I would like to wish them continued success and hope that the people of Philadelphia give this wonderful orchestra the recognition it deserves. People tend to take it for granted in Philadelphia while the people in Ames, Iowa, react with ovations when they get a chance to hear us,'' Schwartz said. The violinist joined the orchestra when Leopold Stokowski was still on the podium. Stokowski, the orchestra's third music director, raised the Philadelphia musicians to world-class status. He was replaced by Eugene Ormandy. Riccardo Muti followed in 1980. On the podium for the anniversary concert was guest conductor Charles Dutoit, music director of the Montreal Symphony and the Orchestre de France. He also is artistic director for the Philadelphia Orchestra's summer series at the Mann Music Center.

DOC.HEAD: Wanted Terrorist Threatens U.S. Interests in Case of War
DOC.TEXT: Abul Abbas, the dissident Palestinian wanted in the West for terrorism, said Friday that U.S. interests around the world will be attacked if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf. Speaking on Algerian television, Abbas said the number of U.S. forces in the gulf region surpasses what is needed to fulfill their official mission. The American presence ``does not target the defense of Kuwait or that of oil wells,'' he said. It targets ``the destruction of the Iraqi potential.'' ``If the U.S.A. starts a war in the gulf,'' it should expect ``that its interests in the region and in other parts of the world (would) be hit,'' he said. Abbas, who heads a Palestinian group based in Iraq, is wanted by the United States for the October 1985 attack on the Achille Lauro oceanliner in which a wheelchair-bound passenger, Leon Klinghoffer of New York, was killed. About 330,000 allied soldiers, including 230,000 Americans, are in Saudi Arabia and the region to counter Iraq. U.S. officials are now sending 200,000 more troops there, saying they want to maintain an offensive capability.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Brings Clouds and Cooler Weather to Central United States
DOC.TEXT: A Pacific cold front moved across the central United States on Friday, bringing clouds and slightly cooler weather to areas that had basked in unseasonably warmth in recent days. Blustery northwest winds behind the front prevailed from the southern high Plains states to the upper Great Lakes region and temperatures dropped into the 40s. Gale warnings were in effect for Lake Huron and Lake Erie. But southerly winds ahead of the front pushed temperatures elsewhere up into the 60s and 70s. Readings in the lower 80s were reported along the Gulf Coast at midday and in the 60s over much of the Northeast. Overnight and Friday morning lows remained above freezing across most of the nation east of the Rocky Mountains, with subfreezing temperatures confined mainly to the northern Plains. Blizzard warnings were in effect in northern Alaska, where a huge storm moved north across the Bering Sea. Storm winds were clocked at 113 mph at west end of the Aleutian Island chain late Thursday. Wind chill readings as cold as 60 degrees below zero were expected north of the Bering Strait over the weekend. Rain was scattered from eastern Oklahoma to lower Michigan. Pellston, Mich., received nearly one-third of an inch of rain during a six-hour period ending at 1 p.m. EST, with totals elsewhere of generally less than one-tenth of an inch. On Friday, record high temperatures for the date included 73 in Baltimore, 69 in Concord, N.H., and 71 in Hartford, Conn., Providence, R.I., and Syracuse, N.Y. The nation's low Friday morning was 11 degrees at both Bozeman and Butte, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Sets Out to Get More Support for U.S. Actions in Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Washington is consulting with its allies on whether to seek a U.N. resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait, U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Friday. On Friday, Baker met with top officials of the European Community. He is to fly to Geneva on Saturday to gather support for such a resolution from the foreign ministers of Ethiopia, Zaire and the Ivory Coast. Backing from those countries would give the United States broader approval among neutral and Third World countries. Baker was later to travel to Paris for talks with the foreign ministers of Finland and Romania during a three-day Paris gathering of the 34-nation Conference on Security and European Cooperation, which begins Monday. All five countries are members of the 15-nation U.N. Security Council, which would have to approve any resolution on the use of force against Iraq. At the United Nations, diplomats said Baker was trying to persuade Security Council foreign ministers to come to New York to adopt a resolution authorizing force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Foreign ministers occupy their country's seats on the council only in grave situations. Baker told reporters Friday that American officials have made no final decision to seek any resolution on using military might against Iraq. ``We are in the continuing process of consulting with our coalition partners about whether or not that might be something we should do,'' he said. Even so, the United States appears prepared to introduce the resolution this month, while its diplomat presides over the council. Yemen, a pro-Iraqi member of the 15-nation council, holds the presidency for December. Baker said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein should understand that force was a credible option if he does not withdraw from Kuwait, which his forces invaded Aug. 2. ``Unless that message gets through to Baghdad, we really are pessimistic about whether or not the political and peaceful solution that we desire ... can really be obtained,'' he said. Baker brushed aside a suggestion Thursday from Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov that a ``flexible linkage'' be drawn between an Iraqi pullout and a conference to settle the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. Saddam has demanded an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait be tied to a solution for the Palestinian question. President Bush has said Iraq must unconditionally withdraw but that other issues could be discussed after Kuwait is freed. Baker said the United States shares a common position on Iraq with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his foreign minister, Eduard Shevardnadze. They have agreed, he said, that there should be no rewards for aggression and no partial solutions to the problem and that ``we should not link this gulf issue with other issues.'' He suggested Primakov may have been speaking for himself and not for the Soviet government. France, China and the Soviet Union have indicated they would like more time to give economic sanctions and diplomacy a chance to work before adopting any resolution authorizing force against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Nursing Home Chain Loses Round in Labor Case
DOC.TEXT: Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest nursing home chain, has been found guilty of unfair labor practices in a ruling organized labor hailed Friday as a major victory that could affect other corporate giants. The Fort Smith, Ark.,-based chain said the ruling, handed down by an administrative law judge, would be appealed to the National Labor Relations Board. At issue was a 1987 NLRB case in which the government accused the company of engaging in 40 illegal acts ``designed to defeat'' workers' rights to organize a union. ``On face value, we don't agree with the decision ... We have good relationships with all of our unions,'' said Bill Ihle, a Beverly spokesman. In the ruling made public Friday, administrative law judge Martin Linsky found Beverly guilty of unfair labor practices at 33 facilities in 12 states and ordered the chain to reinstate and provide back pay to workers who had been illegally fired for union activity. Linsky also issued a ``cease and desist'' order that requires all of Beverly's 860 nursing homes to post for 60 days notices of the company's labor law violations and its workers' rights to unionize. ``This decision is a great victory for the tens of thousands of workers at Beverly nursing homes, many of whom lost jobs, endured years of harassment ... and were denied their right to union representation,'' said John Sweeney, president of the Service Employees International Union. The union said other American businesses could be affected, too, because now the NLRB might be able to hold a single corporation responsible for labor aw violations at its separate facilities. The ruling could ``trigger critical new protections for workers of the future,'' said Sweeney, whose union represents more than 3,000 workers at 50 Beverly nursing homes. In the NLRB's original 1987 case, officials alleged that Beverly had fired more than 25 union supporters and threatened to close nursing homes if employees unionized. The government said other violations included physical assaults by Beverly managers on union supporters and organizers and promises of benefits to discourage unionization. The original complaint was filed in Pittsburgh and consolidated dozens of separate charges raised by four unions since August 1986 at 20 Beverly-owned facilities in Pennsylvania, Michigan, Minnesota, Texas and Washington state. Specific charges included that Beverly fired 17 workers at its Fayette Health Care Center in Uniontown, Pa., in 1986 for wearing union buttons. The fired workers were reinstated three months later after the NLRB threatened to get a court injunction against the company. At the time, Beverly was based in Pasadena, Calif. In his ruling, Linsky said, ``the simple fact is that Beverly's unfair labor practices were egregious, took place over several years at numerous locations and clearly manifest a proclivity'' to violate federal labor law. Linsky found that Beverly engaged in several illegal activities, including unlawful threats, interrogations, promises or grants of benefits and surveillance.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Soviets Begin Work On Dams
DOC.TEXT: Iran and the Soviet Union have begun a $500 million project to build two dams on the Aras River, along the border between the countries, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported Friday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said work on the two dams was inaugurated Thursday by Iran's Minister of Energy, Bijan Namdar Zanganeh, and Hasan Hasanov, prime minister of the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. The dams will beging operating within six years and will cost $538 million, IRNA quoted Zanganeh as saying. They will generate about 280 megawatts of electricity and will irrigate about 250,000 acres on both sides of the border, he said. The projects are part of an agreement for $6 billion in industrial and defense spending signed by Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani on a visit to Moscow in June 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Angola and UNITA Hold Peace Talks in Portugal
DOC.TEXT: Angola's leftist government and the U.S.-backed rebels it is fighting resumed peace talks Friday aimed at ending one of the last regional wars between superpower allies. For the fifth time this year, delegates met under Portuguese government mediation to seek a cease-fire that would lead to multiparty elections in the southwest African nation. Officials said no cease-fire was likely to be signed during the sessions, held at a school near the coastal resort of Estoril, 16 miles west of the Portuguese capital. But Gen. Adolosi Alicerces Mango, a rebel negotiator, said groundwork could be laid for a truce agreement by the end of the year. The Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola, or MPLA, and the National Union of the Total Independence of Angola, UNITA, were among three rival guerrilla groups who fought Portugal until Angola's 1975 independence. With the departure of the Portuguese, the MPLA emerged the strongest group and took power. Since then UNITA, with U.S. and South African support, has been fighting the MPLA in a war has left an estimated 340,000 dead. Steps toward peace began last year when Cuba began a phased withdrawal of its 50,000 troops that backed the Marxist government. That was part of an agreement under which South Africa granted independence to neighboring Namibia. Both Soviet and U.S. delegates were attending Friday's negotiations. The United States has given millions in aid to UNITA; Angola's military is armed by the Soviets. The head of the Soviet delegation, Foreign Ministry official Alexander Smirnov, proposed a halt to U.S. and Soviet arms supplies to the Angolan foes to speed the peace process, Portuguese news reports said. Congress recently approved a bill to continue aid to the rebels, but said the aid could be suspended if the Angolan government met conditions that included a halt to Soviet arms purchases. In previous meetings the rebels and government reached broad agreement on issues including international verification of a cease-fire, human rights protection, and the eventual implementation of a multiparty political system. But deep differences remain over the timetable for political change. The rebels want elections by December 1991. President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has said more time will be need to prepare them. The rebels have insisted the Angolan government recognize their movement before they agree to cease fire. The government wants the rebels to stop fighting before it will grant them political legitimacy. Portuguese mediators have said cease-fire documents could be signed simultaneously with an accord granting UNITA political legitimacy.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Looking at Benefit Cuts in New Budget
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is studying the possibility of reducing government benefits paid to affluent Americans in a variety of programs but not Social Security, White House budget director Richard Darman said Friday. Darman said that as part of the preparation of Bush's new budget, the administration was taking a look at benefits paid to people at several income levels. He said that in the 1980s there had been significant cuts in welfare programs for the poor. But he said those cuts left untouched the big government programs which distribute benefits not on the basis of income but based on other requirements spelled out in law. ``We might present recommendations for trying to change that distribution of benefits,'' Darman said. He specifically mentioned subsidy payments to farmers and the giant Medicare program which provides health care for the elderly. But Darman said that news stories quoting unnamed sources as saying that Social Security benefits might be trimmed were in error. Darman said that report ``was mistaken in suggesting that we were thinking of tinkering with Social Security. We are not doing that as part of this review, but everything else is certainly in the equation.'' Darman made his remarks during an appearance before the Council for Excellence in Government. On another topic, Darman predicted that the budget deficit for the current fiscal year will climb to an all-time high despite the five-year deficit-cutting agreement passed by Congress last month. Darman said the red ink would most likely fall in a range between $250 billion and $300 billion. The deficit for the 1990 fiscal year, which ended on Sept. 30, was $220.4 billion, just short of the all-time high of $221.1 billion set in 1986. Darman said that a variety of factors including the weakening economy and the uncertain situation in the Middle East were combining to make the deficit rise. The economy's weakness was brought home to the White House this week in a series of meetings President Bush held with his own advisers and a group of 20 top executives brought in to brief the president on economic conditions. Darman, who attended the sessions, said that the general consensus among both the president's advisers and the outside experts was that the country was in a downturn, a word Bush himself used in an interview Thursday night on CNN. In that interview, Bush acknowledged for the first time the possibility of a recession but he insisted that any slump was likely to be mild and short. ``Most seem to feel that if we have a recession, it will not be deep and that we'll come out of it relatively soon, six months at most, and I would like to think that is true,'' the president said. Amoco Corp. Chairman DickMarrow told reporters after Friday's session with the president, ``There is a general feeling that we are either in a recession or very close.'' Darman said the purpose of the four meetings Bush has held on the economy in the past week was to develop a strategy for cushioning the shock of any downturn. He said the president will probably make recommendations for stimulating economic growth in his budget, due to be submitted to Congress in February. Darman said that decisions on what types of programs to include would be made by Bush ``at the earliest'' in late December.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Bills On Airport Security And Community Service
With AM-Bush-Environment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday signed into law measures to upgrade airport security and to encourage volunteerism and community service. Bush signed the bills as he hurried to finish domestic business before an eight-day foreign trip. The Aviation Security Improvement Act of 1990 directs the government to develop guidelines to warn passengers of terrorist threats. It implements safety recommendations of the Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism appointed by Bush after the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The bill sets regulations on airport use of metal detection devices. It requires airlines, airports and travel agents to relay any security threat immediately to government officials. Airline and airport employees with access to security areas will have to undergo background checks and new training. In signing the bill, Bush said he had reservations about a provision requiring the State Department to negotiate agreements with other nations to achieve the enhanced security measures at foreign airports. Bush said he believed that provision intruded on his presidential authority to conduct foreign policy and said he would direct officials to interpret it so as not to conflict with that authority. The National Community Service Act of 1990 provides $287 million for community service programs, including $5 million to begin a Thousand Points of Light Foundation to encourage volunteerism, taking its name from Bush's phrase for volunteers. It provides money for programs encouraging youth community service through schools or community organizations; grants to state education agencies; expansion of youth corps teams for such projects as environmental cleanup and helping the poor; and a test program for a civilian national service corps that would provide $5,000 in education assistance in return for a year's full-time service at a subsistence wage. Bush signed the measure despite attacks by Republicans that it included wasteful spending at a time when the government was raising taxes, and budget constraints prevented full funding existing programs for children and the poor. Bush also on Friday signed the Excellence in Mathematics, Science and Engineering Education Act to establish a variety of fellowships, training programs and grants to foster and improve education in those fields. The bill authorizes $150 million for such programs in 1991. The president vetoed the Indian Preference Act of 1990, which would have established a program to direct contracts and grants to Indian enterprises. Bush said the bill ``would impose new, expensive, and often duplicative program responsibilities'' on the Interior Department, which administers Indian reservations. Bush said in a statement that he supports the bill's goals and is ``committed to helping alleviate the widespread unemployment and underemployment on Indian reservations.'' He said the bill's issues ``deserve a full airing in both Houses of Congress. He said he would direct Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan to take steps to address problems with contracting programs involving Indian enterprises. Bush took the action before departing Friday night for Prague, the first stop of an eight-day trip that will also take him to Paris, Saudi Arabia and Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese City Eliminating `Little Black Sambo' to Improve Image
DOC.TEXT: Officials of a Japanese city bidding for the 1998 Winter Olympics said Friday they have asked schools and libraries to get rid of the Little Black Sambo character, which has been attacked as racist. ``It is important for a better international reputation for Nagano,'' said a municipal official in speaking about the move. The municipal office in Nagano, central Japan, late last month requested that the city's schools and libraries destroy all books, pictures and educational tools involving Little Black Sambo. Sambo, originally meaning a person who was half Indian and half black, has been used as a degrading name for blacks for decades. Nagano city maintains everything that carries the word ``Sambo'' or pictures of the boy should be banned, regardless of content. But Nagano's library officials said references describing racial problems in the story should not be banned. Also Friday, the Justice Ministry said it will use a photograph of children of different races on a publicity poster in an effort to combat racism. A ministry official said it will be the first poster featuring American blacks in the government's promotional publication to counter racial discrimination. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the posters are expected to be put up at train stations and public facilities next month. Anti-discrimination campaigns have been held periodically since the Justice Ministry's office of human rights was established about 40 years ago, he said. It is not clear whether the poster for this year's campaign is related to controversial remarks made in September by Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, who compared prostitutes to American blacks. Following a police roundup of foreign prostitutes in Tokyo's red light district, Kajiyama said such prostitutes ``rui the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods they move into. ``It's like in America when neighborhoods become mixed because blacks move in and whites are forced out,'' Kajiyama said. His remarks, which provoked protests in the United States and Japan, were only the latest in a series of controversial comments on race from high-ranking Japanese politicians and government officials. Sambo-like figures, with exaggerated lips and other stereotypical features, can still be seen in some toys and other items. In 1988, Japan drew harsh criticism from the United States for black mannequins and dolls displayed and sold at stores. In August this year, a citizens group forced a major publishing house to strike out expressions and drawings exaggerating physical features of blacks in five popular comic books. Iwanami Shoten, the first Japanese publisher to introduce the Little Black Sambo story in Japan, said in late 1988 that the comics would not be reprinted.

DOC.TEXT: Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich.: ``I think I'm as independent as anybody here, and I think my career shows that - the present campaign financing system is cutting against our democracy and it must be changed. If this inquiry - as miserably unpleasant as it has been for all of us - helps bring about the change that we need, then our country will be the better for it. ... With these public hearings we'll let the truth begin to answer the false charges. ... I am fully responsible for my official conduct as a Senator and I believe my conduct was absolutely proper in this matter.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Peacekeepers Urged to Protect Palestinians
DOC.TEXT: Arab and non-aligned speakers on Friday urged the U.N. Security Council to deploy U.N. peacekeepers in the Israeli-occupied territories to protect Palestinians, a measure the United States rejects. A U.S. diplomat described the PLO-backed initiative as ``veto bait'' and said the United States would block it. Other Western diplomats said, however, that a compromise resolution was possible because all 15 council members want to avoid a veto or divisive vote. Colombia, Libya, Malaysia, Syria and Tunisia all spoke Friday in support of redeploying U.N. military observers stationed in Jerusalem for the U.N. Truce Supervision Organization to monitor the treatment of Palestinians. The proposed resolution also calls for convening a meeting of the 164 signatories of the Fourth Geneva Convention, which governs the treatment of occupied peoples, and an international conference on Middle East peace. It is sponsored by Yemen, Malaysia, Colombia and Cuba. Israel rejects any U.N. intervention to protect Palestinians as a violation of its sovereignty over the territory it seized in the 1967 Mideast war. It also objects to convening signatories of the 1949 Geneva convention, arguing it doesn't apply to the Palestinian territories. The PLO's acting observer, M. Nasser Al-Kidwa, told reporters Friday that the PLO opposes watering down the resolution to drop the call for U.N. observers, saying they were ``an essential factor.'' ``We need to produce a new mechanism to monitor the situation and report back to the Security Council,'' Al-Kidwa said. He said he hoped the proposed resolution would be brought to a vote on Monday. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, meanwhile, was considering whether to send Jean-Claude Aime, his special envoy, to Israel and the occupied territories to study the situation there, aides said. They said Perez de Cuellar would not make a decision until he returns from Paris on Tuesday. Israel rejected a Security Council call for an investigation into the Oct. 8 violence on the Temple Mount in which 17 Palestinians were killed. It announced this week, however, that it would accept a visit by Aime to investigate general Arab-Israeli violence as long as it excluded the Temple Mount.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Leaves Some Questions Unanswered About Box in FBI's Hands
With AM-Noriega Lawyers, Bjt
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: Cable News Network asserted again Friday the FBI wrongfully took a reporter's box of materials on the Manuel Noriega case, but the network could not fully explain just how it ended up in the FBI's hands. The FBI said it would not analyze the box's contents until officials answer CNN's complaint. At a packed news conference at CNN headquarters in Atlanta, CNN general counsel Steven Korn said the network has not seen a subpoena or search warrant for the box, which was taken by FBI agents Thursday after security officers removed it from the hotel room of reporter Marlene Fernandez earlier this week. The hotel is housed in CNN's headquarters complex, and Korn acknowledged that Turner Security, a CNN sister company, was aware of the box's whereabouts before FBI agents removed it. Asked why Turner Security didn't call CNN about the box, Korn said, ``That's a good question.'' But Korn denied that CNN arranged the box's removal as a ruse. ``I am confident the general public will not be misled to think that this is a ruse, because I know you are all good reporters and you will accurately report that this is no such thing whatsoever,'' he said. There was no word Friday on whether the box's contents had anything to do with CNN's legal battle over its attempt to air audio tapes of government wiretaps of Noriega. Korn said he did not know whether the box's contents could identify CNN's sources on the Noriega story, but said ``we don't believe our ability to pursue this story has been compromised.'' CNN President Tom Johnson said Friday he didn't know if the recordings contained in the box were audio or video tapes, or if they were the phone calls between Noriega and his legal team. ``We just know that there were notes, work papers and tapes'' related to CNN's coverage of the Noriega story, Johnson said. William Hinshaw, head of the FBI's Atlanta bureau, said Friday his agency agreed to seal the box. He said he would not examine its contents further until ordered to do so. Hinshaw said he saw some cassettes in the box but didn't know if they were Noriega tapes. CNN would not tell reporters how to reach Ms. Fernandez, and an FBI agent also came up empty when he showed up at CNN's Washington bureau looking for her. Meanwhile, he said, CNN has protested the box's removal ``at the highest level of the FBI'' and demanded its return. Korn maintained that while he has not seen the contents of the box, it was the ``lawful property'' of CNN and Ms. Fernandez. ``The property was not the property of the hotel. It was not the property of the FBI. It had not been abandoned,'' Korn said. Korn would not answer reporters' questions on how long the box was in Ms. Fernandez' room, why it was there and not in the CNN newsroom a short walk away, and why the box apparently was picked up as abandoned property by security officers even though Ms. Fernandez had not checked out of her room. CNN has asked the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn a federal judge's order, issued last week, barring it from airing recordings of conversations between Noriega and the fallen Panamanian dictator's legal team. CNN's reports disclosing the existence of the the government tapes prompted his lawyers to ask a judge to throw out the drug charges against him. Korn said he had not received a response from Joseph Whitley, the U.S. attorney in Atlanta, to a letter CNN sent ``demanding the return of the tapes and that the materials in the box not be reviewed or duplicated.'' Whitley was out of town Friday. Messages left for his assistant, Ray Rukstele, were not immediately returned. Korn said it wasn't clear yet how the FBI was notified about the box. ``I don't know who called who. There was a discussion between the FBI and Turner Security. It's unclear to me who initiated the call.'' ``The FBI did not initiate any call on that whatsoever. The call on that was initiated by Turner Security,'' said Dick Hildreth, assistant special agent in charge of the Atlanta FBI office. ``Until they called us, we didn't know any such box existed.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Says Political Pressure Stopped French Pill
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators, caving in to political pressure, interrupted important non-abortion research when they barred Americans from importing personal supplies of the French abortion drug RU-486, the chairman of a congressional subcommittee said Friday. The Food and Drug Administration's action in June 1989 helped fuel the anti-abortion fever that has led the drug's maker to curtail supplies of RU-486 allowed in this country, said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. The result has been that at least some of the research groups with FDA permission to test RU-486 as a treatment for breast cancer, Cushing's syndrome and other diseases have been stopped, he said. Cushing's syndrome is a disorder of the pituitary gland that can produce obesity, diabetes, osteoporosis, psychiatric problems and other symptoms. ``Here's this drug that's very controversial with multiple benefits, and the only regulatory pronoucement about it was clearly based on politics rather than science,'' Wyden said. The congressman noted that the FDA imposed the personal import ban one month after receiving a letter from 11 members of the House and Senate who oppose abortion. In their letter, the lawmakers told the FDA, ``The U.S. government should not be involved in abetting abortion.'' Groups that oppose abortion have threatened to boycott and take other actions against companies or organizations that try to bring RU-486 to the United States for abortion. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit denied that the agency was motivated by politics or acted under pressure from Congress. The criteria for allowing unapproved drugs to be imported for personal use are straightforward, and RU-486 did not meet three of them, he said. The three criteria that RU-486 failed are that a personally imported drug must be aimed at a serious or life-threatening illness, there has to be no existing standard therapy for the illness and there have to be no safety questions. The safety problem, in FDA's mind, was the possibility that women could take the drug unsupervised by a physician. In France, RU-486 is approved to induce abortion in early-stage pregnancies. It is used, under supervision of a physician, along with prostaglandin, a drug that speeds shedding of the uterus lining. Wyden's Small Business Subcommittee on Regulation, Business Opportunities and Energy plans to hold a hearing Monday at which several people are to testify about their research with RU-486. Researchers at the National Institutes of Health are conducting at least two of the clinical trials that have been approved by the FDA, and as the law requires, none uses RU-486 for abortion. Dr. George Chrousos, a researcher at the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, said he has ``some apprehension'' about getting assurances from the drug's manufacturer, Roussel-Uclaf, for further supply of the drug for the next phase of his study on Cushing's syndrome. ``They are apprehensive,'' he said of company officials. Kathryn B. Horwitz, a researcher at the University of Colorado School of Medicine in Denver, said her federally financed research with RU 486 in the treatment of breast cancer is threatened by the FDA's import ban. ``The politics of abortion is restricting use of a drug that has much potential beyond abortion, for treatment of cancer, hormonal disorders and all kinds of things,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev's Formula For Political Survival Runs Aground
AP News Analysis
With AM-Soviet-Politics
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev has navigated through five years of political upheaval by staking out the middle between angry opponents, but the formula ran aground Friday when lawmakers demanded he pick a side. The Supreme Soviet called Gorbachev to account for the foundering economy and fragmenting union, hoping to hear their president had settled on a path of rapprochement during a four-hour meeting Sunday with his popular rival, Russian republic leader Boris Yeltsin. Yeltsin's vast republic controls the bulk of the country's resources, while the Kremlin holds financial and military authority. The leaders' conflicting orders for economic reform have paralyzed the country, and their meeting raised hopes for a power-sharing compromise that could rescue the economy. But what deputies heard Friday from Gorbachev were more calls for consolidation around his five-year-ol perestroika program and his embattled proposal for a new treaty to hold the 15 republics together. Gorbachev gave short shrift to his private meeting with Yeltsin, calling it a ``routine'' session that was being sensationalized by politicians and the media. Instead, he called for a replacement of the military and government officials whom he said were blocking his reforms. He tried once again to pit his opponents against each other, suggesting the smaller republics, whose national cultures were suppressed during much of the Communist Party's 73-year rule, should be wary of a leading role by ethnic Russians. ``In a coalition government, if the Russian government gets any more power, it will mean discrimination against the other republics,'' he said. A year ago, the warning might have struck a chord with many republic leaders, who are all too familiar with the history of imperial Russia's domination over a country stretching from the Chinese border to Poland. But on Friday, the only lawmakers to respond enthusiastically were from small ethnic groups who themselves complain of discrimination within the republics. Republic leaders attending the session said they would support the proposed treaty only if the Kremlin recognized their independence first and gave clear guarantees the pact would be voluntary. Most of the deputies in the hall were clearly fed up with Gorbachev's pronouncements. The chamber's closed circuit cameras panned the hall to show uninspired faces and heads leaning on hands. Gorbachev didn't even receive the traditional applause at the end of his speech, as deputies began rising to press him with questions. He left the hall without giving any answers. Outside the chamber, both reformists and hard-liners attacked the president. Leningrad's radical mayor, Anatoly Sobchak, told reporters that Gorbachev's speech ``was not what we needed.'' Conservative former Politburo member Yegor Ligachev complained Gorbachev said ``nothing about how to attract the political forces needed to solve the problems.'' Yeltsin, who had sat nearly expressionless during Gorbachev's speech, took the floor and demanded Gorbachev agree within two weeks to set up an ``extraordinary anti-crisis committee'' that would replace the government of embattled Prime Minister Nikolai Ryhkov. The fact that Yeltsin, who is not a member of the parliament, could stage such public defiance of Gorbachev reflected his surging popularity.
