An opinion poll released Friday by the National Public Opinion Center said 75 percent of respondents thought Yeltsin could best represent Russia's interests, compared with 35 percent for Gorbachev. The poll didn't give a margin of error. Another indication of Gorbachev's plummeting support came from a deputy general secretary of the Communist Party, Vladimir Ivashko, who said he has received ``a staggering number of letters'' from party members demanding that Gorbachev quit as party leader and concentrate on his presidential duties. Gorbachev ousted Yeltsin from the party's Politburo two years ago, but Yeltsin made a political comeback and was elected president of Russia last summer. Last Sunday's meeting raised hopes of a new compromise, but when Gorbachev delivered his negative answer Friday, he retreated to a narrow middle ground, which may be a hard place to stand. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Thomas Ginsberg is a Moscow-based correspondent who has written about Soviet affairs for The AP since 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Astronauts Orbit Earth in Public Silence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with sources saying spy satellite deployed, landing day announced; picks up 7th graf, `The Pentagon ...' SUBS 12th graf pvs, `Columbia's astronomy ...' to INSERT dropped word `study.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CSB2
With AM-Jellyfish In Space, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' five astronauts, orbiting Earth in a public silence imposed by the Pentagon, deployed a spy satellite aimed at Iraq and will return to Earth on Monday, NASA and military sources said Friday. The astronauts spent their first full day in space Friday working under a shroud of secrecy. However, sources speaking on condition of anonymity said the satellite was placed in orbit. NASA punctuated the silence Friday evening to report that Atlantis would land at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., sometime between 5 p.m. and 8 p.m. EST Monday. A more precise time will be announced 24 hours before landing. ``The crew is doing well, and the orbiter Atlantis continues to perform satisfactorily,'' said Mission Control's Kari Fluegel. Atlantis thundered into orbit Thursday night carrying a satellite that purportedly is to spy on Iraq. The shuttle was visible along the entire Florida coast and as far north as South Carolina as it rode a 700-foot column of flame through the darkness. It was the fifth time NASA launched a shuttle at nighttime and the seventh and last time a shuttle will carry a classified military cargo into space. Atlantis' crew, commanded by Air Force Col. Richard Covey, had been expected to release the spy satellite from the shuttle's cargo bay within 24 hours of liftoff. Experts believe the spacecraft will focus cameras or electronic signal detectors on the Persian Gulf. The Pentagon plans to use the shuttle two more times, both in 1991 to carry unclassified cargoes. Future military satellites will be lifted into orbit by unmanned rockets, principally the Titan 4. Atlantis' flawless liftoff - the second shuttle flight in two months - was greeted enthusiastically by NASA officials, who spent much of the year contending with grounded shuttles. Hydrogen leaks crippled Columbia, then Atlantis over the summer. Both shuttles were cleared for flight last month following extensive repairs. Atlantis last flew in March, when it carried another spy satellite into orbit. ``It puts Atlantis back into flying status again,'' said launch director Bob Sieck. ``In a few weeks, we expect to have Columbia there, too. So we'll have all three shuttles flying again.'' Columbia's astronomy mission has been on hold since May, when the shuttle's hydrogen leaks were discovered. Four countdowns were attempted before NASA stopped to make way for Discovery's October flight with a satellite on a mission to study the sun. If Columbia goes up in early December as planned, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will have achieved six shuttle flights for 1990. Nine missions originally were planned.

DOC.HEAD: France Reinforces Troops in Eastern Chad Amid Fighting
DOC.TEXT: France announced Friday it has moved 150 soldiers to reinforce its standing detachment in eastern Chad, where that nation's government has been battling rebels who attacked last weekend. The announcement came on the same day as reports that Chad is mobilizing its population to fight the insurgents. There were also reports - denied by Chad - that the North African country had asked Zaire to send troops. In its statement, the French Defense Ministry said the company of soldiers normally based in the Chadian capital, N'Djamena, took up positions this week near Abeche. The French garrison there is about 100 miles from the zone of recent fighting near the Sudanese border. The reinforcements bring the French garrison in Abeche to 500 men. France bases about 1,000 soldiers in the former colony to support the government of President Hissene Habre. Chad has about 5.5 million residents. The ministry communique said the reinforcements were made to increase the security of the Abeche garrison. It did not say if any French forces had come under attack. Military sources say rebels of the Islamic Legion have taken control of several border outposts since attacking from western Sudan last weekend. The rebels are led by Idriss Deby, a former chief of the Chadian armed forces. Habre accuses Libya and Sudan of suppporting the rebels with weapons, training and bases. Both those countries deny the charges. The Chadian Embassy in Paris denied the reports Thursday from Kinshasa, Zaire, that Chadian officials had asked President Mobutu Sese Seko to send troops. ``Certainly, violent combat is under way in the region of Tine, but the Chadian National Armed Forces are mastering the situation,'' Ambassador Allam-Mi Ahmad said. Chadian national radio reported that the government is mobilizing the population against what it called ``hordes of mercenaries coming from Libya and Sudan.'' It did not elaborate on the measures. The country has about 5.4 million people. About 2,000 rebels equipped with Soviet and Brazilian-made armored vehicles were reported to have attacked Tine over the weekend. The government said loyal troops repulsed the incursion after 24 hours of fighting but reported a new attack Monday. There has been no mention of casualties from either side. Chad and Libya have long been at odds. Chad chased Libyan soldiers from the disputed, mineral-rich Aouzou Strip along their common border in 1987. It has since accused Libya of supporting rebels based in Sudan's sparsely populated Darfur province, where the Khartoum goverment exercises practically no control.

DOC.HEAD: Rwandan Fighting Spills Over Into Uganda
DOC.TEXT: Fighting between Rwandan government troops and rebels has spilled over into Uganda, injuring some Ugandans and causing hundreds of others to flee, newspapers reported Friday. Capt. Sam Bishumba, a battalion commander in southwestern Uganda, threatened retaliation Thursday against Rwandan troops pursuing insurgents into Ugandan territory, the newspapers said. Rwandan refugees launched an invasion of their homeland from southwestern Uganda on Sept. 30. Bishumba told journalists on a tour of the Gatuna border area that a Rwandan military helicopter had penetrated up to three miles inside Uganda chasing the rebels on Wednesday. He said an unknown number of Ugandans were injured and others fled. Talks to end the fighting in Rwanda were to resume Tuesday in the eastern Zairean town of Goma, state-controlled Radio Zaire reported Friday. The leaders of Zaire, Uganda, Burundi, Tanzania and Rwanda were to attend the summit, to be followed by a meeting of Rwandan authorities and rebels Wednesday. Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seso, who is mediating the dispute, will chair the meeting between the warring parties, according to the Zairean broadcast monitored in Nairobi. The rebels, who call themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front, are predominantly members of Rwanda's minority Tutsi tribe, most of whom have lived in exile for nearly 30 years. Hundreds of thousands of Tutsi fled the tiny central African nation in the late 1950s when the majority Hutu overthrew the Tutsi-led government and killed more than 10,000 members of the Tutsi tribe. The rebels accuse Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana's single-party government of corruption and seek to replace it with democracy. Habyarimana has expressed his willingness to allow a multiparty system in Rwanda. On Tuesday, he urged Rwandans to present their suggestions of reform to a 30-member committee that has been meeting since September to draft a new political charter.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Recommends Death for Convicted Arsenic Killer
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) - A jury sentenced a woman to death Friday for killing a former boyfriend by spoon-feeding him arsenic-laced food while he lay in a hospital bed four years ago. Blanche Taylor Moore, 57, was convicted Wednesday of killing Raymond Reid in 1986. The jury deliberate over her sentence for four hours. Judge William Freeman concurred with the death sentence, and set a Jan. 18, 1991, execution date. The case automatically will be appealed to the state Supreme Court. If her appeals fail, Mrs. Moore would be given the choice of dying by lethal injection or in the gas chamber. Freeman told Mrs. Moore to stand and she had little reaction as he handed down the death sentence. As the jury's recommendation was read, Mrs. Moore closed her eyes. She appeared to sob as jurors were polled, and then turned to calm her two daughters. As Mrs. Moore was led from the courtroom, brother Sam Kiser said to her: ``We still believe in you, Blanche.'' After she was taken to a holding cell, relatives were permitted to visit her. None of the members of the arsenic poisoning victims' families were present for the sentencing. Defense attorneys had pleaded with jurors to spare her life. ``We're looking at a person here with a good side ... but with a dark spot,'' defense attorney Mitchell McEntire said, reminding the jury of the evidence that she was ``driven to do good works.'' But Forsyth County District Attorney Warren Sparrow called on the jury to condemn Mrs. Moore to death. ``The murder of Raymond Reid was atrocious, heinous and cruel by any definition,'' Sparrow said. ``Do your duty to the state and you will find ... the appropriate recommendation for punishment will be death,'' he said. Reid, of Kernersville, died in October 1986 at North Carolina Baptist Hospital in Winston-Salem. Prosecutors said during the four-week trial that Mrs. Moore was driven by a need for money and that she killed Reid to gain part of his estate. Mrs. Moore also is charged in the death of her first husband, James Taylor, in 1973, and the poisoning of her estranged husband, the Rev. Dwight Moore, who became sick after their honeymoon last year. She may be tried later on those charges. Investigators began looking into the deaths of Mrs. Moore's acquaintances after doctors discovered last year the arsenic poisoning of her husband. Officials exhumed five bodies during the investigation and found arsenic in the body of her father. She was not charged in his death. Defense attorneys tried to lay the blame for the deaths upon an acquaintance of Mrs. Moore's, Garvin Thomas. They produced a rambling, five-page letter in which he allegedly confessed to the crimes. Thomas died before the letter arrived at Mrs. Moore's jail cell.

DOC.HEAD: `Keating Five' Deny Wrongdoing Before Ethics Panel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITS a0725 to delete extraneous matter in 12th graf: ``Many of,''
DOC.TEXT: Senators under investigation for helping Charles H. Keating Jr. battle federal banking regulators emotionally defended their integrity and denied any wrongdoing Friday before the Senate Ethics Committee. ``John Glenn does not peddle influence, period,'' the Ohio Democrat told the panel of fellow senators. Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., held up a jigsaw puzzle and said the committee special counsel was missing some key pieces when he negatively described Riegle's conduct. The committee turned to personal defense statements by the ``Keating Five'' senators after the counsel, Robert Bennett, wound up a day and a half detailing accusations and evidence against them. In addition to Riegle and Glenn, Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz. and Alan Cranston, D-Calif. presented their statements. Cranston and Riegle showed considerable emotion in their appeals for exoneration. The hearing adjourned until Monday, leaving only Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz. to make his defense statement. After he speaks, witnesses will be called. Bennett concentrated on Cranston, the Senate's No. 2 Democrat, on Friday, saying his help for Keating and the businessman's failing Lincoln Savings and Loan was ``closely connected'' to political donations from Keating. Cranston, suffering from prostate cancer and making his first appearance at the hearings, was defiant in his denials. ``I engaged in no unethical conduct,'' he said firmly. ``You know that I broke no law. ... You know that I broke no Senate rule. ... You know that I pocketed no money, that there was no personal gain for me or any member of my family.'' ``Yes, I was persistent in expressing my concerns about the way bureaucrats were dealing with this large business in my state,'' he said, referring to the savings and loan, which was chartered in California. ``I believed that its failure, if it came to that ... would be a catastrophe for countless constituents of mine.'' The Ethics Committee of three Democrats and three Republicans will make recommendations based on the hearings that could determine the political futures of the five, except Cranston, who has said he will not seek re-election. The committee is trying to determine whether the $1.3 million Keating and associates donated to the five influenced their intervention on his behalf with banking regulators. Many of the donations were given to the senators' campaigns and causes while Keating was trying to save his Irvine, Calif., institution. Regulators seized the thrift in April 1989 and it could cost taxpayers more than $2 billion to cover the losses. Cranston and Riegle enlivened their presentation with props in the televised hearings. The California senator placed five huge posters on easels listing designated staff fund-raisers for each of the Senate's 100 members. ``It is absurd to suggest that fund-raising and substantive issues are separated in Senate offices by some kind of wall,'' the senator said. Riegle held up the puzzle because Bennett had done so on Thursday in promising to fit them all together. Bennett, Riegle said, did not ``have all the pieces of the puzzle. We just have some of the pieces.'' For instance, Riegle said Bennett's presentation left out the main purpose of a Riegle-Keating meeting in January 1987. Bennett said it was related to a Keating-hosted fund-raiser for Riegle scheduled the following March. But Riegle said Keating's itinerary made clear the main reason for the meeting was to discuss a $54 million Keating development project in Detroit. ``Sometimes documents can bleed when they're not presented fairly,'' Riegle said. ``That one was not presented fairly.'' At the end of Riegle's presentation his voice broke as he thanked his family for support. First up to defend himself Friday was McCain of Arizona, the only Republican in the group. He declared, ``I know I acted ethically and properly.'' Next came Glenn, who said, ``At no time did I trade favors or perform actions in return for money.'' Bennett has recommended that the committee dismiss McCain and Glenn from the case but that the investigation be intensified for Cranston, DeConcini and Riegle. Friday's second day of the hearings got off to an acrimonious start as Cranston's lawyer asked that one member, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., be barred from judging the California Democrat. Helms, speaking under oath, stoutly denied Cranston attorney William W. Taylor III's accusation that he had already made up his mind in the case. Helms refused to step aside. Taylor had cited reports from Helms' recent, successful re-election campaign in which the North Carolina Republican had referred to Cranston as ``the leading water carrier'' for Keating. McCain said Keating was a ``political friend and supporter'' from 1981 through 1987, when the two had a falling out because McCain refused to negotiate with banking regulators on the businessman's behalf. ``When he came to see me in 1987 and asked me to do something I thought was improper, I said no,'' McCain said. ``When he asked me to get (former top thrift regulator Edwin J. Gray off his back, I said no.'' Despite the argument with Keating in March 1987, McCain said he still attended April 2 and April 9, 1987, meetings between regulators and the senators in which the lawmakers demanded fair treatment for Lincoln. The most immediate decision for the panel is to determine whether the investigation of each senator should be intensified or dropped. Bennett said as he outlined the evidence Thursday and Friday that Crnston, DeConcini and Riegle were more involved in helping Keating than McCain and Glenn. Keating donated $850,000 to three voter registration projects supported by Cranston and $49,000 to his political campaigns. Bennett said that in September 1987 Cranston sought to solicit $500,000 at one time for the voter projects. His fund-raiser, Joy Jacobson, told the committee ``she thought that was too much'' and persuaded him to lower his request to $250,000, Bennett said. Keating gave the $250,000 Nov. 6. Bennett, in presenting his findings from a yearlong investigation, said, ``In retrospect, I think there was a link'' between Keating's contributions and Cranston's assistance. ``Sen. Cranston's contacts with the (Federal Home Loan Bank) board, the evidence will show, were closely connected with fund-raising by Keating.'' He added, ``It wasn't Mr. Keating who was always seeking things. Sen. Cranston sought contributions from Mr. Keating.'' Bennett added, ``The evidence will show on four occasions Cranston accepted or solicited several hundred thousands of dollars from Keating for voter registration.''

DOC.HEAD: Berlin Gov't Paralyzed; Mayor Offers to Negotiate with Radicals
DOC.TEXT: One of Berlin's mayors offered Friday to negotiate with radical squatters to end the riots that have paralyzed the city's government and threatened to topple its other mayor. A mass police crackdown on leftist radicals occupying scores of buildings in the city this week has resulted in violent protests, street fights with police and hundreds of arrests and injuries. The Berlin government has almost collapsed, and the violence has fueled the arguments of those who oppose making it the seat of government of united Germany. Berliners will elect a united government on Dec. 2, when all Germans also will choose a national government. Tino Schwierzina, the former East Berlin mayor who still holds the title until German elections, said he would negotiate with the leftist radicals as long as they refrained from riots. But the radicals, through intermediaries, issued a statement refusing negotiations and describing the police action as ``terrorism.'' In any case, it is not Schwierzina but West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper who is actually running the city, and Momper is in danger of losing his job over the squatters' controversy. The leftist Greens coalition bolted from Momper's coalition on Thursday to protest what they called unnecessary police action in evicting hundreds of squatters occupying scores of abandoned tenements in former East Berlin. The squatters are protesting a lack of affordable housing in Berlin. Momper's Social Democrats now hold a minority in the city Senate, and the remaining parties say they will not support him as mayor. The conservative Christian Democrats were to decide Tuesday whether to support a no-confidence vote for Momper. Violent clashes since Monday have resulted in nearly 300 arrests and 400 injuries, many serious. Traffic has been snarled by street fighting and marches. On Wednesday, 3,000 riot police and paramilitary troops raided a block of tenements that had been taken over by the radicals, and the hours of street battles caused serious damage. Police used bulldozers, armored cars, water cannons and tear gas against masked street fighters who threw rocks, debris and firebombs. The rioting has bolstered the arguments of those who want the seat of a united German government to remain in the relatively placid town of Bonn. Berlin was designated the symbolic capital of Germany when the two former nations united on Oct. 3, but the united German parliament that is elected on Dec. 2 will have to decide whether to move government ministries to Berlin. Critics say the move would be too costly given the massive costs of salvaging eastern Germany's collapsing economy. They also cite the city's chronic social unrest, caused mainly by the veteran leftist underground, for whom the clashes with police fit into a scheme of reducing Germany to a state of anarchy.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavian Nationalist Gang Beats Up Parliament Members
DOC.TEXT: Moldavian nationalist youths roamed the streets of Kishinev, attacking Russian-speakers and beating up an ethnic Russian member of parliament, Soviet news media and a witness said Friday. The violence swept the Moldavian capital Thursday after the funeral of Dumitru Moldovanu, a young man who reportedly was stabbed in the heart three days earlier in an argument with a Russian who insulted the republic's flag. Ethnic tension has gripped the republic of 4.3 million people, bordering Romania, as it has pushed for independence from the Soviet Union during the past year. Alarmed by rising Moldavian nationalism, two minority groups have launched separatist movements. The Gagauz - about 150,000 Turkish Christians - declared a new republic in southern Moldavia. Ethnic Russians and Ukrainians joined in declaring a new republic along the Dniester River in eastern Moldavia. They speak Russian rather than Romanian, Moldavia's official language. The ethnic conflict flared into violence Nov. 2 when Moldavia's government sent its Interior Ministry troops to clear roadblocks set up by militants in the Dniester area. Three people were killed and nine were wounded by gunfire. On Thursday, more than 150 ethnic Moldavian youths, angry over the stabbing of Moldavanu, broke into cafes and beat up people who did not speak Romanian, the official Soviet news agency Tass and the government newspaper Izvestia reported. A member of the non-Moldavian minority in parliament, Ilya Trombitsky, said in a telephone interview Friday he witnessed the beating of a colleague and narrowly avoided a similar fate. He said he was sitting in a popular cafe in downtown Kishinev, drinking coffee with fellow lawmakers Andrei Safonov and Pyotr Shornikov, when about 20 youhs pushed their way into the building. ``They came up to some people at another table who were speaking Russian, and they demanded to know their nationality,'' Trombitsky said. ``One young man said he was Russian. He was sitting with a girl, but they grabbed him anyway and punched him, and he fell to the ground and they started kicking him. ``We tried to help him, but there were too many of them. They came after us, too. We headed for the door, but they blocked the way.'' He said he and Shornikov were allowed through, ``but they wouldn't let Safonov out.'' Trombitsky said they called police, but by the time help arrived, Safonov had a black eye and was cut and bruised, and the young man first attacked had received ``a very good beating.'' The lawmaker said the youths stole Safonov's watch and the girl's jewelry. He said similar attacks were reported elsewhere downtown. Tass quoted First Deputy Interior Minister Konstantin Antoch as saying Kishinev police were on alert, but ``proved ineffective and somewhat late'' in stopping the rampage. No one was arrested, Antoch said. The parliament passed a resolution Friday condemning the violence and calling it a provocation aimed at disrupting Moldavia's ``national reconciliation process.''

DOC.HEAD: Deadline Arrives For Noriega Attorneys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 10 graf, `Noriega's lawyers ...' to UPDATE with details of Noreiga's demeanor during the hearing. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Earlier in ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-CNN Tapes
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega on Friday pleaded to keep his defense lawyers during a hearing to consider appointing government-paid attorneys to represent him because of delays in unfreezing his assets. ``I believed mistakenly I would have a fair trial,'' the deposed Panamanian dictator said. ``I was made to believe that I could use my funds to hire lawyers of my own choice.'' Citing his military background, Noriega said his attorneys were ``armed with handguns and no support staff, while the prosecutor's office has nuclear weapons.'' ``I realize this case has implications to the highest levels of the United States government, including the White House, and I also realize that many forces are at work beyond your honor's control,'' Noriega said, explaining his fears about getting a fair trial. Noriega's private defense attorneys made a last-minute plea to the judge to throw out the limit on fees in the Criminal Justice Act. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler did not immediately decide the issue but appeared unmoved. He said he had received indications from ``some exceedingly fine criminal defense lawyers'' who were willing to take the case under the low government fee schedule. Looking at Noriega, the judge sought to assure him that he would get a fair trial. ``I want the defendant to understand he is not being cast adrift by the court and by the judicial system,'' Hoeveler said. Noriega's lawyers, led by Frank Rubino, told the judge they would have to abandon the case under conditions set by a law governing court-appointed legal counsel. The 20-minute plea was Noriega's first extensive statement in court since surrendering to invading U.S. troops in January. Clad in his four-star general's uniform, he read in Spanish, speaking forcefully but without raising his voice. He had appeared subdued in some recent hearings, but on Friday smiled and waved to an acquaintance in the audience, and talked animatedly with one of his attorneys. Earlier in the day, the private defense team filed a broad motion asking dismissal of all drug charges against their client. Court papers argued that freezing Noriega's assets and taping his phone calls from prison constituted government misconduct. Rubino also said an unidentified government witness had sought a bribe to change his testimony, possibly in an ttempt to entrap the defense. ``It is abundantly clear that the United States has engaged in misconduct heretofore unimaginable,'' the motion said. ``Indeed, the quality and degree of the government's crimes is unlike anything seen since Watergate.'' Earlier this month, Cable News Network reported it had audio tapes of jailhouse telephone conversations between Noriega and his defense team. Rubino protested that such monitoring of confidential conversations, apparently by federal authorities, and any airing of the tapes by CNN compromised his client's right to a fair trial. Hoeveler did not immediately rule on the dismissal motion. The fee controversy springs from U.S. efforts in the wake of December's invasion of Panama to freeze 27 Noriega-linked bank accounts holding about $20 million. U.S. prosecutors told foreign governments in France, Switzerland, Austria and other nations that the money was drug-related. After Noriega's capture and return to the United States, his attorneys went to Hoeveler asking to withdraw from the case because they had no money to pay fees or expenses. Instead, all sides initially worked out a deal for the government to hire Rubino and his legal team for rates as high as $350 an hour under the Criminal Justice Act. The 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, however, said there was no statutory authority for those rates. The law allows only two or three attorneys paid no more than $75 an hour during the trial and $40 for preparatory work. In addition, the law sharply limits expenses, with judges never granting more than a few thousand dollars for investigators and research. After that rejection, Hoeveler took another route. He determined that Noriega must have had legitimate income during his tenure as a military officer and ordered the U.S. government to free about $6 million of the frozen funds. That money was to go into an escrow account to pay legal expenses. But in the following five months, the Justice Department failed to win the release of any money. Its attorneys told Hoeveler on Tuesday that the foreign governments had initiated their own confiscation actions, and balked at releasing the money. The best chance for Noriega's attorneys appeared to be $5.8 million in cash found by U.S. troops in Noriega's offices in Panama during the invasion. But federal prosecutors say the money was turned over to the new government of Panama because Noriega initially denied ownership, a claim disputed by Noriega's defense. Noriega's defense and many independent legal experts have cried foul over the money issue. Rubino said trying to defend Noriega on a restricted budget made the case into David vs. Goliath. Legal scholars said the fact that the United States took away Noriega's money, then gave him a severely limited legal defense, would reflect badly on the nation's legal system. Noriega is being held at the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside Miami on charges of accepting $4.6 million in bribes to turn Panama into a way station for Colombia's Medellin cocaine cartel.

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed in Fighting; Emergency Restrictions Lifted
DOC.TEXT: Fighting between taxi operators and township residents killed six people in Natal Province, police said, and the government lifted unrest restrictions Friday in 14 black townships. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok last month declared the townships near Johannesburg unrest areas, giving police wide powers to put down violence and detain people. The townships had been wracked by black factional fighting that killed more than 800 people since it broke out in August. Fighting has eased recently. Among the townships freed from unrest restrictions Friday were Soweto, Sebokeng and Kagiso. Some of the worst fighting occurred there, pitting Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party against Xhosa and other blacks linked to the African National Congress. The ANC, led by Nelson Mandela, is the country's leading group challenging the white-led government. With Friday's announcement, only two townships near Pretoria and two near Cape Town remained designated as unrest areas. Violence in those townships has been linked to local issues. Police Capt. Kwazi Nene told the government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. that the clashes Thursday and early Friday in the Folweni township south of Durban followed a commuter boycott of taxi operators this week. The residents, reacting after the government dropped fuel prices, said taxi fares should be lowered, the network reported. Youths began stoning taxis on Thursday after operators refused to lower the fares, it said. Nene said several houses belonging to taxi operators were burned during the clashes, which left six people dead and continued overnight, the broadcasting system reported. Also Friday, the government of the Bophuthatswana black homeland said it wants to join negotiations on South Africa's future and will consider calling a referendum on whether to rejoin South Africa. Homeland President Lucas Mangope previously has refused to consider giving up the homeland's nominal independence. Only South Africa recognizes the sovereignty of Bophuthatswana and three of the other nine homelands - Transkei, Ciskei and Venda. The ANC and other opposition groups consider the homelands part of South Africa's apartheid system of segregation and white dominance. Anti-apartheid groups call for Bophuthatswana to rejoin South Africa. The ANC and South Africa's white-led government have held talks since May on ending apartheid and allowing the black majority to share power. The talks are aimed at setting up negotiations with all political groups on a new constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Bodies of 46 Crash Victims Recovered, Investigators Comb Wreckage
DOC.TEXT: Authorities on Friday recovered the bodies of the 46 victims of the Alitalia jetliner crash and investigators combed wreckage for clues as to what caused the aircraft to slam into a hillside. Zurich airport spokesman ndreas Meier said experts planned to try to reconstruct the pieces of the DC-9 to help determine whether it exploded before crashing five miles from Zurich's Kloten airport. Maier said pilot error was the most likely cause of the crash because radar data showed the plane was flying about 1,000 feet below the correct altitude for preparing to land. He said the data suggested the experienced, 47-year-old pilot ``misjudged his altitude.'' Maier noted that records of the pilot's radio contacts with the control tower at Zurich airport did not indicate any problems. He said the instrument landing system for the runway the plane was assigned to was operating normally. Some witnesses said the pilot seemed to gun the engine just before impact, as if he was trying to regain height. Alitalia officials suggested, however, that the plane's electronic navigation system may have failed. The airline said seven Americans, 10 Swiss, six Spaniards, three Germans, two Japanese and 11 Italians, including the crew of six, perished in the disaster. It said one passenger each was from India, Lebanon, the Netherlands, Finland and Britain. There was no information on the nationality of the remaining two passengers. Identification of the bodies was expected to take weeks as most victims and their possessions were burned beyond recognition by the flames that gutted the aircraft when it crashed and broke into pieces. The plane's two ``black boxes'' were recovered Thursday and will be sent to Britain for evaluation. One recorder tracks flight data and the other tapes cockpit conversation. Alitalia said the two-engine DC-9, built in 1974, was last inspected 10 days before the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Aircraft in U.S. Exercise Are Double the Iraqi Air Power
DOC.TEXT: The 1,100 combat aircraft taking part in the Imminent Thunder exercises are a visible reminder to Iraq that the multinational force assembled in the Persian Gulf has double its air power, defense analysts said Thursday. ``That must be a very sobering thought for President Saddam Hussein,'' said Paul Beaver, publisher of Jane's Defense Weekly, a respected publication on military matters. A news blackout remained in effect on the second day of the exercise Thursday in eastern Saudi Arabia, which will include a mock amphibious invasion by U.S. Marines with air cover and naval support. British fighter aircraft are taking part along with U.S. and Saudi Arabian air, naval and marine units, a British military spokesman said Thursday. British said it had more than 50 planes participating in the exercise. The U.S. military announcement Wednesday mentioned only U.S. and Saudi forces. Defense analysts said the main aim of the exercise is to put together the air-strike capability of the multinational force deployed in the Persian Gulf following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. There is also an element of ``psychological warfare,'' especially in the choice of the name Imminent Thunder for the exercise, the experts said. U.S. officials have said the name has no special significance. ``It is all clearly part of a psychological campaign,'' said Edward Foster, a researcher with the London-based Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies. He said the exercises could be ``a form of increasing the pressure.'' Imminent Thunder involves the largest use of aircraft in a single training exercise since the creation of the multinational force. The exercise also involves 1,000 U.S. Marines and 16 ships, including the aircraft carrier USS Midway. The exact location of Imminent Thunder in eastern Saudi Arabia was not revealed. Press reports have said the exercise would be 10 miles from the Iraqi-Kuwaiti border. No live ammunition will be fired, officials said. ``We all know air power is going to be very important in any conflict, and one would be very surprised if they didn't have an exercise like this to see whether they could keep track of all those planes in the air on a radar screen without hitting each other,'' said Col. Andrew Duncan of the London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies. Beaver, of the Defense Weekly, said the U.S.-dominated multinational force was making sure its command and control system works. ``There's no doubt about it - the most important thing in any land battle is to gain air superiority ... and the most important thing is making sure everybody knows what they're doing,'' he said. ``They need to know that Saudis can refuel American aircraft and Brits can rearm and refuel someone else's aircraft,'' he said. All the analysts spoke in telephone interviews from Britain. The amphibious landing, expected Sunday, will be the fourth by elements of the 4th Marine Expeditionary Battalion, which has been floating off the coast since the deployment began. The other three have been on the southern part of the Arabian peninsula in Oman and Bahrain. By keeping the Marines at sea, Foster said, ``You're always keeping the Iraqis guessing. You're always keeping the amphibious option open.'' Iraq has a 1 million-member army, but only something over 500 combat aircraft. About 430,000 of Iraq's soldiers are deployed in or near Kuwait. The multinational force of the United States and 25 other nations numbers about 330,000 forces, including 230,000 American soldiers. But President Bush has said Washington is sending 200,000 more to ensure that the force has an offensive capability.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Rebuffs Remarks by Soviet Envoy; Oil Falls Below $30
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Bush departing, new Primakov comments. Picks up graf 11 pvs, `Primakov might...' ^LaserPhotos DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Friday rejected a Soviet envoy's suggestion that a solution to the Persian Gulf crisis be linked to Israel's occupation of land claimed by Palestinians. Baker said there could be no rewards for aggression. He spoke in Brussels, Belgium, on the first leg of a 12-day foreign trip that will include talks on the gulf situation. At the United Nations, diplomats said Baker was trying to persuade Security Council foreign ministers to travel to New York to adopt a resolution authorizing force to drive Iraq from Kuwait. Foreign ministers occupy their country's seats on the council only in grave situations. President Bush left Friday to join Baker for further talks with allies, then spend Thanksgiving with U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia. It would be the first presidential visit to front-line troops since the Vietnam War. Despite the Bush administration's growing impatience with Saddam Hussein, there have been increasing calls to avoid rushing into war. Egypt, the Soviet envoy and U.S. congressmen urged on Thursday that more time be allowed for the U.N. trade sanctions on Iraq to work. Oil prices fell Friday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders decided that the outbreak of war could take some time. The price fell $1.87 to $29.25 a barrel. Also expressing optimism were seven peace activists, who left London on Friday for Baghdad hoping to set up camps on both sides of the Saudi-Kuwait border. They said they hoped to deter any fighting. A news blackout, meanwhile, remained in effect on the second day of the Imminent Thunder military exercise in eastern Saudi Arabia. Iraq has condemned the exercise, calling it a ``provocation.'' On Thursday, the Soviet Union's top Middle East envoy, Yevgeny Primakov, said the world should do everything possible to persuade Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait - including agreeing to talks on the Palestinian question. In an interview Friday with NBC-TV, Primakov said the Saddam seems to be softening his ideas on the crisis. ``A kind of evolution is taking place in his views,'' Primakov said, ``and maybe it makes me more optimistic than before.'' Despite his other comments, he insisted the United States and the Soviet Union are moving ``in one direction'' to oust Iraq from Kuwait. Baker said earlier Friday that Washington and Moscow have indeed forged a common position on the gulf crisis. He said they agreed that ``we should not link this gulf issue with other issues.'' Primakov might have been speaking for himself and not for the Soviet government, Baker suggested. Saddam has said he might withdraw from Kuwait if Israel pulled out of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, seized in the 1967 Middle East war. But the United States and its allies have said Iraq must withdraw unconditionally. Baker also said the Bush administration was consulting with its allies on whether to seek a U.N. resolution authorizing military force against Iraq if peaceful means fail. ``It is the view of the United States that force as an option cannot and should not be ruled out,'' he said. Baker, also in Brussels for trade talks with the 12-nation European Economic Community, meets Saturday in Geneva with the foreign ministers of Ethiopia, Ivory Coast and Zaire - all Security Council members. An aide to Baker said Thursday the United States would like to introduce the resolution this month, while its diplomat presides over the council. Yemen, a pro-Iraqi member of the 15-nation council, holds the presidency for December. U.N. diplomats said Baker was consulting with Security Council members on bringing foreign ministers to New York to adopt such a resolution. ``I do not exclude the possibility that in November, the Americans ... may wish to stress the importance of the meeting by holding it at the ministerial level,'' said the Canadian ambassador to the U.N., Yves Fortier. About 330,000 allied soldiers are stationed in Saudi Arabia. They face 430,000 Iraqi troops deployed in southern Iraq and Kuwait, which Saddam invaded on Aug. 2 in a dispute over oil, land and money. Bush has said he will send an additional 200,000 troops to Saudi Arabia. Military officials there said Friday the new deployment will be much swifter than the three months it took to bring the original 230,000 troops to the gulf. Allied troops were participating in the six-day Imminent Thunder military exercise, which includes a mock U.S. Marine amphibious invasion with air cover and close air and naval support of ground forces. Defense analysts said the 1,100 combat aircraft taking part were a reminder to Iraq that the allies have double its air power. ``That must be a very sobering thought for President Saddam Hussein,'' said Paul Beaver, publisher of Jane's Defense Weekly. The seven peace activists said they hoped to prevent fighting from breaking out. They headed for Iraq Friday and planned to set up peace camps on both sides of the Kuwaiti-Saudi border. ``We are well aware of the consequences of our actions, but this is a point of principle in the traditions of Gandhi,'' said Pat Arrowsmith, a 60-year-old peace campaigner. The group included activists from Britain, India, Belgium and Ghana. They said they would be joined by others, including Yusuf Islam, formerly the pop singer Cat Stevens, once the camps were established. Iraq has not ruled out a peaceful solution to the crisis, said the Iranian foreign minister, Ali Akbar Velayati. He was returning from two days in Baghdad. Velayati said it appeared Iraq's leaders had not yet made up their minds. ``One cannot say with certainty that it will go either way, staying in Kuwait, and putting into practice the annexation of Kuwait, or the withdrawal from Kuwait,'' Velayati said.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese News Returns to Revolutionary Greeting
DOC.TEXT: In a return to revolutionary rhetoric, Chinese newscasters have been ordered to greet their viewers as ``comrades,'' the country's state-run television announced Friday. The revival of the greeting is part of a general return to revolutionary slogans and orthodox ideology since Communist leaders crushed last year's pro-democracy movement. Books, movies, newspapers and television shows now carry more pronounced ideological messages. Chinese news anchors had been opening their broadcasts with the greeting, ``Good evening, viewers.'' For the first time in years, news anchors are now greeting viewers as ``comrades.'' China Central Television's evening news department said Friday that an order had come from above to use the revolutionary greeting. On Wednesday, when it was first used, the anchor opened the show tersely: ``Comrades!'' But the format of the greeting is apparently still being experimented with: on Friday night's newscast, the anchor opened with, ``Viewers, comrades, hello!'' In the first decades after the 1949 Communist victory in China, ``comrade'' was the only acceptable way of hailing a shop clerk or waitress or addressing a colleague. But in recent years, ``mister'' and ``miss'' - once denounced as bourgeois - have become common. Anyone using ``comrade'' draws stares and laughter. ``Even the anchorpeople laughed the first time'' the television news used it, said a man who answered the telephone at the news department. He refused to give his name. ``Nonetheless, we are trying it,'' he said. ``We will see what the response is like.'' He said higher-level officials indicated they hope it will usher in a general revival of the word. The order came two weeks after the People's Daily, the Communist Party newspaper, published a letter praising ``comrade'' as a glorious title.

DOC.HEAD: Yellow Fever Kills 69 People in Cameroon
DOC.TEXT: An epidemic of yellow fever has killed 69 people in northern Cameroon, the government said Friday. Ninety others are ill with the fever, a tropical disease transmitted by mosquito bites. All those affected are in the northern provinces of Mayo-Sava and Mayo-Tsanaga, on the border with Nigeria, the government said. Provincial medical authorities said many people had refused to be vaccinated because of rumors the injections cause sterility and because of certain traditional beliefs. Health workers in the north of this West African nation have begun a campaign to reassure people and encourage them to be vaccinated, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Carter Opposes Use of Force to End Gulf Crisis
With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former President Carter on Friday declared his opposition to a possible U.S. invasion of Iraq, saying, ``I wouldn't be willing to give my life to invade someone else's land.'' During a question-and-answer session with 1,200 high school students, Carter said higher oil prices and the potential loss of American jobs were not strong enough reasons for the United States to launch a war in the Middle East. ``I don't believe that those are the kinds of reasons for us to sacrifice human life in the desert of Saudi Arabia and Iraq,'' Carter said during the start of a three-day conference studying his administration at Hofstra University. U.S. troops were deployed to defend Saudi Arabia shortly after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. In Brussels, Belgium, on Friday, U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Washington was consulting with its allies on whether to seek a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait. Carter said that invading a country takes three times as much military might as it does to defend one. He also noted that Iraqis' religious beliefs make it an honor to die for their country. ``I don't have any doubts the U.S. would prevail against Iraq, but the effects would be deleterious, politically,'' said Carter. ``I would offer my life to defend my family and country against an invading force, but I wouldn't be willing to give my life to invade someone else's land,'' he said. Carter spoke at the eighth presidential conference Hofstra has sponsored. Carter, the 39th U.S. chief executive, was president from 1976 to 1980, when he lost a re-election bid to Ronald Reagan. Carter said President Bush made the right move by seeking U.N. support after Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait. ``Bush did a superb job in martialing support to prevent what was considered a likely invasion of Saudi Arabia,'' he said. ``But lately the president is shifting from a defensive role to an offensive role.''

DOC.HEAD: A Decline For The First Time In A Decade
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in a decade, the nations of the world are spending less on weapons, the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency reported Friday. Among them is the Soviet Union. Developing nations accounted for most of the decline, spending $25.1 billion less in 1988 than the year before. The overall drop was $36 billion. Even so, spending on arms surpassed $1 trillion for the second year in a row. Military spending in developing countries has been dropping since 1984. The $11 billiion decline among the wealthier nations is the first drop in a decade. The Soviet Union, meanwhile, spent $299.8 billion on arms in 1988, a drop of 4 percent. The United States led the world with $307.7 billion, showing a slight increase over 1987. The Soviets are still in first place, however, in exporting weapons - $21 billion worth or 44 percent of the world's total in 1988. U.S. arms exports were $14.3 billion, the agency said. The end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988 contributed to a drop in military spending in the Middle East. At $60.7 billon it was at the lowest level in a decade. South Asian military spending continued to grow faster than any other region of the world - with an annual rate from 1978 to 1988 of 6.5 percent. The figures were all given in terms of dollars of 1988 buying power.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Given Life Sentence For Death of 4-year-old Son
DOC.TEXT: A mother was sentenced to life in prison Friday for smothering her 4-year-old son and now faces charges in Texas in the deaths of four other children, three of them her daughters. Diana Lumbrera, 32, repeated her innocence when Finney County District Court Judge J. Stephen Nyswonger sentenced her to life in the Kansas Penitentiary. ``All I've got to tell you is that I didn't murder my son the way you all are accusing me,'' Mrs. Lumbrera said. She was convicted Oct. 3 in the death of her son, Jose Antonio Lumbrera, in her Garden City home last May. In August, a Parmer County, Texas, grand jury indicted Mrs. Lumbrera in the deaths of three daughters - 3-month old Joanna Lumbrera, 2-year-old Melinda Ann Garza and 3-year-old Melissa Lumbrera. The three girls died between 1976 and 1982, before she moved to Kansas. Autopsies and death certificates ruled the girls died of natural causes. But the murder charge in Kansas prompted Texas authorities to reopen the cases. On Sept. 10, Lumbrera was accused of first-degree murder of Erica Lenore Aleman, the 6-week-old daughter of a cousin. Prosecutors contend she killed her children for life insurance money. They have not released their contention of a motive in the death of Erica Aleman. Nyswonger approved a motion to transport Mrs. Lumbrera back to Texas immediately after Friday's sentencing hearing. ``It's Diana's request that we advance the court calendar and that she be allowed to return to Texas to clear herself of the charges pending there,'' said Mrs. Lumbrera's defense attorney, Michael Quint. Quint said an appeal to the sentencing should be ready by Monday. The strongest grounds for appeal were extensive pre-trial publicity Quint contended kept his client from getting a fair trial.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: ^By RITA BEAMISH
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday vetoed legislation designed to crack down on countries and firms that traffic in chemical weapons. At the same time, Bush issued an executive order he said would accomplish the principal goals of the bill. The order imposes new export controls on chemical and biological weapons and calls for sanctions against violators. Another provision of the bill would have forbidden trade with Cuba by overseas subsidiaries of U.S. companies, a ban to which U.S. allies strongly objected. The president said in a statement his major objection to the legislation ``is not the requirement of sanctions, but the rigid way in which they are imposed.'' He said the bill would force him to impose sanctions against countries with whom the United States might want to keep smooth relations. Bush's order: -Prohibits exports that would help foreign chemical and biological weapons programs. -Controls exports that would assist foreign countries in producing and procuring chemical weapons. -Requires diplomats to work for a new international agreement banning chemical weapons, with adequate verification procedures, and to seek negotiations with other countries to cooperate in blocking the spread of chemical weapons. -Directs sanctions against foreign countries and their citizens who use chemical or biological wepaons or ``are making substantial preparations to use such weapons'' or have developed or stockpiled such weapons in violation of international law. ``The mandatory imposition of unilateral sacntions as provided in this bill would harm U.S. economic interest and provoke friendly countries who are essential to our efforts to resist Iraqi aggression,'' he said. The sanctions Bush directed against foreign countries involved in chemical weapons proliferation include cutting of U.S. foreign aid and arms exports to that country, opposition to any loans to the country from international lending organizations, restriction of U.S. imports from the country, and a variety of other measures. The State Department said the bill could impede U.S. foreign policy in the current climate of alliances with old foes, would be ``objectionable intrusiveness into Executive Branch prerogatives'' and would be ``potentially fatal to our efforts to cooperate with friends and allies.'' The State Department also opposed a provision aimed at preventing overseas subsidiaries of American companies from trading with Cuba. Britain, Canada and other countries where these subsidiaries operate have complained the legislation would infringe on their sovereignty. During a meeting this past week, Canadian External Affairs Minister Joe Clark told Secretary of State James A. Baker III the requirement was ``unacceptable.'' U.S. overseas subsidiaries do about a $320 million business with Cuba annually. Computer and high-tech industries backed the bill, but the U.S. CHamber of Commerce wanted a veto. The Simon Wiesenthal Center urged Bush to sign the bill, based on its investigation that it said showed 207 western companies helped provide Iraq's President Saddam Hussein with chemical and biological weapons. The center said those included 86 from Germany and 18 from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: No Sure Evidence of Explosives Handled By Birmingham Six: Lawyers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Peirce cq in 8th graf
DOC.TEXT: Defense lawyers said Friday that a government report casts doubt on the 1974 murder convictions of six Irishmen for two bombings that killed 21 people. The report concluded no one could be sure any of the six had handled explosives, the lawyers said. Evidence at least two of the so-called Birmingham Six had traces of nitroglycerine on their hands when arrested was crucial to their convictions. The six have waged a campaign to prove they were convicted and sentenced to life unjustly. Last August the government ordered the Court of Appeal to review their convictions. Home Secretary David Waddington cited apparent discrepancies in police notes of an interview with Richard McIlkenny, one of the six. Ivan Geffen, a lawyer for Gerry Hunter, another of the six, said a report by the Home Office forensic service cast doubt on the convictions in the Nov. 21, 1974 bombings of two Birmingham pubs by the Irish Republican Army. The new report was commissioned by the Director of Public Prosecutions, which is deciding whether to contest the new appeal. ``No one can be sure beyond reasonable doubt that any of the six men had handled explosives,'' Geffen quoted the report as saying. He said the Court of Appeal, which affirmed the verdicts in 1988, ``made a grave error of judgment in the way it interpreted the scientific evidence.'' Gareth Peirce, a lawyer for the other five men, said the government report would likely be ``the final nail in the coffin of the prosecution's case.'' Five of the six men were arrested hours after the bombings, as they were about to board a ferry to Northern Ireland for the funeral of an IRA man. McIlkenny, Hunter, Johnny Walker, Patrick Hill, Hugh Callaghan and Billy Power were convicted of murder for the bombings, which killed 21 and injured 162. They were the deadliest bombings the IRA has carried out in England in its campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Reporters Must Find Own Hotels in South America
DOC.TEXT: As White House reporters prepared to fly off with President Bush to Europe and the Middle East, they got the startling news that they may not have places to stay when Bush goes to South America next month. Hotel rooms will be arranged by the White House in Santiago, Chile, Brasilia and Caracas, but reporters are on their own in Buenos Aires, and in Montevideo and Punta del Este, Uruguay. The only explanation given by White House officials was that hotel rooms for White House staff and the full press corps could not be procured. The rooms had been all arranged for the original dates of the trip in September. But Bush had to postpone the trip under pressure of budget negotiations with Congress and the military buildup against Iraq in the Persian Gulf. In Buenos Aires, where Bush addresses the national congress and meets with President Carlos Menem, a Jehovah's Witness convention was said to have taken all available rooms. ``All press travelling on the trip are advised to make proper hotel reservations in Buenos Aires as soon as possible,'' the White House said in its notice. There was no announcement on what caused the shortage in Uruguay where Bush will stay one night in Punta del Este. ``There is no further hotel space available in either Montevideo or Punta del Este,'' the White House notice said. The press charter plane that accompanies Bush will fly to Buenos Aires after Bush's Uruguay appearances, and those who have been able to find rooms there will have shelter for the night. Generally, the White House travel office canvasses the press corps to see who will accompany Bush and then takes care of all the travel and hotel arrangements, with news organizations paying the bills incurred by their employees.

DOC.HEAD: Small Town Deals With Deadly School Bus-Train Collision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with dead boy's hometown, conditions of injured, results of preliminary investigation. ADDS byline. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Deanna Schultz ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SCD1
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this town of 170 people dealt with feelings of helplessness and sorrow on Friday after a school-bus collision killed two people and injured 21 others. ``It is just horrendous,'' said Sheila Olson, principal at the Miltona Science Magnet School. Olson said many students wanted to rush to the accident scene near the school because they had just gotten off the bus and some had older brothers and sisters still aboard. ``I still can't believe it happened,'' Olson said. ``It's just not real. And the kids, many were crying, wanting their parents and you just feel so helpless. You just don't know what to do.'' The Douglas County Sheriff's Department identified the victims as bus driver Fred Beman, 66, of Alexandria, and 9-year-old Kristian Rindahl of rural Carlos, who attended Zion Lutheran School in Alexandria. Five of the injured were in stable condition at Douglas County Hospital in Alexandria with a variety of fractures and internal injuries, said hospital spokeswoman Verna Pauley. Fourteen people had been treated and released and another two were waiting to be discharged late Friday, she said. The accident happened around 7:30 a.m. Friday in Miltona, about 100 miles northwest of Minneapolis. The cause was not immediately known, but Douglas County Sheriff Terry Eilers said preliminary interviews with witnesses indicated the driver may have rolled the vehicle into the train. Deanna Schultz, secretary for the Miltona school, said the bus had just dropped off some children at the school and was on its way to the high school in Alexandria. Bob Stier, transportation supervisor for the Alexandria school system, which owns the bus, said about 25 students were aboard when the accident happened. ``The front end of the bus got hit,'' Stier said. ``It was a flat-nosed bus and it (the train) hit the side where the driver was. ``The bus got spun around, then the front end of the bus hit a light pole,'' Stier said, adding that the train did not derail. There were no injuries on the train, officials said. Alexandria school Superintendent George Cassell said Beman had been with the school district 10 years and had an excellent driving record. ``We are in shock. (We're) just having a hard time understanding what happened today,'' he said. Cassell said state and federal investigators were expected to arrive Friday afternoon. The school district brought in a team of counselors to help comfort the children, Olson said. ``I just simply stood in the halls as students were walking back and forth between their rooms and just shared hugs with some of the children who were in tears and very frightened by it,'' said Nancy Larson, a Lutheran minister from Carlos.

DOC.HEAD: Landsbergis Tries to Put English Trip in Good Light
DOC.TEXT: Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis sought Friday to portray his four-day trip to Britain as a success, although he failed to win formal British support for Lithuanian independence. In a speech to the parliament of the Baltic republic, Landsbergis said ``the political forces of Britain support Lithuania's striving for independence'' even though ``the stand of the Thatcher government is more restrained.'' British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher met with Landsbergis during his visit this week. Apparently reluctant to add to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's domestic woes, she did not endorse Lithuania's drive to secede from the Soviet Union. Lithuania declared independence on March 11 but suspended the declaration last summer in return for the Kremlin's agreement to halt an economic embargo and enter talks. After weeks of preliminary meetings, the formal negotiations toward possible independence were scheduled to begin at the end of this month. But Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said in an intervew published Friday that the Lithuanian government would not hold talks with the national government headed by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov. Prunskiene said Thursday at a Moscow press conference that Ryzhkov had shown no willingness to compromise. In the interview with the newspaper Lietuvos Ritas, she said Lithuania should appeal to Gorbachev to intervene in the negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Dealer Says State Refused Halt Sale In Berkeley Hostage Incident
DOC.TEXT: The state Department of Justice refused to block the sale of a handgun to a man who later held dozens hostage in a Berkeley tavern and killed a student, a gun shop owner said Friday. Gun dealer Bob Weaver said he tried to prevent sale of a weapon to Mehrdad Dashti, a former mental patient, before his Sept. 27 rampage in the Durant Hotel bar. John Sheehy, 22, was killed and nine other University of California students were wounded before police stormed Henry's Publick House & Grille, freed 33 hostages and killed Dashti, a 30-year-old Iranian immigrant. Weaver said he went so far as to file down the hammer of a 9mm Ruger pistol before he handed it over to Dashti. Dashti soon returned the defective weapon and Weaver said he finally had to sell Dashti a working gun. The type of gun Dashti used in the shootings remains unclear. Details of the sale surfaced in a thick file obtained by the San Francisco Chronicle from Berkeley police under the state Freedom of Information law. ``We knew the guy was loopy,'' Weaver said. ``We told the Justice Department about him, but they said there was nothing they could do about it.'' Repeated telephone calls Friday for comment from the state Justice Department were unsuccessful. Weaver, saying he feared retribution, refused to give the name of the person he spoke with at the Justice Department. The police records backed Weaver's story, saying that all through the state-mandated 15-day waiting period in handgun sales, ``Weaver had the gun in the store, but was very reluctant to release it to Dashti.'' The waiting period for anyone who wants to buy a handgun in California is used for checks with the state Justice Department in Sacramento to see whether the potential buyer has been convicted of a felony or certified as insane by a court. Although Dashti got into minor trouble with the law and had been a patient at the Berkeley Mental Health Clinic, it was legal for him to buy handguns. Alameda County authorities had assessed Dashti as a paranoid schizophrenic. Police records said Dashti bought the defective Ruger from Weaver in March. During the 15-day waiting period ``two of Dashti's friends came to the store pleading with (Weaver) not to sell Dashti the gun,'' the records said. Weaver, who owns the Old West Gun Room in El Cerrito, said he and Berkeley police were convinced Dashti was mentally unstable. On the night he took the hstages, Dashti called a friend to have a late-night drink. After ordering, Dashti opened up his briefcase, produced a handgun and opened fire, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Jetliner Wheels Snap at Curacao; No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: An Air Jamaica jet carrying 59 passengers collapsed on its belly and skidded to a halt Friday after the back wheels broke on landing, airport officials said. The passengers were safely evacuated and no injuries were reported. Witnesses said the Boeing 727, leaning on its left wing, slid or hundreds of yards before coming to a stop on the runway. A wheel caught fire but firefighters quickly extinguished it, officials said. The Air Jamaica jet was on a regular flight from Kingston, the capital of Jamaica, to Curacao, a Dutch island territory in the Caribbean just off Venezuela. Most of the passengers were Jamaican tourists. Curacao International Airport was closed to large aircraft Friday so authorities could remove the plane from the landing strip.

DOC.HEAD: Negotiators For Unions, Newspapers Pressed By Strike Deadline
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with clock stopped on strike deadline, talks to continue; Picks up 10th graf, `Mercury News ...' EDITS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators agreed to continue talks beyond a Friday strike deadline that was set by about 4,500 union employees of the San Francisco Bay area's three largest daily newspapers. Ten unions and management of the San Francisco Chronicle, San Francisco Examiner and San Jose Mercury News made progress on salary proposals and stopped the clock on the threatened 5 p.m. strike, said Johnny Miller, a negotiator for the Newspaper Guild. ``It's an indication there was some movement,'' he said. The unions asked for a 20 percent pay raise and a four-day workweek. Management suggested a wage freeze during the proposed three-year contract, with $80 lump sum payments every six months to each employee. Jessie Knight, management spokesman and senior vice president at the Examiner, said that despite the gap, negotiations were productive. Knight refused to confirm management's specific pay offer. Talks were to continue into the night. Sally Lehrman, spokeswoman for the Newspaper Guild and an Examiner business writer, said workers wouldn't be satisfied with a 3 percent to 4 percent pay raise, although some nervous employees said they could live with that rather than give up paychecks in a strike. All the old, three-year contracts, most of which expired in February, gave employees an average of 3 percent to 5 percent pay and benefit increases each year. The union workers covered include reporters, editors, drivers, secretaries, librarians and press operators. A federal mediator was brought in this week to help resolve the contract dispute. Nearly every reporter and photographer withheld bylines and credits lines Friday and planned to continue the protest until a contract is approved. It was the first byline strike in the 125-year history of the two San Francisco newspapers. Mercury News managers have prepared for weeks to publish without union staff. The San Francisco newspapers also planned to publish. San Francisco's last newspaper strike was in 1968, when workers for the Examiner and the Chronicle walked. The strike lasted 55 days. The Mercury News was last struck in 1959, for four months. ``Whatever happens today, there's a general feeling that we'll be happy one way or another to get off this tightrope we've been walking on without a contract,'' said Angelo Figueroa, Examiner city hall reporter. ``There's been so much speculation about a wage freeze that there's just this desire to get this over with.'' Top scale pay is $800 a week for reporters and editors, $669 for clerical and library workers and $675 for drivers. Non-economic issues were resolved by Thursday night, said Richard Jordan, chief negotiator for the San Francisco Newspaper Agency, which operates the Chronicle and the Examiner under a Joint Operating Agreement. The agreement merges the two newspapers' advertising, circulation and business operations but maintains separate editorial departments. Neil Chethik, chairman of the Newspaper Guild for the Mercury News, and other union officials said the strike deadline was set to force management to talk on pay issues. The morning Chronicle, with weekday circulation of about 560,000, publishes jointly with the Examiner on Sunday for a combined circulation of about 725,000. The afternoon Examiner has a weekday circulation of about 138,000. The two newspapers entered into the Joint Operating Agreement in 1965. The San Jose Mercury News has a daily circulation of about 275,000 during the week and about 329,000 on Sundays.

DOC.HEAD: Salcido Jury Says Death In Gas Chamber
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Friday said Ramon Salcido should die in the gas chamber for killing his wife, two of his daughters and four other people in a 1988 wine country rampage. Salcido, 29, had a faraway stare when a Spanish interpreter translated the jury's decision. One juror wept as the verdict was delivered. ``He doesn't know where he is,'' defense attorney Marteen Miller said. ``He's not insane, but he's a little goofy.'' Jurors said Salcido's aloof demeanor and apparent lack of remorse during the trial played a significant role in their decision to give him the death penalty instead of life in prison without parole. Defense attorneys claimed cocaine, alcohol and jealousy triggered Salcido to kill his wife, two young daughters, mother-in-law, two sisters-in-law and his boss. Another daughter, 2-year-old Carmina, survived after Salcido slit her throat and dumped her in a ravine with her sisters. ``I was expecting a mad-dog killer and I didn't see that,'' jury foreman Dr. John Williams, 36, a medical researcher from Portola Valley, said of his first reaction to Salcido. ``I saw him then as a deer caught in the headlights, an almost pathetic man who may have gone crazy for awhile. ``But in going over the evidence, I decided this was not the case,'' Williams said. ``His crime fit his personality. He did it in a coldhearted way, and he deserved the death penalty.'' Sonoma County prosecutor Peter Bumerts described Salcido as ``fairly cold and calculating, more like a fox than a mad dog.'' Juror Dory Horn, 49, of South San Francisco, wept as the verdict was read. She said deciding the case ``was the hardest thing I've ever had to do.'' ``You know you're deciding to take somebody else's life,'' she said. ``It's not over, and it won't be. There's no peace at all.'' Superior Court Judge Reginald Littrell, on assignment from Sierra County, set formal sentencing for Dec. 17. An appeal to the state Supreme Court is automatic in California death penalty cases, and the defense believes it may have at least two other chances to save Salcido's life - a protest by the Mexican government and a ruling by federal court. Miller said he would file a writ with the U.S. District Court in San Francisco arguing the county did not have jurisdiction over the death penalty because of an extradition treaty with Mexico. Salcido, who fled to his home in Mexico after the killings, was delivered to Sonoma County officials by Mexican authorities. Miller claimed the Mexican government was ``fraudulently misled'' into releasing Salcido under U.S. officials' claims he was an American citizen. The state Supreme Court already turned down Miller's petition on Salcido's release in Mexico. California has not held an execution since 1967, and about 280 condemned prisoners are now on death row. The jury on Oct. 30 found Salcido guilty of six counts of first-degree murder, one count of second-degree murder and two counts of attempted murder. He was convicted of shooting or slashing to death his wife, Angela, his 4-year-old and 22-month-old daughters, Sofia and Teresa, his mother-in-law, Marion Richards, her 12-year-old and 8-year-old daughters, Ruth and Maria, and Tracey Toovey, 35, the winemaster at Grand Cru winery in Glen Ellen. The jury also convicted Salcido of attempting to murder his daughter Carmina, and Kenneth Butti, his supervisor at the winery. The defense never disputed Salcido was the killer. But Miller had sought a verdict of second-degree murder or manslaughter, saying drugs had put Salcido in a ``psychotic depression.''

DOC.HEAD: Mass Honors Slain Jesuits in El Salvador
DOC.TEXT: More than 150 priests took part in an outdoor Mass Friday evening to mark a year since six Jesuit priest-educators were slain by army troops. Seventeen Roman Catholic bishops, including four U.S. prelates, co-celebrated Mass for about 2,000 people in a parking lot at the University of Central America, where the priests taught and were hailed Friday as martyrs. The wooden stage holding the altar was draped with a banner reading ``How Long?'' The phrase is from the biblical book of Apocalypse, which has the souls of those slain for their devotion crying out to the Lord: ``How long until you do justice and demand an accounting for our blood from the inhabitants of earth?'' On Nov. 16, army troops broke into the campus residence and murdered the Revs. Ignacio Ellacuria, Ignacio Martin-Baro, Segundo Montes, Amado Lopez, Juan Ramon Moreno and Joaquin Lopez. Their housekeeper and her daughter were killed to eliminate witnesses, according to testimony from several soldiers. An army colonel, three lieutenants and four soldiers are under arrest and charged with the murders. The case has yet to go to trial. Portraits of the slain priests, the housekeeper and her daughter, hung from a wire stretched above the altar. The setting sun illuminated, one by one from behind, the images on white cloth stretched over wooden frames. The Rev. Jose Maria Tojeira, the Jesuit leader for Central America, delivered the homily. ``Our companions' life and death oblige the developed world to make commitments - a developed world that cannot content itself with good words uttered from its position of comfort as long as the relationship between rich countries of the north and the poor immense majorities of the south remains a fraud that generates injustice and inequality,'' he said. The far right had long considered the Jesuits subversives for their contention that the 11-year-old Salvadoran civil war stems from injustice, repression and poverty - rather than international Communist expansion. The massacre has been a sticking point in relations between the Salvadoran and U.S. governments. Several U.S. congressmen have accused the conservative government of Alfredo Cristiani of foot-dragging in the case. The U.S. bishops who took part in Friday's ceremony were the Revs. Walter Sullivan of Richmond, Va.; Carlos Sevilla of San Francisco; Ricardo Ramirez of Las Cruces, N.M.; and Rembert Weakland of Milwaukee. Weakland has been in the news recently over the refusal of the Vatican to let a Swiss university grant him an honorary degree. The Vatican is unhappy with his willingness to hear the views of parishioners who favor abortion and his criticism of some abortion foes as intolerant.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Los Angeles
Music Fans Steaming Over Pop Duo Sham
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for 13th graf, `Michael Greene ...' to UPDATE with comments on duo's Grammy by president of National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences. Picks up 14th graf, `Milli Vanilli ...'
DOC.TEXT: Angry fans turned in their ``Milli Vanilli'' recordings Friday and radio stations vowed to pull the pop duo off the air after their producer revealed hunky Fab and Rob didn't sing their own way to fame. ``I think they're dirty scumbuckets,'' said 9-year-old Katie Dickman of Richmond, Ind. ``I used to like them, but not now.'' Radio station WLOL-FM in Minneapolis declared itself ``Milli Vanilli Free,'' saying it will no longer play the duo's hit 1988 debut album, ``Girl You Know It's True,'' which earned them a Grammy for best new group. The station offered listeners an exchange of their Milli Vanilli recordings for a CD or cassette of their choice. About 150 people took up the station on the offer, said program director Greg Strassell. ``People are mad,'' said disc jockey Paul J. Roberts of WQQK-FM in Nashville, Tenn. ``Listeners are saying they feel like fools. Some say they feel they should burn their compact discs and tapes. They feel duped.'' Milli Vanilli's German producer, Frank Farian, revealed to reporters this week that dreadlocked pretty boys Fab and Rob - Robert Pilatus and Fabrice Morvan - didn't sing on the album. Farian also said the two did nothing more than look good and lip sync for videos and live appearances while others did all the singing. In a statement Thursday, Pilatus and Morvan said they ``have been ready, willing and able to record our own vocals and have been prevented by Frank Farian from doing so.'' In an interview with the Los Angeles Times, Pilatus said: ``The last two years of our lives have been a total nightmare. We've had to lie to everybody. We are true singers, but that maniac, Frank Farian, would never allow us to express ourselves.'' The duo's record company, Arista Records, said they didn't know the pair were fronts for other vocalists but were not embarrassed by the revelation. Dan McKay, program director at K-LITE-FM in Los Angeles, said the real singers are very good and deserve notice. Farian would not identify the real vocalists, but USA Today and other newspapers reported they are John Davis and Charles Shaw. ``I'm a little disappointed, but I'm not gonna stop playing the record. It's good stuff,'' McKay said. ``Where are these people? Do they look like Homer Simpson or something; they can't surface?'' Michael Greene, president of the National Academy of Recording Arts & Sciences, which administers the Grammy Awards, said an awards subcommittee will meet in New York City on Dec. 5 to discuss whether to revoke the duo's 1989 Grammy.
