The board of trustees will meet later that month to make a final decision, he said. Greene suggested that the Grammy should be forefeited, saying ``I don't think what we've done so far should stand as it is.'' ``We're appalled by it,'' he added at a Las Vegas news conference. ``But our hearts go out to these two guys, because they're very easy targets.'' Milli Vanilli won three American Music Awards this year. Show spokesman Paul Shefrin said organizers have not asked the group to return those awards. ``The only ones who could take them back from Milli Vanilli is the American public,'' Shefrin said. Some in the recording industry were not surprised by the deception. ``Rumors have abounded for a long time about how little Milli Vanilli contributed to their album,'' said Diana Baron, vice president for publicity at A&M Records. Roberts of WQQK said the station started a petition drive to get Milli Vanilli's Grammy recalled. No decision had been made on whether the station will continue to air the group's tunes. Station WFLZ-FM in Tampa, Fla., apologized to listeners for carrying what it considered a ``blatant misrepresentation'' and demanded an apology from Arista Records and Milli Vanilli's management. Program manager Marc Chase said the station will boycott Milli Vanilli records and may even go as far as boycotting all Arista artists. Farian said he was forced to go public with the revelations when Pilatus and Morvan told him they wanted to sing on the group's next album. Farian said the real singers will appear on his next album - not a Milli Vanilli album. Pilatus said he and Morvan planned to do their own singing from now on. Pilatus called Farian a ``control freak.'' ``We were afraid for two years that this day would come,'' Pilatus said. ``We've cried about it sometimes. ... But deep inside, we wanted it to happen.''

DOC.HEAD: Record Store Owner Loses Bid For New Trial
DOC.TEXT: A record store owner convicted of obscenity for selling a sexually explicit album by the rap group 2 Live Crew lost his bid for a new trial on Friday. An all-white jury convicted Charles Freeman, 32, on Oct. 3 for selling the Miami-based rappers' album ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be.'' Freeman's attorney, Bruce Rogow, argued Friday his client should be granted another trial because Broward County Judge Paul Backman gave jury instructions that both defense attorneys and prosecutors had not agreed to. During deliberations, jurors had Backman define again the state's obscenity law. Rogow said Backman went beyond the definition in his answer, adding that jurors did not have to rely on the testimony of expert witnesses. Backman denied Rogow's request, saying his instructions were guidelines for defining obscenity. ``What the court did is what it felt its obligation to be under the law, and that was to reinstruct the jury from start to finish as it related to the totality of the law on obscenity,'' Backman said. ``I'm not surprised,'' Freeman said afterward. ``You expect the worst and that way you deal with it a little better. I think the whole thing is a joke; it's a circus.'' The misdemeanor conviction carries a possible one-year jail sentence and $1,000 fine. Sentencing has not been set. Rogow said he would appeal. A federal judge in June ruled the album's lyrics obscene and banned the album's sale in three South Florida counties. Freeman was arrested two days later when he sold the album to undercover police officers at his Fort Lauderdale record store. Three 2 Live Crew members were acquitted Oct. 20 of misdemeanor obscenity charges stemming from a performance at a nightclub in nearby Hollywood.

DOC.HEAD: Ten-Year Sentence for Capitol Bomber
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday imposed a 10-year prison sentence on a woman who pleaded guilty to charges she helped bomb the U.S. Capitol seven years ago. Marilyn Buck also was ordered to serve a concurrent five-year prison term for conspiracy in the incident, which occurred the night of Nov. 7, 1983. Friday's sentences from U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene will run concurrently with a 60-year sentence Buck is serving on other charges, prosecutors said. Repairs to the Capitol and art work displayed there cost $250,000, the U.S. attorney's office said. Buck pleaded guilty Sept. 7 to charges she was involved in the bombing and in plans to bomb other federal buildings. The remaining co-defendants in the case, Linda Evans and Laura Whitehorn, still are awaiting sentencing. A group calling itself the Armed Resistance Unit claimed responsibility for the Capitol bombing, saying it was done in response to U.S. military action in Grenada. The bomb was placed in a public corridor near the Senate Republican Cloak Room and a few feet from the offices of Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who was then the majority leader. It was detonated with a time-delay device. Prosecutors said an investigation revealed members of the group also were involved in seven other bombings from 1983 to 1985 in the Washington and New York areas. Authorities said Buck participated in a 1981 Brinks armored truck robbery in Nyack, N.Y., in which four people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Majority: Bush Should Clear Iraq Attack with Congress
DOC.TEXT: Three out of four Americans think President Bush should get permission from Congress before launching an attack on Iraq, according to national poll results reported Friday. The ABC News-Washington Post poll found 76 percent favored Bush getting congressional approval, up from 69 percent early this month. But other responses in the poll indicated support for Bush's contention that he must be free to respond swiftly to any Iraqi provocation. Fifty-two percent say either that Bush does not need congressional approval or that they would back him if he didn't have time to get it. The poll has been measuring public approval of Bush's response to the Persian Gulf crisis since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Support peaked at 78 percent in a Sept. 9 poll, fell to 65 percent early this month and 59 percent in the current poll, conducted by telephone Nov. 14 and 15. Bush's decision last week to send additional U.S. troops to the gulf garnered 61 percent support. Fifty-two percent believe the buildup makes war more likely, and 71 percent expect the United States to get involved in a war with Iraq. The pollsters reported questioning 515 adult Americans in a sampling that generally should produce results accurate to within 5 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Czechoslovakia Bjt
Bush Embarks on Trip To Europe, Middle East
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 8: ``Before he,'' to CORRECT that Bush letter addressed to Byrd, not Mitchell
DOC.TEXT: President Bush got last-minute briefings on the Persian Gulf crisis Friday before embarking on a weeklong journey that will include a Thanksgiving visit with American forces sent to the Middle East. Bush's first stop, early Saturday, was to be in Prague, to lay a wreath commemorating the first anniversary of Czechoslovakia's turn to democracy. The visit was the first ever by an American president. Hundreds of thousands of people were expected to pack into Wenceslas Square to hear him speak. After celebrating Czechoslovakia's ``Velvet Revolution,'' Bush is scheduled to fly to Germany to meet with Chancellor Helmut Kohl before heading on to Paris. There, he'll be reunited with longtime American allies in Europe - and former foes as well - in a treaty-signing ceremony that will push the Cold War further into the depths of history. Bush went jogging Friday as he prepared for the transatlantic flight. He also wrapped up details on some domestic work, signed some legislation and went over briefing materials for his eight-day trip. A large part of the official talks during his travels will center on the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. The president left from Andrews Air Force Base near Washington shortly before 7 p.m. The White House announced that congressional leaders - Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, House Speaker Thomas Foley, Senate Republican leader Bob Dole and House Republican leader Robert Michel - accepted Bush's invitation to join him in Saudi Arabia for the holiday. Dole said the leaders will leave Washington Tuesday evening and return Friday. ``I think it's a good indication,'' he said. ``It sends a good signal, not only to the American people, but hopefully to Saddam Hussein, that there is bipartisanship and politics does stop at the water's edge.'' Before he left, Bush wrote Foley and Senate President Pro Tem Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., to announce formally his latest deployements. ``In my August 9 letter, I indictaed that I did not believe that involvement in hostilities was imminent'' and that the buildup would facilitate a ``peaceful resolution of the crisis.'' ``My view on these matters has not changed,'' Bush wrote. The War Powers Act of 1973, which no president has accepted as constitutional, requires notice of overseas deployments if hostilities are imminent and mandates a withdrawl of troops if Congress does not approve the action within 90 days. No one has invoked the act in the Kuwait crisis, but congressional unease with the prospect of war has been palpably rising recently. Bush flies from Paris to Saudi Arabia to spend Thanksgiving Day with the troops he ordered to the Gulf region to stand against the Iraqi army of President Saddam Hussein in the wake of the invasion and takeover of Kuwait. Bush vowed Thursday that despite the massive buildup that will put more than 400,000 U.S. troops in the region, he does not intend to embark on a no-win war akin to Vietnam. ``I will not, as commander-in-chief, ever put somebody into a military situation that we do not win - ever,'' he said in an interview with CNN. ``And there's not going to be any long drawn-out agony of Vietnam.'' But Bush also said he could understand the public's growing uneasiness with his military buildup ``because they are thinking, we don't want to have a drawn-out Vietnam.'' He said he wanted a strong U.S. offensive capability in the Middle East to send a ``clear clarion signal to Saddam Hussein, we are deadly serious'' about Iraq retreating from Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. During his trip, Bush will take the opportunity to discuss the Persian Gulf problem with members of the 34-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, including Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Bush has repeatedly touted the international solidarity against Saddam and has rigorously solicited support from other countries for the U.S. military buildup. He plans to sound out Britain, France and other CSCE participants on the wording of a pending United Nations resolution that would authorize use of military action to oust Iraq from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Iraq Believed to Have British-Made Superguns
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is believed to possess three superguns that are capable of firing artillery shells at targets up to 465 miles away, according to a report Saturday in The Independent. The London newspaper said U.S. intelligence sources believe the British-made guns may have been delivered to Iraq before the supergun development program, known as Project 839, was uncovered by British customs officers in April. It said it was not known if the guns were operational. The report noted that charges were dropped Thursday at Sheffield Magistrates Court against two men charged with breaching Britain's arms embargo against Iraq. Both had denied any knowledge of the alleged gun. Reports had indicated the two men, businessman Peter Mitchell and metallurgist Christopher Cowley, were linked to ballistics expert Gerald Bull, who helped design the Iraqi supergun but was shot to death outside a Brussels,. Belgium, apartment last March. British reports speculated Israeli agents may have killed Bull, a Canadian who became a naturalized American citizen, to halt work on the weapon. Bull reportedly was hired by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to develop a supergun capable of lobbing shells hundreds of miles or launch satellites cheaply. The Independent said the ecision to drop charges against the two men ``is understood to have been made at the highest level with Cabinet knowledge.'' It suggested that technical intelligence services in Britain and the United States had been infuriated by the withholding of data about the weapons system while the case was pending. ``Now that Britain and America face a possible war with Iraq, the need to know the full capability of any superguns in Iraqi hands has become pressing,'' the paper said. On April 12, British customs officers seized eight large sections of steel tubing at Teesport dock in northeast England as they were about to be shipped to Iraq. The Iraqi government and the manufacturer, Sheffield Forgemasters of Rotherham in northern England, said the tubes were intended for an Iraqi petrochemical plant. But military experts at that time said they believed the tubes were destined to form the barrel of a huge Iraqi gun. The Independent reported Saturday, however: ``Further customs investigations revealed that these tubes were not part of a gun but were part of a ballistic test bed, designed to allow the Iraqis to devise a cheap way of launching satellites by literally firing them into space. ``However, it was later discovered that at the same time the Iraqis had been taking delivery of other components which, customs learned, were designed to be assembled into working artillery pieces.'' Turkish customs officers in April seized a 30-ton steel cylinder from a Hungarian-registered truck heading for Iraq. British customs officers said they thought this was also due to form part of an Iraqi gun. Other suspected parts were seized in Greece and Italy. Cowley, 52, is a former associate of Bull, according to Press Association, the British domestic news agency. Mitchell, 43, is managing director of forgemasters Walter Somers Ltd., of Halesowen, manufacturers of the pipe found in Turkey. Both had been charged with organizing illegal exports from England. Press Association said Cowley acted as Bull's project coordinator in contacts with Walter Somers. The Independent said Saturday that Cowley designed Project Babylon, the experimental system seized at Teesport.

DOC.HEAD: Hackers Sentenced in 911 Computer Break-in
DOC.TEXT: A 20-year-old computer hacker was sentenced Friday to a 21-month prison term on federal charges of breaking into a nine-state 911 emergency network and passing access codes to other hackers. Robert J. Riggs pleaded guilty with two other computer enthusiasts. An indictment alleges they belonged to the ``Legion of Doom,'' a tight-knit group of hackers who used computers to tap into the 911 system and copy the program. Riggs, from Decatur, and Franklin E. Darden Jr., 23, of Norcross pleaded guilty to conspiracy to commit computer and wire fraud, among other charges. Darden and Adam E. Grant, 22, of Atlanta were sentenced to 14-month prison terms, seven of which can be served in a halfway house. Grant pleaded guilty to possession of access codes with intent to defraud. U.S. District Judge Owen Forrester ordered the three to serve probation and perform community service after they serve their prison time. Riggs was charged with breaking into the Atlanta-based BellSouth Corp.'s 911 network covering Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi, Tennessee, Kentucky, Louisiana, North Carolina, South Carolina and Florida. The hacking between September 1987 and July 1989 did not produce a service disruption. The computer program was published in an electronic newsletter. ``He was involved in a quest for knowledge,'' said Darden's lawyer, Michael Hauptman. ``Frank was addicted to this world of computer doors ... put before him.'' Riggs was ordered to surrender to begin their sentences no earlier than Feb. 15. Darden and Grant were told to report Jan. 4, 1991.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 1st item to CORRECT that Nixon, not Johnson, was last president to visit front-line troops.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, leaving tonight on an eight-day trip to the Middle East and Europe, vows he will not plunge the United States into a Vietnam-like war ``that we cannot win'' in the Persian Gulf. ``There's not going to be any long drawn-out agony of Vietnam,'' Bush said Thursday in Cable News Network. He said the reason he is sending 200,000 more troops to Saudi Arabia was to demonstrate to Iraq's Saddam Hussein that ``we are deadly serious'' about demanding that he withdraw his troops from Kuwait aan interview on nd free all hostages. Bush also cautioned that Saddam is ``trying hard to get an atomic weapon.'' And he said the world will have to insist on international guarantees against further aggression by Iraq even if it pulls out of Kuwait. The president's hard-line remarks signaled anew that he is not in the mood to compromise with Baghdad over its invasion of Kuwait. On Thanksgiving Day, Bush will visit in the Saudi desert with troops who may be ordered to fight Iraqi forces. He will be the first U.S. president to visit front-line troops since Richard Nixon in Vietnam in 1969. ---=

DOC.HEAD: Radio Broadcasts Real People's Dramatic Moments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First name Boy in 7th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: Lita Belga hadn't heard from her husband in months. When she learned he was killed in a car accident in Saudi Arabia, she wept, and millions of other Filipinos wept with her. Mrs. Belga received news of her husband Benjamin's death in a telephone call to his Saudi employers, paid for and broadcast by private radio station DZRH as part of its program ``Around The World, With Love.'' The program, in its seventh year, features telephone conversations between Filipinos and relatives working abroad. It has become a real-life soap opera, a daily litany of money troubles, loneliness, death, and other family crises. Rey Langit, the host, said: ``The beauty of the program is the spontaneity. ... It is true-to-life drama unfolding right before you. It is both entertaining and educational.'' Most people who appear on the show cannot afford to pay for overseas calls themselves. ``You have not been sending money,'' Gloria Abalos said in a recent call to her husband Ernesto in Saudi Arabia. ``I will kill myself, that's what I'll do. ... I don't care how long you stay there as long as you send us money.'' With millions listening, relatives tried to muster the courage to tell Boy Santos, also working in Saudi Arabia, that his 4-year-old daughter had died. None would admit the girl was dead, but Santos figured out what they were trying to say. ``What have you done to my baby?'' he cried. ``You killed her!'' Potential callers come to the DZRH studios every morning to sign up. All except emergency cases are put on a waiting list two months long. Langit said the station makes little profit from the program because the calls are expensive. An average of six a day are made during the two-hour program, broadcast six days a week. ``The program is both a commitment and moral obligation to give good advice and help the poor with their problems,'' Langit said in an interview. ``They say they do not have hope in the government. They complain that government reaction is too slow and they come to us pleading and telling us that we are their only hope.'' Mrs. Belga turned to the station after being told by a Filipino who returned from Saudi Arabia that her husband was dead. Neither his employers nor the Philippine government had notified her. ``May I talk to my husband please?'' she asked the Saudi on the other end of the line in Riyadh. ``Dead, dead'' he muttered in Arabic. Eventually, another Filipino came to the telephone and confirmed the death. Many conversations are embarassingly candid. In one, a jealous husband in Saudi Arabia harangued his wife until Langit passed the telephone to their young daughter. ``Why are you angry at mother?'' the girl asked. ``Mother now has to wash clothes for other people just to feed us. She weeps day and night.'' After the daughter spoke, Langit scolded the husband about his family responsibilities. ``The success of that call was that I was able to instruct the guy to say `I love you' to his wife before he hung up,'' Langit boasted. Some calls have happy results. A 14-year-old girl asked the station to help find her father, who had abandoned his family and moved to the United States. ``We really wanted to help her, but how can we when the only clue she had of his whereabouts was that he worked at a restaurant in New York with huge glass panes in front?'' Langit said. Using a Manhattan hotel directory, the station began calling until they found the father working as a bartender under an assumed name. ``You don't know me, but I'm the child you abandoned,'' the girl said as the nation listened. ``You never sent us money and that is the reason why I have to sell flowers in the street and miss school.'' In a quivering voice, the father replied: ``It is my fault, my daughter. But you must understand that if I did not remarry here, I would not have survived.'' The girl now lives in the United States with her father, Langit said.

DOC.HEAD: Austria May Become East-West Middleman
DOC.TEXT: Austria, a neutral bridge between East and West during four decades of Cold War, is in an ideal position to be the middleman in a new age of political and economic cooperation. It seems predestined to act as interpreter of both Eastern needs and Western requirements for development. Herbert Krejci, general secretary of the conservative Federation of Industrialists, said Austria could use its historical experience to function as a ``transmission belt'' between the two halves of Europe. Austria once was an empire encompassing Hungary, Czechoslovakia and parts of Yugoslavia, Poland and Italy. Now it is a small republic of 7.6 million at the crossroad between East and West, with strong ties to both. Many Austrians have relatives in the East, or parents who grew up there, but their country has established itself as a Western democracy. It has a strong economy and applied in July 1989 for membership in the 12-nation European Community. ``Membership in the EC is a logical consequence of our geographic situation ... and the already existing strong economic ties between Austria and the EC,'' said Heinz Fischer, a Socialist Party legislator and speaker of Parliament. Krejci, a member of the conservative People's Party, said Austria ``belongs to this Western community.'' The Socialists are the senior partners in a coalition government with the conservative People's Party. Fischer sees Austria as the mediator with Western Europe for nations of the former Soviet bloc. ``However attractive the EC is for Budapest and Prague,'' he said, ``Frankfurt, London and Brussels will nevertheless be more foreign'' to them than Vienna. Jan Vit, a spokesman for the Czech regional government, was quoted by the Austrian newspaper Die Presse as saying there was a growing feeling of ``belonging together'' with Austria because of the common history. A former Hungarian premier, Andras Hegedus, said recently his country should seek its future in some form of alliance with other nations of the old Austro-Hungarian Empire. Vienna has long been a center for East-West trade and is likely to remain so. Poor facilities for communications and travel in Eastern Europe make it difficult to conduct business efficiently. Telephone, rail and road connections often are unreliable. IBM plans a computer information network connecting universities in the East, but Vienna is the hub. A major question in Austria is whether it needs to continue a neutral policy now that NATO and the Warsaw Pact no longer menace each other. Austria became neutral by tacit agreement after the withdrawal in 1955 of the occupying powers - the United States, Soviet Union, France and Britain. That neutrality, and Austria's position on the East-West divide, made it a logical meeting place for the two sides. Vienna has been the site of East-West arms talks since 1970, a two-year meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe was held in the Austrian capital and some U.N. agencies have their headquarters here. An official policy of neutrality could create problems with Austria's application for EC membership. Some EC officials have said neutrality might affect common stands on security. Fischer, the Parliament speaker, cautions against writing off neutrality just because East-West conflict appears to be over. ``One can't treat permanent neutrality like a share that one immediately considers selling when the prices rise,'' he said. Many Austrians say the policy already had been redefined, when the government gave permission for U.S. and British military planes carrying troops and supplies to the Persian Gulf to use Austrian airspace. Some feel the country must heed its past when reconsidering neutrality. As an ally of Germany in 1914 and part of it after annexation by Hitler in 1938, Austria was ``both initiator and accomplice in the most horrible wars of human history,'' said Johannes Voggenhuber, head of the Green-Alternative party. In the view of Krejci, the industrialist, EC membership could offset the danger of overdependence on Germany, Austria's leading trade partner. There was a surprising lack of emotional reaction to German unification in Austria, and state television did not provide extended live coverage of the event. The lack of emotion appeared to reflect Austria's sense of its own independent identity since World War II. Krejci explained the seeming indifference with a quote from former Chancellor Julius Raab: ``German is our mother tongue, but Austria is our mother country.''

DOC.HEAD: Thanksgiving Turkey Arrives Early on NBC
DOC.TEXT: It's easy to tell when a TV movie is written in Los Angeles. At times of crisis, the characters say things like, ``I can't believe this is happening!'' Or, ``This isn't happening!'' Indeed, in ``Thanksgiving Day,'' airing tonight on NBC, Mary Tyler Moore plays a freshly minted widow who gets grossed out by her oldest son's tasteless eulogy and mutters: ``Is this really happening?'' It is. It is part of what NBC calls an ``offbeat'' black comedy in which Max Schloss (Tony Curtis), a wealthy maker of industrial gloves in Detroit, dies at Thanksgiving dinner, his head falling into the turkey he's carving. This causes hunger, mourning and later crises that include veteran TV yeller Morton Downey Jr., briefly loose as a lech who is hot for Max's widow (Moore). He vomits into the bushes not once but twice when she says no dice. That is offbeat. But look at it this way: The script is by Steve Zacharias and Jeff Buhai, whose previous biggie was ``Revenge of the Nerds.'' On the bright side, the show includes a cameo appearance by Sonny Bono, who once sang half of ``I Got You, Babe.'' And it's actually fitfully funny. This is largely because of the valiantly deft direction by Gino Tanasescu and wonderful comic turns, first by Curtis in his too-brief stay, then by Joe Bologna as Ned Monk, a ruthless billionaire once engaged to the widow Schloss. And the show does get off to a good start. Its initial scenes have the sly, sardonic tone of a traditional Midwestern family reunion on Thanksgiving engineered by the maestro of Americana, Jean Shepherd. Alas, it starts sputtering after Max dies in midcarve and his industrial-glove empire is turned over to Randy (Jonathon Brandmeier), his divorced, womanizing, happy-go-lucky slob of an older son. The authors try to keep things lively. Randy, who has his two kids with him, still fights with his sister (Curtis' daughter, Kelly), just like old times. Only now she's a lesbian activist with, gasp, a lover. And there's a second Schloss son (try saying that rapidly), played by Andy Hirsh. His character, Michael, just watches TV. Well, that might be considered lively in Hollywood. Moving right along now, Randy, whose inherited business is rapidly going poof, would be very happy for the wealthy Monk to marry his mother. He even says: ``You ought to go out with my mom, Ned. ... She's got a great body.'' Little does he know that the evil mogul, still in love with the widow Schloss after 30 years, will resort to crushing the family's glove empire. The idea is to drive her into his arms to save her family (she broke off their first engagement due to what you might call a mother's love). All this unfolds with the aid of strained writing, one spoken crudity that would have had NBC censors shouting ``BINGO!'' in their glory days, and an inspiring moment when the sister threatens to drool on Randy's face. The fine silly bits scattered about usually go to Bologna. During a banquet honoring Ned for his aid to the homeless, for example, Ned declares himself pleased to give them ``a taste of what they need - nouvelle cuisine.'' Another worthy scene: Ned, wooing the widow, does it with a string quartet and serenades her by playing Mozart - on the bassoon. But the good times are frittered away by such things as a silly South Seas musical fantasy number involving Moore, or the family butler posing this question to another of Randy's sweeties, a dental hygienist: ``I've been flossing my teeth for three years, now. But let me ask you: Is it all right to eat the little food particles once you get 'em out from between your teeth?'' Too bad. NBC should have had the script tuned up by an old pro. An old pro is someone who knows that too much Truly Tasteless humor usually means the authors are film school students who graduated magna cum ``Porky's.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... THE SIMPSONS GET DOWN: Responding to public demand, maybe, the best-known of Fox's ``The Simpsons'' will make his singing debut Tuesday, when Geffen Records releases ``Do the Bartman.'' It's a single, part of the long-awaited ``The Simpsons Sing the Blues'' album that will be released on Dec. 6. At that time, Fox also will air a ``Do the Bartman'' music video - it runs just over five minutes - at the end of ``The Simpsons.''

DOC.HEAD: Hope and Fear Mix in Trade Deal With United States
DOC.TEXT: In a country where hawkers sell Coca-Cola beside monuments to martyrs of U.S. invasions, plans for a free-trade agreement with Mexico's powerful northern neighbor rouse both hope and dread. President Carlos Salinas de Gortari says free trade and a liberalized economy will help Mexico ``become a part of the first, not the Third World.'' He and President Bush are to meet in Monterrey, Mexico, on Nov. 27 to advance their plans for free trade. Formal negotiations are to start in the first half of 1991 and could be finished in two years. Mexican businessmen are eager to sell in a market 40 times larger than their own, but fear greater competition from richer American rivals. Labor leaders see a chance for new jobs and a risk of losing old ones. Intellectuals look upon free tradeas part of a reform pattern that is transforming Mexico, turning it from government control to a freer market. A country that has struggled for decades to remain apart from the colossus across the Rio Grande now is on the verge of embracing it. ``We are at the end of the Mexican Revolution ... or at least we are at the end of the identity of the national state with Mexican Revolution,'' said Francisco Valdes, a political scientist. Canada may join the talks, which could lead to a North American free-trade zone of 350 million people. For decades, Mexican industry hid behind high tariff walls that made legally imported goods unavailable or extremely expensive. The resulting lack of competition often led to inefficient local companies producing shoddy goods. Opening the gates to better and cheaper products from the north has some managements wondering if they can survive. The Mexican decision to join the tariff-lowering General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade exposed some industries to serious foreign cometition for the first time. Businessmen like Viktor Miklis, president of the National Chamber of the Clothing Industry, are excited by access to the U.S. market. He told journalists imports had captured 30 percent of the domestic market because of tariff cuts but that Mexico could vastly increase exports to the United States, which now gets less than 3 percent of its imported clothing from this country. ``These new treaties ... just as they could be very beneficial, they could be damaging if we don't think about them and if we are not prepared,'' he said. His organization and other groups opened a Design and Style Center this year to help Mexican companies track international fashions they once could ignore, and to offer computerized design and cutting services. ``This is state of the art,'' said the center's technical director, Robert Demmer, who returned to Mexico from the New York City garment district to help run the center. ``You can't find anything better than this.'' He showed off U.S.-made computer terminals that plot clothing designs and patterns, and guide a machine that slices through 50 to 200 pieces of fabric at a time. Miklis and Demmer say they hope such know-how will help keep Mexico from being a sweatshop that assembles imported parts in foreign-owned factories. If Mexican businessmen can't keep up, ``you'll have Japanese people coming in here and setting up a plant with their own manager and methods, and we're going to be cleaning and sweeping and doing the crappy work once again,'' Demmer said. ``Mexicans don't want to be in the trade agreement only because of cheap labor.'' Mexico's minimum wage of $3.40 to $4.10 a day, depending on the area, lures many foreign investors. Most business leaders and economists say, however, that free trade should push wages up by creating competition for more skilled and productive workers. In his annual State of the Nation speech this month, Salinas said Mexico would suffer ``stagnation, technological backwardness, social tension and finally national weakness - in other words, effective loss of sovereignty'' if it did not join the world economy. Mexico City newspapers carry daily stories about the trade agreement even though no details are known. Many critics express fear that Mexico will swap its independence for foreign investment. ``We are removing all of our traditional outlooks ... to arrive at a national surrender, which is the plan for negotiating a free-trade treaty,'' political scientist Alfonso Aguilar said at a seminar on global political change. Valdes, a researcher at the National Autonomous University of Mexico, said increased integration of the U.S. and Mexican economies is inevitable, but ``the problem is how it is negotiated.'' He complained that little information about the forthcoming treaty was available, and said Mexico has a poor record of negotiating. Mexico is bargaining from weakness, Valdes said, and ``the United States has a tendency to take advantage of the weak.'' Many Mexicans say U.S. companies already operating in Mexico ignore safety and environmental standards they would have to meet in the United States. ``What Mexico is selling, perversely, is a country without regulations,'' Aguilar said, but added that a free-trade agreement treaty would pressure business to meet U.S. standards. Noting that Mexico's prosperity and stability is important to the United States, Miklis gave U.S. companies a message: ``Join us, don't use us.''

DOC.HEAD: Airline Near Misses, Claims Against Drexel
DOC.TEXT: They could have become statistics in the predicted shakeout of the nation's airline industry, but Eastern Airlines and Pan Am Corp. are still here. For the time being anyway. The two carriers, among the weakest in an industry burdened by rising fuel costs, signed new leases on life this past week - one in bankruptcy court, the other in the boardroom. Both deals went down within minutes of each other late Wednesday night. Eastern, operating under bankruptcy court supervision, persuaded Judge Burton R. Lifland to release cash from an escrow account and reject a creditors' request to liquidate the airline. Pan Am, weighed down by heavy operating losses, completed the sale of trans-Atlantic routes to stronger rival UAL Corp. that will bring in $400 million and set the stage for joint marketing efforts by the two carriers. Rejuvenation was far from assured in either case. Eastern only got half of a requested $30 million from the escrow account and could hit another financial flash point within weeks. Pan Am, meanwhile, must develop a plan for succeeding as a smaller carrier. It hinted at a worst case scenario Thursday, announcing that in the unlikely event it stopped flying, UAL would honor up to $100 million of Pan Am tickets. Both Eastern and Pan Am faced a tough climb against the same economic conditions that drove them to their separate fates. Fuel prices have risen relentlessly since the Persian Gulf crisis began in August, and air travel has become a victim of the nationwide economic downturn. Observers were most skeptical of Eastern's chances, since it is trying to rebuild its customer base by attracting first-class business at coach fares. Creditors of the airline argued that strategy was hopeless. Eastern trustee Martin R. Shugrue Jr., who has been running the airline since Frank Lorenzo was ousted in April, was unbowed by the challenge, although he had to admit Eastern's reputation was damaged by the creditors' push for liquidation. ``Their actions in public and in the media are nothing short of reckless and shameful,'' he said after the bankruptcy court ordeal. The nine-hour bankruptcy hearing Wednesday had attracted legions of reporters, photographers and television film crews who had put the Eastern story on the back burner the past few months.
DOC.HEAD: CRIME BEAT: Drexel Faces Huge Claims, Milken Begs for Mercy
DOC.TEXT: In another bankruptcy drama, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was hit with billions of dollars worth of claims from the government and private investors allegedly defrauded by the investment firm. The biggest bombshell hit Wednesday when government thrift regulators filed claims seeking $11.3 billion. Total claims from all those who say they were defrauded could approach $30 billion, far more than what's left to be doled out by Drexel in its Chapter 11 reorganization. Lawyers are negotiating how much Drexel will set aside to pay all the claims. It only has about $3 billion in assets, plus various investments, and a long list of other creditors waiting to be paid. Most fraud claims are related to Drexel's 1989 guilty plea to six felony counts of illegal trading. The thrift regulators laid some of the blame for the &L crisis at Drexel's door, alleging that the firm ran a corrupt junk-bond network that helped ruin dozens of savings and loans. Drexel's junk-bond ace, Michael Milken, facing a criminal sentencing in federal district court Wednesday, asked Judge Kimba Wood to show him mercy. In an 11-page letter to the judge, Milken admitted he broke the law but said he feared prison and hoped to be sentenced to community service. In one revealing passage from the letter, he told the judge of his emotional reaction to the motion picture ``Field of Dreams,'' in which an Iowa farmer has a mystical reunion with his dead father, who returns to play baseball on a diamond the farmer has hewn from a cornfield. ``I found myself wondering what I would be saying to my father if he was alive today?'' Milken wrote. In a signal of what could be in store for Milken, Judge Miriam Cedarbaum gave John A. Mulheren Jr. a year's worth of prison time and a $1.68 million fine on a stock manipulation conviction. The judge said the former friend of Wall Street felon Ivan Boesky deserved jail because he tampered with ``the integrity of the stock market.''
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: Trump Faces the Music, Icahn Stirring
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump was pressured by his junk bondholders to put the ``eighth wonder of the world'' - the Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City - into bankruptcy after his missed a deadline for a $47.3 million interest payment. But the so-called ``prepackaged'' bankruptcy would theoretically last only a matter of weeks while Trump and the bondholders work out a new payment schedule on $675 million worth of junk. Trump put a positive spin on the episode, but it erected still another hurdle for the developer-casino baron, who has junk bonds outstanding on all three of his gaming establishments and owes $2 billion to banks. One of Trump's interested bondholders was investor Carl Icahn, whose influence in the negotiations with Trump was hard to measure. But Icahn was making news on two other fronts, with a bid to buy Pan Am and fresh demands for USX Corp. The Pan Am idea fizzled quickly, since it was only a backup for the ultimately successful deal between Pan Am and UAL. But USX faced continuing pressure from Icahn, who is the energy and steel company's biggest shareholder. In a letter to USX chairman Charles Corry, Icahn praised the company's plans to transfer its steel operations to a separate subsidiary, but he reiterated his threat to seek seats on the board unless USX pursued a major restructuring. Icahn would like to see the steel business sold off and the proceeds distributed to shareholders. Elsewhere, Dallas investor Harold Simmons was stirring, updating a play for defense giant Lockheed Corp. Simmons, rebuffed in a previous attempt to increase his 20 percent stake in the company, offered to take it private in a $2 billion deal if Lockheed put up half the cash. The company responded cautiously and market reaction was lukewarm.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Inflation Numbers Encouraging
DOC.TEXT: The latest batch of inflation numbers from the government were high, but nevertheless encouraging. Overall, consumer prices were up 0.6 percent in October, following jumps of 0.8 percent in each of the previous two months. But analysts pointed out that the core rate of inflation - minus products related to oil - was a more moderate 0.3 percent.
DOC.HEAD: COMPANIES: Fat-Free Big Macs
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's continued its recent pro-consumer initiatives, announcing test-marketing of a hamburger, in which most of the fat is replaced by a combination of water and a seaweed-based additive. The Lean Deluxe burger follows earlier tests of low-fat fries, shakes and breakfast foods. Just two weeks ago, the company also said it would eliminate the environmentally threatening foam boxes cradling Big Macs and other sandwiches.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Nov. 17-18

DOC.HEAD: Profit Picture Keeps Getting Bleaker
DOC.TEXT: For stock-market investors looking for relief from a steady barrage of recession news, the picture presented by corporate profits offers scant encouragement right now. More than a year after earnings at many businesses started to slump, Wall Street analysts are still busy cutting their profit estimates for 1990, and 1991 as well. The stock market, meanwhile, has been demonstrating that it is still vulnerable to disappointments on the bottom line. The latest gloomy message came via long-distance telephone, when MCI Communications, one of the stalwarts of the over-the-counter market, announced a restructuring plan. The company said the costs of the changes it would be making, plus intense competition, loomed as a drag on earnings ``for the next several quarters.'' The ensuing selling pressure on MCI spread to stocks of other companies in the long-distance phone business - including American Telephone & Telegraph, with its 2.5 million-plus shareholders, and United Telecommunications and GTE, the two owners of U.S. Sprint Communications. AT&T's assertion that its long-distance business remained strong did little to calm investors. The MCI problem, of course, concerned a specific company in a specific business. But it also echoed a broader theme. ``The outlook for corporate profits is dismal,'' said Suresh Bhirud at Oppenheimer & Co. in his latest appraisal of the stock-market outlook. ``Technical rallies notwithstanding, the fundamentals remain largely negative for the stock market. In our opinion, even at current levels the market is still somewhat overvalued.'' With most of the figures in for the quarter that ended Sept. 30, Melissa Brown at Prudential-Bache Securities calculated that overall corporate profits were down about 5.3 percent from the third quarter of 1989. ``The results are particularly disturbing when one recalls that the third quarter of 1989 was a weak quarter for many industries,'' she said. That left the Street with no sign of break in a lengthening trend. ``Profits have been falling sharply but not steadily since the end of 1988,'' noted the economists David Levy and S. Jay Levy in their advisory letter Industry Forecast. ``They will slide in the current quarter and continue to fall in the first half of 1991.'' But with all the short-term pain that goes with this, Wall Street's optimists still see prospects for longer-term gain. Historically, they point out, down cycles in the stock market reverse well before corporate profits bottom out. This kind of willingness to ``look across the valley'' was evident in the stock market during the past week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 61.64 points to 2,550.25. The New York Stock Exchange composite index chimed in with a 2.13 gain at 173.30; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 8.90 to 350.85, and the American Stock Exchange market value index was up 6.49 at 297.52. Volume on the Big Board averaged 163.55 million shares a day, up from 147.70 million the week before. ``To our mind, the investment outlook is improving,'' maintains Michael Sherman at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``We believe that interest rates, both short and long, are ultimately going to be sharply lower,'' he said. ``The decade-long credit expansion that was spawned by excesses in leveraged buyouts, junk bonds and huge overinvestments in commercial real estate has come to an end. ``In its wake will be sharply reduced credit demand and sharply lower interest rates as savers push their funds toward existing financial assets.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Nov. 17-18

DOC.TEXT: Government regulators for the first time have laid much of the blame for the savings and loan industry collapse on the junk bond dealings of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. In a 60-page legal claim, federal thrift regulators accuse the failed investment firm of bribery, fraud, market manipulation and other serious crimes they allege hastened the demise of 48 savings and loan institutions. The claim, which seeks $11.3 billion on behalf the thrifts, was released Thursday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Business inventories grew 0.5 percent in September, the government said, leading some analysts to express concern the buildup could lead to further production cuts and loss of jobs. Economist Evelina Tainer of the First National Bank of Chicago noted Thursday that industrial production in October already dropped 0.8 percent, its sharpest cutback in nine months. ``It's consistent with the idea that the economy is sliding into a recession and growth will be negative in the fourth quarter,'' she said. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - MCI Communications Corp. said as many as 1,500 workers may be laid off in the next six months as the company restructures its operations because of competition and ``changing economic conditions.'' MCI, the nation's second largest long-distance telephone company behind AT&T, employs about 25,000 people. It said Thursday the 1,500 layoffs would be spread around the nation. --- SYDNEY, Australia (AP) - Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd., currently negotiating with banks over debt relief, reported a 31.3 percent decline in its operating profit after taxes for the first quarter. The results, reported Thursday, came as the international media company talks with bankers about allowing more time to repay billions of dollars in debt due within the next three years. Murdoch, chief executive of News Corp., was scheduled to meet with bankers in London. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Jurors have ordered Lockheed Corp. to pay $45.3 million in damages to three former employees who claimed they were wrongfully fired for questioning the safety of the giant C-5B military cargo plane. Lockheed will try to have the award reduced or overturned, company vice president Joseph G. Twomey said in a statement following the Thursday order. The plaintiffs asserted that four C-5Bs built with defective mainframes continue to fly and are currently transporting troops to Saudi Arabia, said Herbert Hafif, lawyer for two of the whistleblowers. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The Bush administration is considering cuts in popular government benefit programs such as Social Security and Medicare as part of the budget it will submit to Congress in February, an administration official said. The official, who spoke Thursday on the condition his name not be used, said the cuts being considered would reduce benefits for affluent recipients with the savings used to provide tax cuts to the poor and middle class. Such an action ``is clearly being contemplated very seriously,'' said the official, who also stressed that all planning for the new budget was in a very preliminary stage with final decisions a long way from being made. --- SUNNYVALE, Calif. (AP) - Reeling from a $17.8 million loss in the third quarter, Advanced Micro Devices is laying off about 200 employees to cut costs, the company announced. ``Intense global competition dictates that we make a number of difficult decisions to improve productivity,'' Richard Previte, president and chief operating officer of the electronic equipment manufacturer, said Thursday. The layoffs are in the sales, general and administrative departments both in the United States and overseas, said a company spokesman. AMD employs more than 12,000 people. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe will drive down prices for food and energy worldwide, an international panel of experts predicted. Increased grain production will end the common farm policy that has helped keep prices high in the 12-nation European Community and elsewhere, said L. Alan Winters of the University of Birmingham in Britain, a panel member. The report, released on Thursday, said the biggest drop in food prices would come in grain and dairy products. --- CHERRY HILL, N.J. (AP) - Campbell Soup Co. said higher sales and a worldwide reorganization boosted first-quarter earnings 28 percent for the best quarter in the company's history. For the three months ended Oct. 28, net earnings climbed to $105.1 million, or 82 cents a share, on sales of $1.6 billion, the company said Thursday. In the first quarter last year, earnings were $83 million, or 64 cents a share, on revenues of $1.5 billion. ---

The stock market suffered a moderate setback Thursday, giving up some of the gains recorded in its rally since mid-October. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 14.60 to 2,545.05. Bond prices eased. The dollar inched higher. Gold prices fell overseas but advanced domestically. Wheat prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, plunging to near contract lows. Crude oil prices finished slightly lower after see-sawing in brisk trading in the absence of significant news from the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Outlook: Cost-Cutting, Mergers, Stiff Competition
DOC.TEXT: The 1980s were a decade of expansion on Wall Street. The 1990s promise to be just the opposite. Moody's Investors Service said in its annual report on the securities industry that Wall Street faces weak profits and more consolidation through the end of the century as bad times erase happy memories of a decade of growth. Big companies will continue to take over and bail out weakening securities firms, but some nonetheless will go under, Moody's said. Competition will increase as banks push into the industry and foreign firms threaten U.S. turf. Firms across the board face cost-cutting pressures, Moody's said. Likely targets for reductions are reducing the ballooned compensation of the 1980s, eliminating whole businesses and exiting from unprofitable foreign markets. ``The 1980s goal of becoming a global player in a broad range of products is fading for many firms,'' Moody's said in its report, released Thursday. ``Managements are refocusing on core business in which they can build sustainable competitive advantages.'' Moody's said Wall Street firms' overhead expenses at the end of 1989 quadrupled from their 1980 level to $57.7 billion. The companies' aggregate pretax earnings last year were $1.8 billion, slightly lower than in 1980. The industry has struggled since the October 1987 stock market crash. More than 45,000 jobs have been erased and the key business lines of investment banking, leveraged buyouts, and mergers and acquisitions have nosedived. ``The outlook now is that those three areas will be much, much smaller and in some cases nonexistent,'' said Moody's vice president Christopher Mahoney, who helped prepare the report. ``The Street was subsidizing a lot of growth domestically and internationally from lucrative businesses that are drying up or diminishing,'' he said. Moody's predicted further consolidation leading to domination by firms created through acquisition by wealthy companies. ``Ultimately there may be few, if any, large independent Wall Street securities firms,'' the report said. The report said that overcapacity in the industry ``will take years to reduce, and will put fundamental downward pressure on securities firms' returns.'' The power of diversified, strong owners has been a theme of the industry's woes this year, in which several major securities firms have been bailed out of severe financial difficulty by deep-pocketed parents. Most recently, CS First Boston Inc. this week received a $300 million equity infusion from its Swiss parent, CS Holding, which took majority control of the investment banking firm. CS First Boston's main U.S. subsidiary is First Boston Corp. Mahoney said a problem with the trend is that the survival of the fittest is thrown on its head. Wall Street's failed firms used to be acquired by the successful ones. ``One impediment to that now is that a lot of weak firms are owned by strong parents, so they don't die a natural death,'' Mahoney said. ``They're not absorbed by strong firms; they're maintained as independent entities.'' The Moody's report said intense competition, continued overcapacity and the decline in major business segments mean weak prospects for profitability on Wall Street through the end of the century. ``Additional risks are the temptation for managements to ease profit pressure by taking greater risks, and the likelihood of more aggressive involvement in U.S. and overseas securities markets by powerful foreign securities firms and banks,'' Moody's said. The report also cited a recent erosion of the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act that prevented commercial banks from entering the securities industry. It said several U.S. bank-holding companies, including J.P. Morgan, Citicorp and Bankers Trust, ``are eager to expand further into the securities business, and they pose important competitive threats to U.S. securities firms.'' A similar trend is occurring in Japan, Moody's said, increasing the challenge to U.S. firms' core businesses and markets.

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims Move S&L Crisis To New Level
With PM-Drexel-List
DOC.TEXT: Government regulators for the first time have laid much of the blame for the savings and loan industry collapse on the junk bond dealings of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. In a 60-page legal claim, federal thrift regulators accuse the failed investment firm of bribery, fraud, market manipulation and other serious crimes they allege hastened the demise of 48 savings and loan institutions. The claim, which seeks $11.3 billion on behalf the thrifts, was released Thursday. A federal bankruptcy judge denied the government more time to investigate Drexel's junk bond dealings with other savings and loans. Sackfuls of claims by investors, companies, former employees and other parties against Drexel arrived at U.S. Bankruptcy Court to meet a Thursday deadline. Lawyers said total litigation claims would exceed $20 billion. Drexel has only about $3 billion in assets, plus a portfolio of investments, which won't come close to meeting the legal claims and those of secured creditors, those who definitely are entitled to money in the bankruptcy case. Attorneys for Drexel, investors and the government agencies are negotiating to establish an estimate of how much the firm will set aside to pay the litigation claims. That figure would have to be approved by a federal judge. The charges by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Resolution Trust Corp. are the most detailed yet by the government in the S&L collapse, which is expected to cost taxpayers $500 billion over the next 30 years. Thrift industry analysts said that without judging whether Drexel broke the law, blaming the firm for the industry's failure was excessive. Drexel managed most of the $15 billion in high-risk, high-yield bonds bought by thrifts in the 1980s. ``The fact is junk bonds played a very small role overall, but it's an area the S&Ls shouldn't have been in at all in the first place,'' said Kenneth H. Thomas, a Miami consultant who has studied the portfolios of failed thrifts. Thomas estimates that total thrift junk bond losses could hit $7 billion. Drexel controlled a network of thrifts that invested billions of dollars of federally insured money in the securities, some of it swapped among the S&Ls. When the market collapsed a year ago, much of the holdings was wiped out. The sweeping allegations describe a market rigged by Drexel in concert with thrift executives. The FDIC and RTC allege Drexel gave the junk market the appearance of liquidity by fixing prices, mandating who would buy which securities and providing investment opportunities to favored customers. Thrift executives were induced to buy and sell the bonds at Drexel's behest, ``to share in the plunder of their own institutions and to obtain other benefits - including assistance in evading regulatory discipline of their S&L,'' the agencies said. Other thrifts were victims of alleged fraud and conspiracy, the agencies claim. The firm and its co-conspirators also ran an ``extensive propaganda campaign'' to mislead the public about junk bonds, the filing states. The allegations are likely to be challenged in court, and several creditors and outside observers complained that the government - which was responsible for regulating the savings and loans - was ignoring its own role in the thrift debacle. ``The FDIC monitored the operations of all these thrifts while they were in business and did not take any steps to stop it while the actual conduct was going on,'' said Barry Dichter, attorney for one of Drexel's largest creditors. Nonetheless, the FDIC and RTC detail alleged securities price manipulation, secret ``parking'' arrangements, bogus transactions, payoffs, loans among members of the junk network and rampant violation of federal disclosure laws. In total, the agencies seek $6.8 billion in damages for junk bond and other frauds. They also want another $4.5 billion on behalf of Columbia Savings & Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., which has not yet been taken over by the government. Among the allegations: -Drexel helped CenTrust Bank Chairman David Paul skirt Florida laws by falsifying records about the thrift's purchase of more than $1 billion in securities. Paul also is accused of illegally holding millions of shares of securities for Drexel. -Drexel, through a series of investments with associates, helped install a new management of Imperial Savings Association of San Diego, which then became a major purchaser of Drexel-issued junk bonds. Imperial in one year increased its junk bond investments from $1 million to $1 billion. The thrift has lost $56 million on sales of Drexel junk bonds. -Drexel enabled now-indicted financier Charles Keating to gain control of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and gave him stock kickbacks in exchange for huge Linoln investments in Drexel-underwritten junk bonds, some in major takeover deals of the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: United Will Guarantee Pan Am Tickets If Pan Am Stops Flying
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines' parent company has agreed to honor up to $100 million of Pan Am Corp.'s tickets at face value if the troubled airline should stop flying. Cash-strapped Pan Am insisted it was not trying to signal any pending problems. Pan Am said that the unusual guarantee was being offered in an effort to calm any fears that the current sluggish economy could leave anyone holding worthless tickets. ``We recognize that our financial condition has been weakened and certainly the current fuel situation is having a negative impact on the company's finances,'' Pan Am spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said Thursday. Hanlon was unaware of any similar guarantees ever taking place in the air travel industry. The arrangement is part of a marketing agreement struck by the rival carriers in a $400 million deal that gives United Airlines five coveted London routes that had been some of the most prized possessions of Pan Am. In the marketing pact, the two carriers also agreed to coordinate some flights in an effort to feed passengers to one another. Pan Am and UAL signed the deal late Wednesday night after first announcing it in October. UAL is also getting additional routes; Pan Am's facilities at San Francisco International Airport, Washington's Dulles Airport and London's Heathrow Airport; two Boeing 747s; two spare engines; and spare parts. In a statement outlining the details, Pan Am said Thursday evening that ``United will redeem up to $100 million face value of Pan Am tickets for travel on United if Pan Am were to cease its air transportation operations.'' Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett said, ``The customer protection guarantee program is yet another demonstration of Pan Am's and United's commitment to the traveling public.'' Hanlon said the ticket guarantee ``isn't intended to raise suggestions that we would stop flying. But it should certainly alleviate any travel agency or consumer fears that travelers would be left with worthless tickets if indeed the carrier ever did stop flying. There is certainly no plan or intention to stop operations.'' Pan Am was merely trying to calm any travelers who are concerned about the overall health of the air travel industry, which has been rocked by soaring fuel prices and the sluggish U.S. economy. Industry executives predict the airlines will lose up to $2 billion in 1990. Asked for the face value of Pan Am's tickets that are currently outstanding, Hanlon said those figures are not made public. United issued a statement on the marketing agreement that said it will ``honor up to $100 million in Pan Am tickets should the carrier cease operation.''

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Narrows in September
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. merchandise trade deficit narrowed 3.3 percent to $9.4 billion in September, the first improvement since June, the government reported today. But petroleum imports were at their highest level in nine years because of escalating costs due to the Persian Gulf crisis. The Commerce Department said imports dropped 2.4 percent to $41.3 billion despite a huge 28.5 percent jump in petroleum imports. But exports also fell, down 2.2 percent to $31.8 billion. The deficit is the difference between the two. The cost of imported oil rose to $6.2 billion as the price per barrel shot ahead 24.4 percent to $24.31. Volume increased 6.7 percent to 8.5 million barrels a day. It was the largest oil bill since October 1981 when it rose to $6.3 billion. The price per barrel then was $32.50. The September deficit pushed the gap to a seasonally adjusted rate of $99.1 billion for the first nine months of the year. The deficit peaked at $152 billion in 1987 and the fell to $118.53 billion in 1988 and to $109.40 billion last year. Before the Persian Gulf crisis pumped up oil prices, government officials and economists believed the gap would fall below $100 billion for the first time since 1983. Bush administration officials still view exports as one of the few nets available to keep the economy from falling into - or too far into - a recession. It has accounted in recent years for a third of the nation's economic growth. Consumer spending, the other two-thirds, has been fading recently in the face of adverse economic news acerbated by the Persian Gulf crisis. Some officials hope that a weaker dollar will help prop up exports by making U.S. products less expensive overseas. At the same time, they say, a cheaper dollar will make imports more expensive and thus less attractive to Americans. Excluding oil products, the deficit totaled $3.8 billion, down $1.2 billion from the August non-oil gap. The government contends this is a better measure of the nation's overseas competitiveness. The price of oil was driven up when Iraq stormed Kuwait on Aug. 2 and disrupted world markets. In the month that followed, the cost of oil imports jumped 20.9 percent to $4.8 billion although volume also dropped. Economist Michael P. Niemira of the Mitsubishi Bank in New York said in advance of the report that the Persian Gulf crisis also had an effect on exports. ``Exports transported by air during September again were disrupted by the military operation in the Middle East'' when some domestic air cargo companies that usually haul shipments overseas were diverted to transport military goods, he wrote in the bank's Weekly Economic Indicator Report. Imports of foreign-made cars declined 4.2 percent in September. Imports of capital goods and consumer goods also fell, while industrial supplies increased. The decline in exports was widespread except for capital goods, which rose fractionally. The biggest deficit continued to be with Japan - a $3.05 billion imbalance, down from $3.78 billion in August. Other deficits included Taiwan, $1.03 billion; China $1.07 billion; Canada, $1.25 billion; South Korea, $406 million; Hong Kong, $231 million; and Brazil, $105 million. The United States posted a $882 million surplus in its trade with Western Europe after a $374 million imbalance a month earlier.

DOC.HEAD: MCI Eliminating 1,500 Jobs Through Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: MCI Communications Corp., the nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company, cited weak economic conditions and increased competition in announcing that it may lay off as many as 1,500 workers over the next six months. Company officials said it was too early to say where the layoffs would occur. According to plans announced Thursday, MCI will fold its seven domestic divisions into four and create two new units to deal with network services and consumer markets. President Bert C. Roberts Jr. said the slowing economy, the costs of changing the company's structure and the costs of a recent $1.25 billion acquisition ``are negative constraints on the company's financial performance for the next several quarters.'' MCI, based in Washington, has seen its expansion slow to a crawl as market leader American Telephone & Telegraph Co. has moved to recapture market share. The expansion of the long-distance market has also faltered because of the economic downturn. Roberts said if current trends continue, MCI's revenue growth would ``flat'' for the quarter, compared to the previous quarter. Analyst Geoff Johnson, with Argus Research of New York, said long-distance calling has slowed significantly because customers are cutting back on the number and length of calls. He said the trend was expected to continue. MCI spokesman Bernard Goodrich called the 1,500 job losses ``really kind of slim'' given that the company has about 25,000 workers. MCI had revenues in 1989 of $6.5 billion. In July, the Federal Communications Commission approved MCI's merger with Telecom USA Inc., the fourth largest U.S. long distance company.

The stock market advanced early today, encouraged by government reports showing that inflation, excluding food and energy prices, moderated in October. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 9.41 at 2,554.46 in the first half hour of trading. Volume on the Big Board came to 23 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by more than 3 to 1 with 712 issues up, 289 down and 409 unchanged. The Labor Department said that the nation's core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, advanced a moderate 0.3 percent last month. The report supported stock prices and made for a firm opening, said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. The Consumer Price Index ``was definitely encouraging,'' he said. ``It suggests that if you subtract oil, inflationary pressures are easing.'' The report pushed bond prices higher - moving interest rates lower in tandem - and that helped the stock market, Metz said. Separately, the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit narrowed 3.3 percent in September, the first improvement since June. Among actively traded Big Board issues, IBM was up ] at 113; Ford was off } at 27{; AT&T lost ~ at 32\, and International Paper was up ] at 49|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.71 at 173.83. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index gained 0.28 to 296.97. On Thursday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 14.60 to 2,545.05. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2 on the NYSE, with 593 up, 899 down and 478 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 151.37 million shares, against 179.31 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Strike By Traders Halts Stock Trading
DOC.TEXT: A strike by floor traders protesting a proposed capital gains tax halted stock trading in Italy on Friday. Picket lines went up outside the Milan exchange, Italy's largest, and trading was also blocked in Rome and the other small stock exchanges in the country. The union said the strike will continue until at least Wednesday, when the Finance Commitee of the Chamber of Deputies has agreed to hear their grievances. The traders say the proposed 30 percent tax on capital gains will discourage investors. They also charge that the government has been slow in implementing long-pending legislation aimed at modernizing the bourse in order to keep it competitive with other international stock markets.

DOC.HEAD: General Dynamics Division To Cut Work Force By Up To 15 Percent
DOC.TEXT: General Dynamics' Electronics division plans to cut the unit's union-represented work force by up to 15 percent in January, labor officials said. General Dynamics also said it will lay off 61 Convair machinists, effective Jan. 12, and has notified labor representatives that more of the division's employees may be laid off after the first of the year. The company told the International Association of Machinists - which represents almost 6,000 workers at the company's San Diego divisions - in a letter earlier this month that the Electronics division employees would be laid off effective Jan. 28, IAM District Lodge 50 president Ed Maudlin said Thursday. Company spokesman Jack Isabel acknowledged that ``it is possible that we will make staff adjustments before the end of the year.'' ``If there is a work adjustment, notices will be given after Thanksgiving and will be effective after the holidays,'' Isabel said. However, he declined to comment on the number of workers who could be lad off, or the divisions that would be affected. The San Diego divisions employ 17,900 people. The announcement comes as aerospace firms from San Diego to Seattle are paring payrolls in an effort to blunt the effects of defense cutbacks. Union officials said a 15 percent reduction in the Electronics division would put about 120 machinists out of work. Approximately 800 of the unit's 2,900 employees are represented by IAM. ``There aren't too many jobs out there right now,'' Maudlin said. ``The picture really isn't that bright.'' The layoff notice came less than four months after General Dynamics reported a $240 million loss due to cost overruns on contracts to build the A-12 navy bomber and field radios for the Army. The two programs resulted in a $500 million one-time charge against second-quarter earnings, the largest in company history. The Electronics division, which was awarded the Army radio contract two years ago, opened a new facility in Tallahassee, Fla. to manufacture 265,000 of the hand-held devices. However, company officials said production of the Single Channel Ground and Airborne Radio System was more complex than anticipated, resulting in the overrun.

DOC.HEAD: Fixed Mortgage Rates Fall, Adjustables Rise
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.02 percent this week, down from 10.09 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It was the lowest rate since Aug. 3, when it averaged 9.84 percent. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.11 percent, up from 8.09 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: New Law Will Take Years to Show Effects
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 5-6 on other bills signed. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's signing of a toughened clean air law begins a new era in the fight to rid the country of its dirtiest air, but it will still take years to produce noticeably clearer skies. ``Every city in America should have clean air, and with this legislation, I firmly believe we will,'' the president declared Thursday as he signed the 748-page bill aimed at cutting air pollution dramatically over the next 15 years. As a result of the tougher pollution controls, Bush said, 100 cities now choking in smog will have cleaner air by the year 2000 and annually 56 billion pounds of pollution - 224 pounds for every man, woman and child - will disappear from the atmosphere. Acid rain will be significantly curtailed, as will toxic chemical releases from factories, he said. ``It is simply the most significant air pollution legislation in our nation's history,'' inaugurating a ``new era for clean air,'' Bush said. Today the president signed eight more bills on environmental issues. They include measures to ban U.S. minerals exploration in Antarctica until Congress approves a new international compact; designate the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary off the Florida Keys; establish national wildlife refuges in Bayou Cocodrie in Louisiana and New Jersey's Walkill River; designate the Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area in Nevada's Mojave Desert; and triple the size of the Coastal Barrier Resource System. He also signed bills to award teachers grants for environmental education; fund further research on global warning; and foster cleanup in the Great Lakes and Lake Champlain. Over the next decade, automobiles must emit 40 to 60 percent less pollution; industrial plants must cut toxic air emissions by 90 percent; the oil industry must supply cleaner-burning gasoline in cities with the worst smog, and coal-burning electric plants will have to cut in half their emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain. Environmentalists, although praising Bush and lauding the new law, expressed concern over hether the provisions will be aggressively implemented and enforced. Some suggested that polluters, a few of whom already are complaining that some of the new requirements cannot be met, will seek to water down the law as the Environmental Protection Agency writes the regulations to implement it. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., a key architect of the legislation and chairman of the Senate's subcommittee on environmental protection, said ``now it's a matter of oversight and making sure it works.'' EPA Administrator William Reilly said the agency has already begun to hire several hundred additional employees to deal with the new regulations and said he has no doubts the law will be administered aggressively. ``Its the most ambitious law that EPA has ever administered,'' said Reilly. ``We recognize how ambitious it is. ... I believe we're up to the challenge.'' The EPA anticipates issuing at least 27 major new regulations under the clean air law over the next two years. Eventually more than 2,000 people will be involved in administering clean air regulations, officials said. William Rosenberg, the EPA associate administrator who will oversee those regulations, said the task of cleaning up the air will be a decade-long effort. ``It's not going to happen overnight, but we should see some progress in a couple of years,'' he said. Most of the bill's major provisions do not take effect fully until the end of the decade. Many cities will have 10 to 15 years to meet federal air quality standards. Richard Ayres, executive director of the Clean Air Coalition, said that ``in every respect this bill is an advance over today's law'' but maintained that its effectiveness will depend on how the requirements are implemented and enforced. ``The tools are in the president's hands,'' and regulations can be either pursued aggressively or in a halfhearted manner, said Ayres, also an attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council. ``If George Bush succumbs to polluter pressure to emasculate the Clean Air Act with ineffective regulations, Americans will never breathe the clean air their president has promised them,'' said Ruth Caplan, executive director of Environmental Action. Environmentalists noted that the original clean air law, enacted in 1970, directed that cities achieve smog-free, healthy air by 1987. Last year, 96 cities had yet to meet those requirements. The 1970 law called on utilities to achieve cleaner air by curtailing chemical emissions. A few years later, the utilities received permission to meet the requirements by sending the pollutants high into the air through tall smokestacks. Sulfur dioxide from those Midwestern smokestacks later were found to be responsible for the acid rain that has damaged lakes and aquatic life in the Northeast.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans, Corn Higher, Wheat Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Wheat and corn prices opened mostly higher today on the Chicago Board of Trade after the government announced new export business for both commodities. Soybeans also were higher. Wheat posted moderate gains in early trading after the government's announcement that it is targeting three countries for 450,000 subsidized tons of the crop. Wheat had been suffering from above-average temperatures in the regions where the winter crop is grown and a bountiful crop from an earlier harvest. Corn opened lower, suffering from follow-through selling after yesterday's sharply lower close. Corn futures firmed after early reports of modest export business with Spain, South Korea and Taiwan. Soybean futures rose after traders sought to cover their positions from sharp losses posted late last week and earlier this week. In early trading, wheat futures were 1{ cents lower to 2\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at 2.49} a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1 cent higher with December at $2.22} a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $1.11 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents higher to 4{ cents higher with November at 5.63 a bushel. Corn futures settled 3 cents to } cents lower with December at $2.22 a bushel; oats settled 1} cents to 2\ cents higher with December at $1.09} a bushel; soybeans settled { cent to 4\ cents higher with November at $5.58{ a bushel.
