DOC.HEAD: Court Lifts Ban on Mexican Tuna
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has lifted a controversial nationwide ban on imports of yellowfin tuna from Mexico. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Thursday ended an embargo ordered Oct. 4 by a federal judge in San Francisco. The three-judge panel gave no reason for its action but scheduled oral arguments in the case for next February. Imposed under a U.S. dolphin-protection law, the embargo has stirred some anti-U.S. feeling in Mexico and has affected the debate over establishment of a joint free-trade zone for the two countries. A lawyer for environmental groups that fought for the ban said the government submitted declarations to the court from administration officials saying the embargo was disrupting relations with Mexico on issues that included anti-drug efforts nd petroleum sales. The officials included Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and John Negroponte, the U.S. ambassador to Mexico, said Joshua Floum, lawyer for the Earth Island Institute and the Marine Mammal Fund. ``Congress knew if an embargo was imposed, Mexico wouldn't like it. We're surprised that agents of the U.S. government are so hostile to the law. (The court's action) will allow the continued slaughter of dolphins by Mexico without the consequences contemplated by Congress,'' Floum said. Floum said he would seek reconsideration of the ruling, signed by Judges Thomas Tang, Jerome Farris and Alex Kozinski. Martin Hochman, regional counsel for the Commerce Department's National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, said the government hopes to gain foreign cooperation in reducing dolphin kills in meetings over the next several months. ``One reason for the kind of reaction we've gotten from foreign nations is that it is unilateral action by the United States,'' Hochman said. ``The hope is, something can be achieved that will do what the U.S. domestic legislation is aiming at but in a cooperative way with the foreign countries.'' He said a U.S. delegation, including environmental and tuna industry representatives, has been meeting with eastern Pacific tuna fishing nations to discuss a possible international organization or agreement on the issue. Hochman said Mexico has the largest foreign tuna fleet but sells most of its tuna to Europe. The suit was filed under a law aimed at reducing the killing of dolphins that swim above yellowfin tuna in the eastern Pacific. Some commercial tuna fleets deliberately drop their nets on dolphins. The law requires the U.S. government to embargo tuna from nations that fail to reduce their dolphin-killing below certain levels: for 1989, twice the kill rate of the U.S. tuna fleet, and for any year, a total kill that includes no more than 15 percent eastern spinner dolphins, a protected subspecies. U.S. District Judge Thelton Henderson ordered a ban Aug. 28 on imports of tuna from Mexico, Panama, Ecuador, Venezuela and the Pacific island nation of Vanuatu, saying the Commerce Department had failed to show that their 1989 dolphin kill rates were less than twice the rate of the U.S. fleet. The Commerce Department never imposed the embargo on Ecuador, Venezuela or Vanuatu, saying new figures from the first eight months of 1990 showed that they were in compliance. Panama did not meet the limit and is being embargoed. The department also said Mexico would not be embargoed because it was below the limit for the first eight months of 1990. But Henderson ordered an embargo on Mexican tuna Oct. 4 and extended it Oct. 19, citing Mexico's excessive kills of eastern spinner dolphins in 1989. Though Commerce Department figures showed Mexico below the 15 percent limit for eastern spinners in the first eight months of 1990, Henderson said the law protecting eastern spinners required compliance for an entire year before an embargo could be lifted. Government lawyers argued that Henderson should have deferred to the department's interpretation of the law.

DOC.HEAD: Condor Partners Liquidates, Distributes UAL Holdings
DOC.TEXT: Condor Partners, a New York investment group formed to acquire UAL Corp., said Friday it has liquidated and no longer controls any common stock in the parent of United Airlines. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Condor Partners said it liquidated on Thursday and distributed 2.4 million UAL shares to investors. Previously, Condor Partners sold more than 186,000 UAL shares on the open market between Nov. 6 and last Monday at prices ranging between $97 and $100 a share. Condor was an affiliate of Coniston Partners, which had been the largest UAL shareholder. In September a United Airlines workers group ended its agreement with Condor partners to acquire the carrier's parent.

DOC.HEAD: Phone Companies Alerted to Possible ``Hacker'' Attack Today
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with no problems reported at AT&T; picks up 7th graf pvs, bgng, Linnen said... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Telephone companies reported normal operations today after bracing for a possible disruption of service somewhere in the country by computer ``hackers'' breaking into the phone network. Non-specific threats had been made to invade the massive computers that control the telephone network, but not to attack physical facilities, industry sources said. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the threats apparently were in connection with a sentencing scheduled in Atlanta this afternoon for three members of a hackers' group called the Legion of Doom who had broken into BellSouth Corp. computers. Franklin E. Darden Jr. and Robert J. Riggs pleaded guilty earlier this year in federal court to one conspiracy count each. Adam E. Grant pleaded guilty to possessing 15 or more access devices with intent to defraud. But late morning on the East Coast, no problems had been reported. ``This has been a normal weekday and there's been no indication of trouble anywhere in the network,'' said Herb Linnen, a spokesman for American Telephone & Telegraph Co. On Thursday, Linnen had said AT&T was aware of a ``purported threat to try and disrupt at least part of the nationwide network,'' and that company security officials had alerted AT&T managers nationwide to be alert. ``We have not been able to assess the validity of the threats, but we certainly take any threats seriously, and we've taken precautions to minimize the risk of intrusion,'' BellSouth spokesman Bill McCloskey said. Linnen said the purported threat was not against any single company. He said the rumor of the attempted disruption was discussed at a regular meeting Wednesday of technical executives of a number of phone companies. ``We have no idea how widespread the threat might be, but it's our understanding that the group may be national,'' said Peter Goodale, a spokesman for Nynex Corp., parent of the New England Telephone and New York Telephone companies. ``We've taken the appropriate security measures to ensure the integrity of our network.'' FBI and Defense Department officials said they were unaware of any such threat. Federal prosecutors in Chicago last year charged that members of the Legion of Doom had used their computers in February 1989 to tap into the 911 system of Atlanta-based BellSouth and copy the program. The information then was published in an electronic newsletter in Chicago for hackers, but the 911 network was not disrupted. Charges against the Chicago publisher were dropped in July.

For release Monday, Nov. 19
DOC.HEAD: Center Explores New Ways to Teach Economics Without Losing Students
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to youngsters, studying the economy has about the same appeal as eating vegetables, says Suzanne Gallagher of Virginia Commonwealth University. ``Just give it a chance,'' said Ms. Gallagher, sounding like a parent trying to get a child to take a mouthful of brussels sprouts. ``Economics has a bad press, but it's not dull or difficult.'' Ms. Gallagher, who came to the school in July to teach teachers how to teach economics, calls her class ``Economics, the Science of Common Sense.'' ``I think we all need to be economists on our own behalf,'' she said. ``My favorite analogy is that you wouldn't send a child out to play ball without explaining the rules of the game. You shouldn't do that for the economy, either.'' Through the efforts of the school's Center for Economic Education, hundreds of teachers in public and private schools in the state are mixing lessons on supply and demand, inflation and economic alphabet soup - GNPs and CPIs - with regular studies on social studies, science and other subjects. ``You think you have to sit and teach an economics lesson,'' said Michelle Via, who took a course at the school last year for ideas to show her first-grade students at Mary Munford School in Richmond. ``But you don't have to do that at all. You're already doing so many things that relate to it.'' Ms. Via decided to incorporate economics into a school project on recycling aluminum cans. Besides learning math by counting the cans and science by weighing them, Ms. Via's 25 students talked about the scarcity of natural resources and why it is cheaper to recycle aluminum than to mine the ore used to make the metal. Her students also learned about the capital resources needed for recycling. ``They got to see the truck come in and pick up the cans,'' she said. As the grade level increases, so does the sophistication of the economics lesson. Carole Sandy, who teaches ancient history to eighth-graders at Richmond's Collegiate Schools, has her students become citizens of Rome. Some are nobles, some are soldiers and some are slaves. All learn that their social status reflects their economic status. ``You either gain or suffer under the rule of Caesar Augustus,'' said Ms. Sandy, who first gained a respect for economics while attending a UCLA pilot program in 1979. ``I was basically very cynical about economics,'' she said. ``Coming back as a promoter of economics was a pretty interesting change around here.'' Robert C. Jameison, a Brookland Middle School social studies teacher, helps his seventh-graders learn about what he called the ``cottonball economics'' that played a role in precipitating the Civil War. The students take on the roles of three sides in the war - the industrial North, the agrarian South, and cotton-customer England. Jameison said Ms. Gallagher's ideas on teaching economics are excellent for getting students pulled into the subject. ``She makes students realize there's more to a situation than meets the eye, and it makes it fun,'' he said. Ms. Gallagher, who came here from the University of West Florida's Center for Economic Education, said school activities that relate to economics range from ``opportunity cost'' lessons - choosing, say, to go out for pizza instead of studying - to auctioning a candy bar to determine its market value. Virginia also has about 1,000 teams in various schools playing a stock market game, a 10-week investment simulation program. Each team starts with $100,000 in pretend money and buys, sells and trades stocks to increase the team's wealth. ``It's a whole lot like the real world,'' she said. ``The kids love it. It gives them something to talk to their parents about, and the parents can learn something right along with their kids.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Nov. 19

DOC.HEAD: Giant Faxes, Pocket-Sized PCs Amid Glitz at Computer Show
With AM-Computer Show-Multimedia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Fax machines big enough to send blueprints, computers that fit into a pocket and gizmos of every size in between line the miles of aisles at the world's largest computer show. And if the machines don't catch the eye, the displays and exhibitors probably will. At one booth at the Comdex show, a company's representatives played ping-pong. At another, they pranced around dressed as football players and cheerleaders. Across the hall exhibitors wore Roaring '20s gangster getups. Pop music blared from displays hawking multimedia - the combination of music, text, graphics and video that is one of the hot items at this year's show. Overhead, green laser light danced across the ceiling of the cavernous Las Vegas Convention Center. Conventioneers beneath it lined up for free software and raffles that gave away CD players and personal computers. A software display area featured giant Dixon pens and Crayola crayons, symbolizing the software industry's theme of easy-to-use graphics-based programs. Intel Corp.'s exhibit was anchored by a walk-through computer, where inside the semiconductor company's employees extolled the virtues of its microprocessor technology. Despite the circus atmosphere, many of the 120,000 attendees appeared to be doing business at the show, which ended Friday. Technical specifications on products were traded as freely as business cards. Conventioneers' arms were laden with shopping bags emblazoned with company logos that brimmed with glossy brochures on new products. There was little evidence amid the hype that the economy may be entering a recession, and that the computer industry has been in a slump for several years. Both attendance and the number of exhibitors was up from last year, said Comdex's organizers But a computer executive from a major insurance company said corporations may start to think twice about buying new high-end computer gear. He said makers of cheaper ``clone'' computers, which mimic brand-name lines, could benefit. Here is a sampling of the more interesting items at Comdex, where exhibits covered the equivalent of 50 football fields: -The Video Toaster. This $1,595 device converts a Commodore Amiga personal computer into a video editing machine. NewTek, the tiny Topeka, Kan., company that developed it, says Video Toaster can do the same things as professional TV studio gear costing $20,000. It can cut from one video to another with various special effects, add titles and logos and colorize black-and-white images. -Computers that recognize handwriting. Probably the most advanced on display is the Gridpad from Grid Systems Corp., a subsidiary of Tandy Corp. The $2,370 Gridpad, which resembles an Etch-a-Sketch, can recognize numbers and block letters written on its screen with a special pen. -``Desktop offices.'' Canon's $2,495 Navigator combines a small personal computer, phone, answering machine, fax and printer into a desktop unit designed for the home office. -``Portable offices.'' This category includes Kodak's 3}-pound, battery-operated printer, aimed at laptop computer users, and Ricoh's 3-pound portable copier, which can be converted into a fax machine by plugging in a 1-pound adapter. -Portable computers with improved color screens. Several makers demonstrated models based on a technology called active matrix, in which each pixel, or dot, on the screen is connected to a separate transistor. It produces crisper, deeper colors than conventional laptop color monitors. -``Palmtop'' computers. These models are so small they fit in a coat pocket. Probably the most sophisticated is the $1,995 Poqet machine from Poqet Computer. This 1-pounder runs most programs written for the popular DOS operating system used by International Business Machines Corp. computers and IBM compatibles. Among cheaper palmtops, Atari's $299 Portfolio contains a calculator, address book, word processor, work organizer and diary, but doesn't run DOS programs. But palmtops have a major drawback - tiny keyboards, which could be awkward for many adult hands and make their word-processing programs of limited use. -Car adaptors for portable devices. Several companies offered products that plug into the cigarette lighter to provide current for computing on the go. But the most novel products at Comdex may be Whereabouts, by a company called ArtSoft. It's a series of humorous graphical messages that a personal computer user can call up on the screen before leaving the office. Among the messages are ``out to lunch,'' accompanied by a picture of a pizza, and ``in a meeting,'' with a space for the meeting-goer to type in the location.

DOC.HEAD: GM Extends Fairfax Shutdown
DOC.TEXT: The General Motors Corp. will not reopen its Fairfax plant on Monday as planned, the company said. Citing a drop in orders for the Pontiac Grand Prix, GM said Thursday the plant will continue its shutdown until Dec. 3. About 3,000 production workers have been affected by the shutdown, which has already lasted two weeks. GM did not elaborate on its action at Fairfax, but dealers and analysts said it stemmed from a decline in orders from dealers. The Grand Prix has been selling above last year's levels in recent months. October sales numbered 10,377, up 38 percent from October 1989. But sales appear to be slowing in November, and dealers have a more than adequate supply. ``There's a great concern from the people,'' said Clint Simmons, bargaining chairman at United Auto Workers Local 31, which represents Fairfax production workers. ``We haven't encountered a 30-day shutdown in a long time.'' The last time the Fairfax plant was down for a month or more was in January.

DOC.NOTE: $adv19
For Release Monday Nov 19
DOC.HEAD: Long Drought for Budding Growth Stocks
DOC.TEXT: How long can a bear market last? For a gloomy answer to that question, ask anyone in the shrinking band of Wall Street investors who specialize in small-company growth stocks. Fans of ``emerging growth'' companies get a lot of practice being patient, enduring lengthy dry spells in their quest to discover the budding IBMs, Mercks and Philip Morrises of the future. But even their fabled stamina has been wearing down of late, given the continued drubbing their favorites have been subjected to in the market decline since midsummer. By most gauges, the last period of sustained prosperity in their chosen field of expertise ended around the middle of 1983. ``Almost everyone involved in small growth stock investing throughout the 1980s knows how it feels to get up off the canvas,'' observes analyst L. Keith Mullins in a current Morgan Stanley & Co. appraisal. ``However, if you think the latest series of blows have been particularly severe, you are right. From a historical perspective, the small growth sector's abysmal recent performance is without precedent.'' When junior growth stocks started to lag behind the mighty bull market in the mid-1980s, their admirers had several explanations to console themselves with. No matter how bright small companies' futures might look, most of them lacked the kind of undervalued assets corporate raiders were looking for in the takeover boom on Wall Street. These up-and-comers didn't have the marquee names that attracted big foreign investors. They got little benefit from the vogue for index-fund investing, in which money managers bought up stocks of big companies in order to duplicate the performance of some yardstick such as Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index. By the time Wall Street had weathered the crash of 1987, many analysts figured that the small growth stocks were ready for a comeback. After a short-lived burst of enthusiasm, however, investors turned their backs on the group once again. Then, when the market as a whole ran into trouble this year, junior growth stocks took yet another pounding. From the start of July through September, the T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, a traditional standard-bearer of the emerging-growth camp, fell 26.4 percent. That was almost double the 13.7 percent loss recorded over the same period by the S&P 500. ``The third quarter was one of the most difficult periods in the fund's 30-year history,'' John Laporte, the fund's president, said in a report to shareholders. ``We were surprised by the susbtantial underperformance of small company stocks because valuation levels were already at the low end of historic ranges.'' How low has the group gone now? Well, at Sept. 30 the price-earnings ratio of the New Horizons Fund was .96 of the Standard & Poor's 500's P-E, equaling lows reached just twice before - in 1977 and again after the '87 crash. In theory, small growth stocks should carry a ``normal'' P-E of perhaps 1.5 times that of the overall market, if only because these companies are in position to post greater-than-average profit increases in the future. By an old rule of thumb, emerging growth stocks are a bargain when their multiple vs. the overall market shrinks much below 1.5, and should be sold as the multiple gets closer to 2. If you apply any standard of that sort now, says Laporte, ``emerging growth stocks look incredibly cheap.'' From Mullins's perspective, ``the point is clear. The present valuations for small growth stocks are either a temporary anomaly, or the group has sunk permanently into uncharted valuation waters.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon Nov 19

DOC.HEAD: Dow Jones Boosts Ad Rates by 7 Percent at Barron's
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co. Inc. said Friday it was boosting advertising rates by 7 percent for Barron's National Business and Financial Weekly, effective in January 1991. The rate hike is the latest in a recent series of increases announced at publications such as Time, Newsweek, U.S. News & World Report magazines despite the recent slump in demand for print and broadcast advertising. It also comes only two weeks after the weekly announced it was boosting its cover price by 50 cents to $2.50 effective with the Dec. 3 issue and subscription prices by $10 a year to $109 in 1991. Barron's last advertising rate increase was 5.5 percent a year ago. This year's 7 percent increase applies to its national and regional editions. The national rate for a full-page ad will rise to $15,488. Robert Paradise, publisher of Barron's, said the increase was fair and reasonable given the publication's efficiency in reaching top corporate executives, financial professionals and individual investors. Barron's weekly circulation averaged 250,789 in the latest reporting period. Ad volume for the first nine months of the year was off 4.3 percent. Barron's sister publication, The Wall Street Journal, announced last week it was boosting its ad rates starting next year by 6 percent for national ads, 7 percent to 9 percent for regional editions and 10 percent to 12 percent for overseas editions.

DOC.HEAD: Fall in Trade Deficit Seen as Sign of Economic Weakness
With AM-Economy, Bjt. Also moving on general news wires.
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: America's merchandise trade balance narrowed to $9.4 billion in September, the government said Friday. Analysts said the improvement probably likely sprang from consumer retrenchment in the face of a weakening economy. ``Imports were weak and that confirms the weakness in the economy itself,'' said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International in New York. Consumers cut their purchases of imported goods by 2.4 percent, to $41.3 billion, despite a 28.5 percent jump in the cost of imported oil. Exports also dropped, down 2.2 percent to $31.8 billion. The difference meant a 3.3 percent improvement over August's $9.7 billion gap. Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, noted that non-oil imports fell $2 billion and predicted that ``this will continue.'' ``That is, as consumer spending and capital spending weakens, Americans will cut back not only on domestic goods, but imported goods as well.'' Many economists believe the economy has slid into a recession - a possibility President Bush acknowledged for the first time Thursday. ``I am concerned that we are in a downturn here,'' he said in an interview with Cable News Network. Both the value and the volume of oil imports rose, pushing America's foreign oil bill to $6.1 billion in September. That was the highest since October 1981, when it reached $6.3 billion during a period of global shortages. Oil prices in September, boosted by the Persian Gulf crisis, jumped 24.4 percent to $24.31 a barrel. At the same time, shipments rose 6.7 percent to 8.5 million barrels a day. Among the imports, shipments of foreign cars and both capital and consumer goods fell. Foods and beverages were virtually unchanged, while both industrial supplies including oil and other merchandise rose slightly. Except for capital goods, almost all general categories of exports fell. ``Export growth is supposed to be one of the factors that helps this economy along and moderate the extent of the recession,'' said economist John Silvia of Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. ``But if exports continue to grow less than we expect, it means the economy may go through a deeper recession than what we're going through.'' Bush administration officials have been counting on exports to cushion a falling the economy, particularly as consumer spending fades. Exports have accounted in recent years for a third of the nation's economic growth. Consumer spending represented the other two-thirds. Some economists believe a weaker dollar will help prop up exports by making U.S. products less expensive overseas. But both Brusca and Steinberg said they do not expect much improvement before next year. ``Thirty percent of U.S. exports go to countries that are in a recession,'' Brusca said. ``You shouldn't hold your breath for exports to save the economy.'' Nevertheless, J. Antonio Villamil, Commerce Department chief economist, pointed to the surplus the United States has posted with Western Europe so far this year, including $882 million in September. ``For the first nine months of 1990, the trade surplus with Western Europe stood at $3.5 billion compared with a deficit of $600 million in 1989'' and $8.8 billion during the same period of 1988, he said. But at the same time, the biggest deficit continued to be with Japan - a $3.05 billion imbalance, down from $3.78 billion in August. Other deficits included Taiwan, $1.03 billion; China $1.07 billion; Canada, $1.25 billion; South Korea, $406 million; Hong Kong, $231 million; and Brazil, $105 million. The September deficit pushed the gap to a seasonally adjusted rate of $99.1 billion for the first nine months of the year. The deficit peaked at $152 billion in 1987 and then fell to $118.53 billion in 1988 and to $109.40 billion last year.

For Release Monday, Nov 19
DOC.HEAD: Foreign Investors Are Buying U.S. Treasury Issues Again
DOC.TEXT: Foreign buyers may be returning to the U.S. Treasury debt market, despite higher interest rates at home and a weak dollar that depresses the securities' value. Early numbers from the federal government indicate foreign investors added $14 billion to their net holdings of U.S. Treasuries between July and September. Although that doesn't come close to the levels at which overseas investors were financing the federal deficit in the late '80s, it is a sharp increase from a trend that appeared to be developing earlier this year. In the first three months of 1990, foreign investors were net sellers of $6.6 billion in Treasury securities and net buyers of only $6 billion in the second quarter. With higher real interest rates available in Japan, Germany, France and Britain, who would buy a security denominated in weak dollars to earn low yields? Salomon Brothers' bond market researchers look to the Middle East. Politically, Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries have more to gain by supporting U.S. bond prices than by picking up a few extra percentage points elsewhere. ``We suspect that the principal foreign purchasers have been official or quasi-official institutions,'' the investment firm said in its weekly research report. Salomon Brothers cited a $10 billion third-quarter rise in the amount of Treasury securities held in custody at the Federal Reserve for international authorities as another sign that the purchasers are tied to foreign governments. Japanese investors participated moderately in the Treasury's record November refunding auction, buying 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. But shortly after the auction, they turned around and sold the securities in the open market. Dealers said the Japanese institutions were trying to show support for the U.S. government, but with the weak dollar and interest rates relatively unattractive to those in Japan, they moved to get rid of the securities. The real interest rate, the nominal rate minus projected inflation, is 4 percent on 10-year U.S. notes, according to Philip M. Hubbard, director of London-based Consensus Economics Inc., an economic survey firm. The real rates on 10-year bonds in Japan, Germany, France and Britain are around 6 percent, Hubbard said. Although there has been more activity recently, it is unlikely that foreign investors are substantially bolstering the U.S. Treasury market, said Carol A. Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``While foreign investors have taken large portions of Treasury debt, they have never dominated domestic investors ... their recent reduced participation has not at all resulted in higher interest rates,'' she said in a weekly report. At the peak of foreign purchases of U.S. Treasuries - 1988 - overseas investors bought $62 billion, or 44 percent of the Treasury's total net issues. In 1989, net foreign buys were $30.3 billion, or 20 percent of the total. In the same period, yields on 10-year Treasuries averaged 8.85 percent in 1988 and fell to an average of 8.57 percent so far this year, she said. Investors intent on keeping thier money in the United States, meanwhile, have had plenty of reason to choose the Treasury market over other securities. The weak U.S. economy and expectations of monetary easing by the Federal Reserve prompts many to expect lower interest rates soon. By buying now, they hope to lock in higher yields that might not be available much longer. For quality, investors can't beat the U.S. government. With fears about the effects a recession would have on state and local governments to stay current with their municipal bond payments and the junk bond market collapse, many investors are looking for less risk.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Sentencing for Next Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: The sentencing of former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. junk bond financier Michael Milken will take place on Wednesday, a federal judge announced Friday. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood issued an order saying that the sentencing was scheduled for Wednesday at 10 a.m. in Manhattan federal court. Milken, 44, pleaded guilty in April to six counts of fraud and conspiracy related to illegal securities trading. He faces a maximum 28 years in prison. As part of his plea bargain, Milken agreed to pay $600 million in penalties. The sentencing originally had been set for Oct. 1, but was postponed so Wood could hear evidence to help her decide Milken's punishment. The hearing on additional government charges not included in Milken's guilty plea lasted about two weeks. Milken was first linked to the government's investigation of Wall Street corruption in late 1986 by Ivan Boesky, the former stock speculator who turned state's evidence and admitted to widespread insider trading.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth-Quarter Net Down for Hewlett-Packard
DOC.TEXT: Computer giant Hewlett-Packard Co. on Friday reported an 18 percent drop in fourth-quarter earnings, which it attributed to increases in operating expenses and the cost of goods sold. Net earnings totaled $202 million, or 83 cents per share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31, compared to $246 million, or $1.04 per share, in the same quarter last year. Net revenue rose 6 percent, to $3.6 billion from $3.4 billion last year. John A. Young, president and chief executive officer, said the drop in income was due to slower revenue growth, a weaker dollar pushing up the cost of overseas operations and a higher cost of goods sold. To offset such setbacks, Hewlett-Packard has consolidated some manufacturing operations, offered voluntary severance and early retirement programs and slowed hiring. ``Even though we've made good progress toward reducing our expense structure, we haven't yet seen the full benefits of our initiatives this quarter,'' Young said. For the year, net income totaled $739 million, down 11 percent from $829 million in 1989. Per-share income declined 13 percent, to $3.06 from $3.52. Net revenue for 1990 rose 11 percent to $13.2 billion, vs. $11.9 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Inflation Eases a Bit, but Only Because of Recession
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 4 grafs with Bush meetings and Darman comments after 16th graf pvs, In a. Picks up 17th graf pvs, The 0.6. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Consumer inflation slowed slightly in October and the country's trade deficit narrowed, but economists attributed Friday's seemingly upbeat developments to the near certainty that the nation has slid into a recession. Meanwhile, President Bush wrapped up a week of hastily called meetings with his economic advisers and leading U.S. business executives as the administration scoured for ways to alleviate the pain from any economic downturn. Bush received a generally bleak assessment of the economy's prospects from the executives, leading the president to acknowledge the possibility of a recession for the first time. He continued to insist, however, that any downturn would be brief and relatively mild. ``Most seem to feel that if we have a recession, it will not be deep and that we'll come out of it relatively soon, six months at most, and I would like to think that is true,'' Bush said in an interview with Cable News Network. The Labor Department reported that the Consumer Price Index rose 0.6 percent in October, better than the 0.8 percent spurts that hit in August and September as oil prices surged after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Prices rose a modest 0.3 percent last month for products not related to energy. Economists said this ``core'' rate, often seen as a better barometer of inflation, probably stayed relatively low because the economic slump is holding down prices. ``The sliding economy is preventing the oil and energy shock from causing a runaway on inflation,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. ``There's a hint here that we may get through this inflationary shock from oil in reasonably good shape, but only at the cost of a sharp downturn in the economy keeping inflation from getting out of hand,'' Sinai said. Added analyst David Wyss of DRI-McGraw Hill: ``There's some good news on the inflation side, but bad news on the real side, which is that the real economy is a mess.'' The slightly improved inflation rate might give room to maneuver to the Federal Reserve, which has been uner pressure from the Bush administration to ease its inflation-fighting campaign and lower interest rates to spur the economy, analysts said. ``With inflation stable or coming down, the Fed has some room to fight'' a recession, Wyss said. Also Friday, the Commerce Department reported that the U.S. merchandise trade deficit narrowed 3.3 percent in September, the first improvement since June. But the value of petroleum imports was at its highest level in nine years because of escalating costs due to the Persian Gulf crisis. Imports dropped 2.4 percent to $41.3 billion despite a huge 28.5 percent jump in petroleum imports. But exports also fell, down 2.2 percent to $31.8 billion. The deficit is the difference between the two. The improvement in the trade deficit, as with the better inflation rate, was probably due to the economic slowdown shaking consumer confidence and pushing down import buying, analysts said. In a separate report, the Labor Department said Americans' average weekly earnings, after adjusting for inflation, plunged 2.1 percent in October. It was the largest decline since a 2.3 percent drop in April 1979. The average weekly wage, before adjusting for inflation, was $349.85. The weakness in the economy was reflected in the comments 20 top business executives made Thursday and Friday during White House meetings with the president. ``There is a general feeling that we are either in a recession or very close,'' said Amoco Chairman Dick Morrow following Friday's session. White House Budget Director Richard Darman, who attended the meetings along with other top economic advisers, said that the general consensus among the executives and the presidential advisers was that the country was in a downturn, a word Bush himself used during his CNN interview. ``As to what to do about it, that is the purpose of having these meetings,'' Darman said. He said Bush will probably not make any decisions on policy proposals until mid-December at the earliest. The 0.6 percent increase in consumer prices in October capped the worst three-month bout of inflation since 1982. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait, Americans' cost of living has risen at an annual rate of 8.9 percent, nearly double the 4.6 percent inflation rate for all of last year. Fuel oil prices have shot up more than 50 percent in the last three months; gasoline prices have soared nearly 27 percent. However, analysts expect that inflation - without the outbreak of a shooting war in the Persian Gulf - will return to more normal levels in coming months as oil prices stabilize. ``If oil prices do not go up, one can expect the inflation fire to basically be out by next spring,'' Sinai said. A recession could keep the oil price shock from filtering through to the thousands of other energy-related products such as chemicals, plastics and air fare. ``The economy's just not growing. If the economy's not growing, people can't pass on price increases if they want to maintain market share,'' said Peter Radford, an analyst with National Westminster Bancorp. in New York. So far this year, inflation has risen 6.7 percent, well above the 4.7 percent rate for the similar 10-month period last year, the government said. In October, food costs rose 0.4 percent, double the 0.2 percent increase of September, the government said. A slight drop in fruit and vegetable prices was more than offset by larger increases for other grocery store products, such as meats, poultry and eggs. Clothing costs were down 0.2 percent as prices fell for men's, women's and children's apparel. Footwear prices were up 0.1 percent. Medical care prices jumped 0.8 percent, following similar sharp increases in August and September. Those prices are now 9.4 percent higher than they were a year ago. New car prices rose 0.5 percent in October while housing costs were up 0.3 percent, the report showed. The various changes put the index for all consumer items at 133.5 in October. That means a hypothetical selection of goods and services that cost $100 in the 1982-84 base period would have cost $133.50 last month, up from $125.60 a year earlier.
Stock prices were little changed today in an erratic session. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down .25 at 2,544.80.

DOC.HEAD: VA Cuts Rate Ceiling to 9.5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Veterans Affairs said Friday it is lowering its maximum interest rate for federally backed VA home mortgages by one-half percentage point to 9.5 percent, effective Monday. ``This should provide a significant stimulus to the housing market and the economy as a whole,'' said VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski. The new rate is for home and condominium loans. It means the monthly payment for principal and interest on a typical VA loan of $80,000 will total $672.29, down $29.37 a month from the previous rate. The department increased the rate from 9.5 percent to 10 percent last February. The department also lowered the rates for manufactured homes to 12 percent; graduated payment mortgages, to 9.7 percent; manufactured home and lot combination loans, to 11.5 percent; manufactured home lots only, 11.5 percent; and home improvement loans, to 11 percent. It said in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, it guaranteed 196,600 home loans totaling $15.8 billion, compared to 188,000 home loans totaling $14.4 billion in the previous year. VA home loan guarantees may be used to purchase, improve or refinance a house or condominium and to purchase or refinance a manufactured home.

The stock market made little progress today despite signs that the Federal Reserve had moved to ease its credit policy. In the economic news, the Labor Department said the nation's core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, advanced a moderate 0.3 percent last month. The report ``was definitely encouraging,'' said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. ``It suggests that if you subtract oil, inflationary pressures are easing.'' Separately, the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit narrowed 3.3 percent in September, showing its first improvement since June. Brokers said the most recent data evidently gave the Federal Reserve whatever encouragement it might still have needed to take new steps toward lower interest rates in the money markets.

DOC.HEAD: United-American Rivalry Intensifies with Reservation Link
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines, battling with United Airlines for global dominance, announced Friday that its Sabre reservations system is linking up with Europe's largest network. The combination with the Amadeus system gives American a network with 126,000 reservations terminals, 40,000 more than United's Covia system and its European partner, Galileo. Sabre and Amadeus announced in Paris that they had reached a long-term agreement to combine technology and marketing to offer a joint product worldwide. American is the world's second largest airline in terms of revenue passenger miles and United is third, according to the Air Transport Association in Washington. The Soviet airline, Aeroflot, is No. 1. United's Covia system already is a 25.6 percent shareholder in Galileo, a European system that is smaller but more advanced than Amadeus. Madrid-based Amadeus gains access to Sabre's considerable computer system and marketing muscle, which should help it compete with Galileo. Amadeus so far ``has been the least effective system,'' said David Richardson, an independent travel industry expert in Oxford, England. Sabre, with 85,000 terminals in travel agencies and airlines worldwide, claims to be the world's largest computerized reservation system. As air travel becomes increasingly global, reservation systems become more crucial to the success of airlines who want to sell their products as far afield as possible. The systems provide wider, faster and more efficient distribution not only of air tickets, but hotel rooms and car rentals. ``In the long term, all the major airlines (listings) will be on all the major systems,'' said Richardson. United and American last month fought over Pan American World Airways' London routes, which United won with a $400 million deal. United also recently won a new route from Chicago to Tokyo but American already had acquired Eastern's South American routes last year. United won Pan Am's Pacific routes in 1985. John Hotard, an American spokesman in Fort Worth, Texas, said in a telephone interview that Sabre is not buying a stake in Amadeus and the two databases will remain separate. The deal will last at least 20 years, he said. ``This is a marketing agreement which will give much more access to Sabre in Europe,'' Hotard. Madrid-based Amadeus was formed in 1987 by equal partners Air France, Spain's Iberia Airlines, Lufthansa German Airlines and the Scandinavian Airlines System. Although it has 41,000 terminals, Amadeus was hampered when its shareholders switched to a different computer system to get the capability they wanted. Galileo, also founded in 1987, has 21,000 terminals and is based in Swindon, England. Covia Corp., the 65,000-terminal system owned by United, is one of 10 shareholders who include British Airways, Swissair and KLM Royal Dutch Airways.

DOC.HEAD: U S West to Aid Czechoslovakian Phone Systems
DOC.TEXT: U S West signed agreements with Czechoslovakia on Friday to help develop communications systems in that country. Bell Atlantic International also is partner in the plan to create joint venture companies with the country's Post and Telecommunications Administrations. The Czechoslovakian administration will own 51 percent of each company with Bell Atlantic and U S West jointly owning the remaining 49 percent. The companies will build and operate cellular mobile and packet data networks in Czechoslovakia. Initial service is expected to be available in the second half of 1991, beginning in Prague, Bratislava and Brno followed by expansion to other metropolitan areas. Construction of a cellular network in Czechoslovakia is U S West's third cellular venture in eastern Europe, company officials said. The company is a partner with the Hungarian Telecommunications Co., which is operating a cellular system in Hungary. It's also signed an agreement to build the Soviet Union's first commercial cellular system in Leningrad.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Cancels Little Jeep Project
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. on Friday canceled its ``JJ'' small sport-utility project, saying it cost too much money to continue without a partner. Chrysler ad Fiat SpA of Italy recently called off talks that included discussions about a joint project to develop the small Jeep. ``While attractive as a joint venture, the JJ project as a stand-alone program required too great a commitment of resources that are needed for higher priority product programs,'' a Chrysler news release said. Originally, the JJ was conceived as a joint project between Chrysler and the French automaker Renault. It was to be built at a factory in Spain and one not identified in North America. When Chrysler's relationship with Renault soured, the No. 3 U.S. automaker turned to Fiat. The companies did not disclose what prompted them to call off their talks.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 173.22 Friday, up 2.58, or 1.51 percent, from a week ago and down 24.06, or 12.20 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 164.16 Friday, up 2.36, or 1.46 percent, from a week ago and down 20.95, or 11.32 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 124.26 Friday, up 2.96, or 2.44 percent, from a week ago and down 44.05 or 26.17 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: The National Lays Off 18 Editorial Employees
DOC.TEXT: The National, the nine-month-old daily sports newspaper running into financial problems even as it tries to expand, has laid off 18 editorial employees to cut costs, a spokesman said Friday. The layoffs, which amount to 6.5 percent of the company's total employmnet of about 275, offer the most concrete evidence to date of the privately held paper's difficulties in establishing itself with readers and advertisers as the first national sports daily in the United States. The newspaper has encountered a very difficult environment for advertising as companies appear cut back on spending as the economy weakens. That poor advertising market has driven some magazines out of business and has prompted some media companies to close bureaus, lay off reporters, seek concessions from remaining employees and impose austerity measures. Spokesman Stephen Hammond said those being laid off at The National include mostly editorial support workers such as layout designers and copy editors at sites nationwide. The National currently publishes nine metropolitan editions in cities spread from Boston to San Diego and plans to launch three more - in Philadelphia, Atlanta and Baltimore-Washington - in the next three months. But the paper has apparently been spending more than expected when it was launched last winter with editions in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. Last week, the newspaper announced it was suspending publication of its Sunday issue after Nov. 25 because of low circulation and distribution difficulties. It will continue to publish on weekdays, Monday throught Friday. Also last week, the president and publisher of the paper, Peter O. Price, was stripped of day-to-day responsibilities for the operation and three top executives - the circulation director, assistant publisher and the finance and administration director - were fired. The largest shareholder in the partnership that runs the paper, the Univisa unit of Mexico's Televisa entertainment and publishing company, put one of its U.S. executives, Jaime Davila, in charge of the National's operations. A week ago, Editor in Chief Frank Deford told editorial staffers that a handful of jobs may have to be eliminated but that he hoped to do it through attrition rather than layoffs. ``That is what we hoped but nobody left,'' Hammond said. Efforts to reach Deford on Friday were unsuccessful. Price and Davila also were said to be unavailable to the media. Hammond was asked whether the layoffs, which he said reduce the number of editorial staffers at the paper to about 210, complete the cutbacks. ``I can't give you an honest answer on that,'' he said. John Morton, who follows newspaper companies for the brokerage Lynch Jones & Ryan in Washington, D.C., said, ``This was bound to happen.'' ``They are trying to create something we have not had before. Whenever you are inventing something new, there will be unexpected events,'' he said. Morton said the National has had trouble competing for readers with the sports sections of metropolitan dailies. In addition, it was launched during a ``media recession,'' he said. ``These are the worst conditions in the newspaper business in 20 years. That is very painful for a new newspaper that is trying to achieve a standing with readers and advertisers,'' Morton said. He said the question of whether The National will survive much longer depends on how much its owners are prepared to lose. At the time of the launch, it was reported that Emilia Azcarrga, the head of Televisa, was prepared to spend $100 million over five years to make the paper profitbale. Morton declined to give odds on the paper's chances, but said they were worse than when the paper was launched. ``The newspaper environmnet has gotten worse, and that is going to cause them to spend money faster,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: US-EC Fail To Bridge Gaps In GATT Talks
DOC.TEXT: Top U.S. and European Community officials failed Friday to resolve differences over cutting subsidies for farmers, putting world trade talks in jeopardy. U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter estimated the chances of a successful conclusion of the talks at ``much less than 50-50,''following the meeting with officials of the 12-nation European Community. Yeutter, Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Trade Representative Carla Hills met with members of the EC executive Commission to try to close gaps in world trade talks. ``Many problems do remain and not much time remains,'' said Baker. ``But I think it is fair to say all of us are committed to intense discussions at the highest level to resolve our differences.'' These gaps have brought the Uruguay Round of talks, a four-year effort involving more than 100 nations, to the brink of collapse, two weeks before the negotiations are to be completed. Both sides said they were committed to successful completion of talks to liberalize world trade under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But each side warned the talks could break down if the other did not change its positions, especially on agriculture -- one of 15 areas under negotiation in the global trade talks. An EC offer to cut farm subsidies by 30 percent over 10 years, beginning in 1986, is at odds with a proposal by the United States and other major farm exporting countries to cut subsidies by 75 percent, starting in 1991. Also, the United States, Argentina, Canada, Australia and other countries seek a 90 percent cut in export subsidies. The EC has made no offer on export subsidies, an issue that has particularly upset Washington. EC Agriculture Commissioner Ray MacSharry told reporters there was ``no question of compromise'' on the EC's offer saying the United States ``must lower its expectations.'' Yeutter said ``crucial elements'' of the EC proposal did not ``meet the criteria of success'' in the trade talks. He and Hills were to have more talks with EC officials over the weekend. Friday's meeting was the second time this year the giant trade partners held high-level meeting talks to reflect the increasing importance they attach to closer transatlantic ties. The two sides also pledged to cooperate in providing aid for the Soviet Union. ``We agreed on the importance of working together in the event that there were requests from the Soviet Union for humanitarian relief,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Reaches New Low Against Mark
DOC.TEXT: The dollar declined broadly Friday and settled at a new low against the German mark as the specter of lower U.S. interest rates drove investors from the market. Gold prices were mixed. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $378.90 a troy ounce, down 20 cents from Thursday. Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for bullion at $379, up 25 cents an ounce. Much of the day's activity centered on the mark, which has been rising on expectations that Germany's Bundesbank may be on the verge of hiking interest rates. Such a move would make German fixed-income securities more attractive to investors, thereby enhancing their need for marks. Further hurting the dollar was the continuing expectation that the Federal Reserve is preparing to lower interest rates. Anticipation that the differential between U.S. and German interest rates is about to widen worked against the dollar. In New York the dollar settled at a post-war low of 1.4705 German marks, down from 1.4755 marks on Thursday. Currency trading was active following a Labor Department report showing that consumer prices were up a steep 0.6 percent in October. But once volatile food and energy prices were subtracted, the so-called core inflation rate registered a moderate 0.3 percent. ``The market seized on the figure,'' said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank here. He said that because inflationary pressures seem to be stabilizing, the Fed has more room to maneuver interest rates downward. Around midday, the Fed announced it would injected reserves into the banking system by buying Treasury bills with the promise of repurchasing them soon, usually after the weekend. ``It looks like a clear signal of Fed easing,'' said Michael Malpede, a senior analyst at Refco Group Inc. in Chicago. The federal funds rate, the rate charged on overnight loans between banks, also shifted lower, but several analysts said they wanted to track the rate over the course of a few days to determine whether it signified the easing the markets have been expecting. The Fed typically loosens credit to spur a flagging economy, but the central bank has been inhibited by fear lowering interest rates might heat up inflation. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 129.73 Japanese yen from 129.30 yen late Thursday. Later in London, it fell to 129.45 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.50 yen, down from 129.69 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.9655 from $1.9590 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9660 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.9575. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates included: 1.2465 Swiss francs, down from 1.2518; 4.9685 French francs, down from 4.9850; 1,109.50 Italian lire, down from 1,113.25; and 1.1633 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1624. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.4715 German marks, down from 1.4765; 1.2445 Swiss francs, down from 1.2515; 4.9690 French francs, down from 4.9890; 1.6595 Dutch guilders, down from 1.6650; 1,110.25 Italian lire, down from 1,112.50; and 1.1643 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1617. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $376.25 a troy ounce, from $379.25 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $376.20 an ounce from $378.60. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.08 an ounce to $380.11. Silver prices also were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.15 a troy ounce, up from Thursday's $4.117. But in London the metal slipped to a late bid of $4.11 a troy ounce, from $4.16.

DOC.HEAD: Bankers Say Murdoch is Seeking $600 Million Bridge Loan
DOC.TEXT: Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd. is seeking a $600 million bridge loan to help alleviate a short-term liquidity squeeze brought on by tough market conditions, bankers said Friday. Murdoch and other senior News Corp. executives presented their proposals to creditors earlier this week in Sydney and at a meeting Thursday in London with British and European bankers. Australian-based News Corp. is trying to line up support for a new credit facility of $6.5 billion to replace much of its existing debt, bankers said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Several key institutions have given conditional support to the proposal, the bankers said, but added it was too soon to say whether News Corp.'s more than 100 lenders would accept the proposal in full or in part. The short-term financing would be used largely as a guaranteed line of credit until the media markets improve and the company can begin disposing of about $1 billion in assets, they said. News Corp. is currently saddled with 2.9 billion Australian dollars, or $2.2 billion, in short-term debt, the bulk of which is coming due in July. Murdoch and other News Corp. executives told bankers that the rescheduling, coupled with asset disposals and cost controls, would better position the company to service its debts after 1991 when trading conditions are expected to improve, the bankers said. News Corp. on Thursday reported a 31 percent drop in its fiscal first quarter operating profit after taxes largely due to costs associated with its European satellite television venture and exchange rate factors. News Corp. confirmed Murdoch ``discussed a proposal to reschedule bank debts through a new three-year agreement.'' It added that he also assured bankers the company would seek to reduce its debt load through disposals of ``non-core businesses'' over the period. News Corp. declined to identify what operations would be put up for sale, but bankers said News Corp.'s 50 percent stake in Australian Paper Mills, British coated paper manufacturer Townsend Hook, and certain Australian printing operations were mentioned in the talks. Some U.S. operations were also mentioned, bankers said, including the Daily Racing Form, a newspaper dedicated to horse racing, and Delux Labs, an affiliate of Twentieth Century Fox Corp. Murdoch also assured bankers that News Corp. would seek to hold down operating costs by ``deferring major capital projects,'' News Corp. said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Plunges Below $30 Per Barrel
DOC.TEXT: Oil fell below $30 a barrel on the futures market Friday, as perceptions that war in the Persian Gulf would be delayed dragged crude to its lowest level in weeks. ``The whole thing looks like it's getting further and further away,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Light sweet crude settled at $29.78 per barrel, down $1.34, after falling as low as $29.25 for December delivery contracts at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Contracts for crude delivery in later months all traded lower, as did the rest of the energy futures traded on the exchange. For the week, December crude fell $4.11 a barrel. Crude for next-month delivery had last traded below $30 per barrel on Oct. 23, when oil hit as low as $28.30 before settling at $29.37. Traders said the drop below $30 was having a psychological effect on the market, just as oil's rise above $40 had. ``It's a big number. Everybody looks at it,'' Tagler said. The trading was partly technical, as traders liquidated their positions on the December contracts, which go off the board on Monday. Otherwise, they were looking mostly at the bearish implications of news coming in from the Gulf. The market was responding in part to an ABC-TV interview with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, who said he wanted peace in the Middle East, as well as reports that Iraq had told Iranian leaders that it had not ruled out the idea of withdrawing from occupied Kuwait. There have also been recent reports that the Egyptians, the Soviets and some members of Congress are urging President Bush to avoid an immediate confrontation. Bush's planned trip to visit U.S. troops in the Gulf for Thanksgiving, which is observed next Thursday, has also led traders to doubt any military actions are imminent. ``We may be seeing a grace period where nothing will happen,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc., in Hoboken, N.J. Other energy futures also fell sharply on Friday. Home heating oil for December delivery dropped 2.25 cents to 84.42 cents a gallon, with later delivery months all moving lower. For the week, heating oil fell 5.82 cents on December contracts. Unleaded gasoline futures fell for all delivery months, with December contracts off 2.53 cents at 77.63 cents per gallon. For the week, unleaded gasoline fell 10.60 cents. Natural gas contracts fell 6.5 cents to $2.335 per 1,000 cubic feet for December delivery. Later months all moved down, mostly by several cents. For the week, natural gas was off 8.4 cents per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Indiana CEOs, Tired of Untrained Workers, Back School ``Choice''
DOC.TEXT: Indiana business leaders, fed up with poorly trained workers, offered education remedies including granting parents the right to choose the schools their children attend. ``If the business community in this state really believes that education has to get a lot better, and believes that it has a vested interest in making sure that happens, then the burden is on us to come forward with ideas, with a plan, to make it better,'' said James K. Baker, chairman of Arvin Industries in Columbus, Ind. Executives from Eli Lilly & Co., Cummins Engine Co. and other large firms said the state is threatening its own economic development by producing workers who cannot read, write, compute or communicate. Indiana high school graduation rates, after peaking at just over 80 percent in 1983 and 1984, have steadily worsened to about 75 percent last year. The state also ranked 19th among 22 states who make wide use of the Scholastic Aptitude Test, a college entrance examination. Baker, who is also chairman of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, presented the executives' four-point state reform package at a gathering of business officials, educators and public policy-makers at the Indiana Convention Center. The plan proposed: - Preparing children at an early age for the rigors of education. - Tighter school standards so students are prepared for the work force. - Freeing teachers from burdensome regulations. - Allowing parents to send their children to the schools of their choice. The proposals echoed a study last spring by the Brookings Institution advocating broad school choice as the key to better schools. It also follows numerous studies suggesting U.S. schools are failing to produce workers equipped to compete in a global marketplace. ``The time has come to put the education spotlight on the child, not the system,'' Baker said. ``Public education should mean tax dollars to educate children, not to support school systems.'' Richard Wood, chairman of Indianapolis-based Lilly, asked business officials to contribute to a lobbying effort to change the state school system. State Superintendent of Public Instruction H. Dean Evans applauded the involvement of the business community, adding it could provide a breakthrough for reforms, including the controversial principle of school choice. ``I see no problem whatsoever in injecting competitive spirit into the school environment,'' he said.

The stock of MCI Communications plunged 7] to 22| in heavy over-the-counter trading. Late Thursday the company announced a restructuring and said the costs of corporate changes, along with intense competition, loomed as a drag on earnings ``for the next several quarters.'' The shock effects of MCI's drop spread to other long-distance telephone issues. American Telephone & Telegraph fell 1[ to 32; United Telecommunications 2~ to 22{, and GTE Corp. | to 27|. In a statement responding to the stock activity, AT&T said its long-distance volume and revenues remained strong. In the economic news, the Labor Department said the nation's core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, advanced a moderate 0.3 percent last month. The repor ``was definitely encouraging,'' said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. ``It suggests that if you subtract oil, inflationary pressures are easing.'' Separately, the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade deficit narrowed 3.3 percent in September, showing its first improvement since June. Brokers said the most recent data evidently gave the Federal Reserve whatever encouragement it might still have needed to take new steps toward lower interest rates in the money markets. But the reaction in the stock market was mild at best. Analysts have said the market largely anticipated a move toward easier credit with its recent rise to eight-week highs. General Electric rose ] to 55] as the company raised its quarterly dividend from 47 cents a share to 51 cents a share. Other gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 1 at 113|; Exxon, up ] at 50]; Coca-Cola, up { at 45}, and Merck, up ] at 85. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $0.04 billion, or less than .01 percent, in value.
