DOC.HEAD: Billions in Claims Against Drexel May Be Prelude to Other Charges
DOC.TEXT: When the lawyers and accountants complete their tally, total fraud claims against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. are expected to approach the ridiculous sum of $30 billion. The firm has only about a tenth of that amount in assets. No one has yet proved the allegations of systematic fraud, deception and other forms of cheating by Drexel and its junk bond empire have any validity. But in bankruptcy court, as in budget proposals and Turkish bazaars, the idea is to exaggerate, negotiate and hope the middle ground is a little higher than expected. ``Everyone is inflating their initial claims,'' said John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University. ``People see this on the outside as a fight between Drexel and these claimants. It's not. It's a fight among Drexel's creditors committees.'' The battle involves entities that claim they were stiffed when Drexel, the Wall Street prima donna whose comeuppance was a 1989 criminal securities fraud guilty plea, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection in February. Legal experts said no group of creditors is likely to receive even half its claims. But inflated requests can improve leverage during negotiations among creditors, who ultimately must approve any reorganization plan. While Drexel's resources are limited and the filing deadline for claims passed last week, claimants plan to bring separate cases against other entities who actually have money. The government's efforts are expected to focus on a Drexel-led network of individuals and savings and loan institutions that regulators charge manipulated the nation's junk bond market in the 1980s. In their claim against Drexel, two federal thrift agencies are seeking $11.3 billion for allegations that rigged junk bond dealings helped topple 48 S&Ls. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and Resolution Trust Corp. described a conspiracy among major thrift institutions that did business through Drexel. If the court supports the theory, dozens of individuals and institutions named in the claim could face lawsuits from the government. Legal experts said likely targets are former Drexel executives such as CEO Frederick Joseph and convicted junk bond financier Michael Milken; Drexel's insurance companies; still-functioning savings and loans; indicted and unindicted thrift executives; and companies swept up in Drexel's dealmaking. ``Those people are solvent,'' Coffee said. ``They have deeper pockets. Michael Milken has a few million or so sitting around.'' ``Claims can be brought against a lot of people in this alleged conspiracy,'' he said. The FDIC said it is continuing an investigation of failed thrifts with ties to Drexel, which controlled about two-thirds of the risky high-yield debt securities that S&Ls bought with federally insured deposits. Entities outside the thrift industry someday also could be exposed. S&L holdings were only a small percentage of the entire junk bond market - about $15 billion of $200 billion in securities issued. For now, the government and other claimants want to recover money from Drexel. Attorneys are negotiating to try to reach a settlement figure of all the litigation that would be passed onto a federal judge for approval. The FDIC and RTC are seeking $6.8 billion from 47 failed thrifts in connection with junk bond losses, securities fraud and other alleged lawbreaking by Drexel. A separate claim for $4.5 billion was filed on behalf of Columbia Savings and Loan Association of Beverly Hills, Calif., which has not been seized by the government but has huge junk bond losses. Another $9.3 billion is sought by investors, shareholders and companies who allege they were defrauded in the deals to which Drexel pleaded guilty. Add on at least $8 billion more from Drexel- and Milken-related cases consolidated before a federal judge in New York. Other actions scattered nationwide seek $2 billion, lawyers said. All the claims reflect tripled damages under organized crime laws. In a bankruptcy reorganization, the legal claims would fall somewhere below those of secured creditors such as banks or financial firms who lent Drexel money. But the threat of such massive claims is that they will dilute the pie for everyone. A reorganization plan will allot a percentage of Drexel's assets to creditors. Plaintiffs lawyers admit the claims are inflated - but that is part of the bankruptcy game. `To get our proper percentage of Drexel's assets we have to assert our full claims against it,'' said Melvyn I. Weiss, a New York lawyer whose firm filed the $9.3 billion claim alleging 18 separate securities frauds and listing scores of defendants - each of whom is individually liable. ``That's what bankruptcy is all about,'' dded David Berger, a Philadelphia plaintiffs lawyer who also is suing Drexel. Before any money is apportioned, claimants have to persuade Drexel's lawyers and a bankruptcy court judge their allegations are substantial enough to merit a large settlement. Legal experts said the FDIC and RTC will have to prove that thrifts bought junk bonds from Drexel despite knowing they were a bad investment with the intent of manipulatively propping up prices and deceiving outside investors. If no settlement is reached, the judge may call a trial to resolve the claims. To prevent a trial from delaying the bankruptcy reorganization, the judge could set aside a portion of Drexel's estate as potential compensation, depending on a verdict.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for Monday Nov. 19

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Job-Cutting Reported as MGM and Pathe Merge Operations
DOC.TEXT: Nearly one-third of the workers at newly formed MGM-Pathe Communications Co. have been handed pink slips since Giancarlo Parretti bought the MGM-UA studio two weeks ago. ``As with any merger, there was duplication in a number of areas that could not be maintained on any sound economic basis,'' a Pathe-MGM statement said Friday. The Italian financier's Pathe Communications Corp., which operates movie theaters in Europe and makes films, paid $1.36 billion for MGM-UA Communications Co. Spokesman Craig Parsons said nearly 300 of the company's 1,000 workers lost their jobs since the merger. The cuts were completed by Wednesday and no more are expected, he said. Lower-level employees who agreed not to sue were paid through the end of the year, plus a week's notification pay and a week for every year with the company. Middle level managers got nine months' pay. Top managers under contract were negotiating. However, haste and snarled communications angered and upset many workers, including some at top levels. ``One was a senior executive who was asked to take some names off the distribution list on a confidential report, because they were no longer going to be with the company,'' said one official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The guy looked at the list, and his own name was on it,'' he said. Parretti bought MGM-UA from Kirk Kerkorian, a billionaire who made his fortune in the used airplane and casino businesses. Kerkorian sold many of the company's assets over the years, including the studio buildings and most of the rights to the historic MGM film library. New movie production has been dormant for the two years MGM-UA has been on the block. One still-thriving MGM-UA business was its network television operation (``thirtysomething,'' ``In the Heat of the Night,'' ``The Young Riders'') - a division that was spared the ax. But Parretti, who has hired Alan Ladd Jr. as his filmmaking chief, let go virtually all the remaining film production staff. Still unsettled was the future of Richard Berger, MGM-UA's studio president. He said he'd been negotiating with Parretti, but had received offers to work elsewhere, and would probably decide next week.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Agreed to Interest Rate Ease at October Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve policy-makers agreed in early October to ease interest rates if a federal budget-cutting agreement was reached and to permit further easing if economic conditions warranted, records released Friday showed. Four weeks after the Oct. 2 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the federal funds rate dropped to 7.75 percent from 8 percent as the Bush administration and Congress agreed to a deficit-reduction package. No further easing occurred. But the committee met again on Tuesday and some economists predicted it had voted to again lower interest rates to stimulate an economy that many analysts contend has skidded into a recession. Until recently, the Fed has been reluctant to ease credit because of fears the country was on the verge of an inflationary spiral caused by the jump in oil prices after Iraq invaded Kuwait. In fact, three of the four committee members opposing the easing of rates that eventually occurred Oct. 29 dissented because they felt ``the committee risked losing sight of its fundamental objective of controlling and ultimately bringing down inflation.'' However, oil-price increases have not spread to other costs. In fact, the Labor Department reported on Friday that the core rate of inflation - the rate excluding food and energy - rose only 0.3 percent in October. According to the committee meeting minutes released on Friday, Fed governor Martha Seger dissented from the majority vote because she favored permitting lower interest rates immediately. The other dissenters - governor Wayne D. Angel, district bank Presidents Robert H. Boykin of Dallas and W. Lee Hoskins of Cleveland - opposed any easing. The majority included Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan, governors Edward W. Kelley Jr., John P. LaWare and David W. Mullins Jr., and presidents Edward G. Boehne of Philadelphia, E. Gerald Corrigan of New York and Gary H. Stern of Minneapolis. There is one vacancy. The federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, has been used for two years in combating inflation. It had peaked at 9.75 percent in the spring of 1989 but the central bank has let it drop in quarter-point increments since then to stimulate economic growth. It had fallen to 8 percent last summer. Some analysts said they thought the Fed might have voted on Tuesday to cut the discount rate it charges commercial banks for loans. That rate has stood at 7 percent for more than four years. The committee is composed of the seven Fed governors and five of the 12 presidents of Fed regional banks. It meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. Minutes are released about six weeks later, a few days after the next meeting.

DOC.HEAD: All Markets Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices showed impressive strength Friday on New York's Commodity Exchange as Japan logged substantial orders for the commodity. On other commodities markets, silver ended higher; gold fell; energy futures dipped; soybeans and grains rose; and meat and livestock futures climbed. Platinum settled $5.70 to $6 higher with the contract for delivery in January at $421.70. Despite a report released earlier this week indicating a glut of the commodity, prices gained steadily throughout the day on word that Japan is placing more orders for use in jewelry and automobile parts. ``Japan has always been a big buyer of platinum, and the orders coming in now have negated the effects of any surplus,'' said Carl Denney, an analyst for Johnson Matthey Inc. in New York. Gold prices slipped most of the day on the Commodity Exchange but rallied late to close with a slight loss. Analysts said the precious metal followed plunging oil prices but were helped by late commercial buying. Silver also rallied after dropping early. Gold settled $1.20 to 20 cents lower with December at $379.80 a troy ounce. Silver settled 3.3 cents to 3.5 cents higher with December at $4.15 an ounce. Energy futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange slid below psychological resistance points as traders continued to bet on near-term peace in the Persian Gulf. Crude oil slipped below $30 a barrel for the first time since Oct. 22. Light sweet crude settled $1.34 to 78 cents lower with Decemberat $29.78 a barrel; heating oil settled 1.25 cents to 2.25 cents lower with December at 84.42 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline settled 1.95 cents to 2.93 cents lower with December at 77.63 cents a gallon. Soybeans futures prices were buoyed on the Chicago Board of Trade by aggressive commercial and professional buying amid continuing reports of improved export business. Soybeans futures staged a comeback following sessions of lackluster trading or double-digit losses in the week after a government report indicated a higher-than-expected soybean crop. ``We've gone a week since the crop report came out, and it's about time they recovered,'' said Rich Feltes, director of commodities research at Refco Inc. ``We also had some rather impressive export sales numbers released by the government (Thursday) night that helped.'' Corn opened down on the Board of Trade, suffering from follow-through selling after Thursday's sharply lower close. The future later firmed after reports of modest export business with Spain, South Korea and Taiwan. Wheat posted moderate gains after the government's announcement that it is targeting three countries for 450,000 subsidized tons of the crop. Wheat had been suffering from above-average temperatures in the regions where the winter crop is grown and a bountiful crop from an earlier harvest. Wheat futures settled 1 cent to 3 cents higher with December at 2.50\ a bushel; corn futures settled 3 cents to 4{ cents higher with December at $2.25 a bushel; oats settled 1{ cents to 2 cents higher with December at $1.11} a bushel; soybeans settled 5\ cents to 9{ cents higher with November at $5.66} a bushel. Cattle futures prices settled higher on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange after gaining support from a late-afternoon rally in pork. Feeder cattle prices also gained following an Agriculture Department report that some of next week's cattle already had been sold. Hog futures reversed Thursday's losses in a volatile trading session. Traders moved to cover their positions over the weekend as they waited to see whether a U.S.-European food-aid package to the Soviet Union would come out of President Bush's trip to Europe. Live cattle settled .08 cent to .40 cent higher with December at 79.05 cents a pound; feeder cattle was .08 cent to .15 cent higher with January at 87.70 cents a pound; hogs were .35 cent to .93 cent higher with December at 53.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were up to the 2 cents trading limit with February at 72.12 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Phone Company Stocks Tumble After MCI Discloses Troubles
DOC.TEXT: Phone company stocks took a pounding Friday after MCI Communications Corp. said its financial performance could falter due to stepped-up competition from AT&T, the economic slump, a cost-cutting program and a recent acquisition. The decline was accelerated by a number of Wall Street stock analysts, who lowered their earnings forecasts for the nation's No. 2 long-distance phone company. They also cut their forecasts for the parent of No. 3 U.S. Sprint. MCI stock lost more than a quarter of its value, plunging $7.37{ to close at $22.62{ in national over-the-counter trading. MCI is a mainstay of the over-the-counter market as one of NASDAQ's most widely followed and actively traded stocks. Though the news appeared to favor American Telephone & Telegraph Co., the stock price of the dominant long-distance company also suffered, falling $1.12{ to close at $32. AT&T was the most active issue on the New York Stock Exchange, with more than 3.7 million shares changing hands. ``The concern is that if MCI is hurting they might have to get more aggressive with pricing and the whole industry could be affected,'' said Joe Bellace, a Merrill Lynch & Co. analyst. AT&T took the unusual step of releasing a statement about its stock activity. AT&T is the nation's most widely held stock. ``Today's decline in AT&T's stock price apparently is a result of concern among investors about the telecommunications industry. The fundamentals of AT&T's business are sound. Our third-quarter long-distance volumes were strong, and current volume and revenue trends are consistent with those results,'' the company said. Share prices of United Telecommunications Inc., the majority owner of Sprint, and of GTE Corp., which owns the remaining 19.9 percent of Sprint, also fell. United Telecom dropped $2.87{ to close at $22.50, while GTE slipped 62{ cents to $27.62{. MCI disclosed its cost-cutting plan the after the stock markets closed Thursday. It said it may lay off up to 1,500 employees in a restructuring prompted by the sluggish economy and a more competitive long-distance phone market. The Washington-based company also cited the cost of its recent $1.25 billion acquisition of long-distance carrier Telecom USA. MCI President Bert C. Roberts Jr. said these factors ``are negative constraints on the company's financial performance for the next several quarters.'' Merrill Lynch's Bellace said MCI officials painted an even bleaker picture in a conversation with him. ``Increased competetion from AT&T is resulting in lower customer retention rates,'' he said. ``This is the first time we have a high risk that MCI's market share penetration may slow.'' Analysts said AT&T has become more aggressive in fighting to retain its existing customers and to win back customers who defected to MCI and Sprint. Gregory Sawers of the investment firm Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. traced AT&T's stronger marketing moves to a decision by the Federal Communications Commission about a year ago that gives the phone giant more latitude in cutting rates. ``AT&T is getting its competitive act together at a rate far faster than anyone expected,'' he said. In recent months, the company redeployed 5,000 employees to its marketing force, boosted its advertising budget substantially and started mentioning MCI by name in its ads, he said. ``Investors are fearful we're going to go through a period when these guys beat on each other's heads with clubs. Ultimately, that's not how this will work. Some type of implicit understanding between the three carriers will emerge,'' Sawers predicted. He added that AT&T, in the end, does not expect to lose ``endless amounts of market share.''

DOC.HEAD: Coniston Dissolves UAL Buyout Unit
DOC.TEXT: Coniston Partners, the largest shareholder of UAL Corp., said Friday it has dissolved the subsidiary it formed to push for an employee buyout of the Chicago-based parent of United Airlines. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York-based investment group said Condor Partners liquidated on Thursday and distributed its 2.4 million shares of UAL common stock among Coniston's general and limited partners. The stock amounts to about 11 percent of UAL's 21.8 million shares outstanding. Condor Partners sold more than 186,000 UAL shares on the open market between Nov. 6 and last Monday at prices ranging between $97 and $100 a share, according to the filing. UAL closed at $99.75 Friday, down $1.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. In September, a United Airlines workers group ended an agreement with Condor aimed atbuying the airline for $201 per share, or about $4.4 billion. Condor had threatened to seek control of UAL's board of directors if the board did not agree to the employee' bid. The bid failed in October after workers were unable to get bank financing for the deal. UAL made peace with Coniston later by agreeing to add two Coniston representatives to its board of directors. Coniston's general partners are Keith Gollust, Paul Tierney Jr. and Augustus Oliver. In July, the partners dissolved their $850 million investment pool but held on to their UAL stake and a controlling interest in TW Services Inc., a restaurant and food-service company.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Market Sponsors Party for Gulf Soldiers' Families
DOC.TEXT: The New York Mercantile Exchange, the oil market that has come under criticism as a forum for speculation on war fears, is sponsoring a holiday party for families of soldiers in the Persian Gulf. The rock star Tiffany will ppear at the Dec. 2 event set up at Manhattan's Roseland Ballroom by USO of Metropolitan New York with money from the Mercantile Exchange, organizers said Friday. ``The members of this exchange have been deeply concerned about the families of these servicemen and women during the holiday season,'' said Z. Lou Guttman, chairman of the futures market. ``For many of them, it is the first time they have not been able to celebrate the holiday together as a family unit. This is one small way of expressing our gratitude for the selfless sacrifice and bravery they are demonstrating.'' The Mercantile Exchange and USO said they expected about 1,000 relatives of soldiers from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to attend the party, which they said will feature carnival games, face painting, magicians, Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles, Bart Simpson and clowns. The Mercantile Exchange wanted ``to do something for the families over there and also get some good press over it,'' USO spokesman Michael Gray said Friday. An exchange spokeswoman said the board's decision to host the party had nothing to do with recent controversies over oil prices. ``This has to do with the fact that the exchange wants to help the families,'' said the spokeswoman, who under exchange policy cannot be identified by name. The exchange said it has profited from the oil crisis, though not as much as some successful oil traders. ``We've had increased volume,'' said the exchange spokeswoman. ``It's like a dollar-something we make on each trade. It's not like major, major income. You're not putting us in a category with a successful trader.'' During August, the month that Iraq invaded Kuwait, the exchange brought in more than $44,000 extra each day, when numbers are compared with the yearly average, according to figures provided by the exchange. By October, when activity had tapered off, the exchange's increased volume was resulting in more than $8,000 a day in increased money for the market, according to those same figures. The exchange is spending $92,500 on the event, according to a source who spoke only on condition of anonymity. Among the invited guests are politicians from the tri-state area, including Sen. Joseph I. Lieberman, D-Conn., who held a hearing into the trading on the exchange and characterized its participants ``speculator sharks.'' Lieberman's spokesman, Jim Kennedy, said Friday that the senator might attend the exchange-sponsored party, because many of his constituents would be there, and he hoped it would be a success. Lieberman's earlier remarks ``were targeted more to the activity on the exchange rather than the entity of the New York Mercantile Exchannge itself,'' Kennedy said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Northwest Chairman Exploring Buyout of Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines Chairman Alfred Checchi is exploring a buyout of Eastern Airlines using up to $150 million in pension funds of Eastern's union pilots, according to a report Friday. The Saint Paul Pioneer Press reported that officials of the Eastern Air Line Pilots Association have said union leaders are agreeable to a Northwest acquisition. The officials also said their leaders are willing to pitch the idea of lending Checchi the pension funds, the paper reported. A spokesman for Northwest, based in Eagan, said only that dealings involving Eastern are ``a private matter.'' Eastern's court-appointed trustee, Martin R. Shugrue Jr., succeeded Wednesday in getting a $15 million cash infusion from a bankruptcy judge in New York. Shugrue said the next day he would be happy to talk to anyone interested in Eastern. A Northwest buyout of Eastern is viewed as a long shot prospect by some analysts. Creditors are pressing a bankruptcy judge to have Eastern liquidated, and such a buyout would take time to put together. ``They have to act awful quick,'' said Paul Karos, airline analyst for First Boston Corp. in New York. Checchi has long been interested in acquiring selected Eastern assets, but he has had little success in winning creditors' attention. A series of bids he submitted earlier this year included an offer to liquidate Eastern, but little cash. The Pioneer Press quoted an unidentified source who is familiar with recent talks between Checchi and the Eastern pilots as saying both sides are exploring the idea. ``The Eastern pilots are dead serious,'' the source said. Checchi is likewise viewing the idea seriously, the source said. Union leaders said that for Checchi to borrow money, he would have to agree to buy the entire airline and hire the union pilots to fly Eastern's jets. Union spokesman E.J. Breen said members would have to agree to the loan and it is not clear whether they favor it. Another union official, Ernest Dodson, said leaders would also insist on preferred stock in Northwest, status as a secured creditor, or other assurances that their investment is worthwhile and safe. Precisely how much money could be raised also is unclear. Union officials acknowledged that the funds could total as much as $200 million. But even if many pilots agree to allow their pension funds to be used for the loan, the total amount available could be reduced sharply by pilots who choose not to participate.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Jump on Clear Sign Fed Has Eased Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose sharply Friday amid intense speculation among traders that the Federal Reserve has moved to lower interest rates. The Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond jumped 13-16 point, or $8.13 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, was down to 8.45 percent from 8.53 percent late Friday. Traders said they viewed a drop Friday in the federal funds rate as a clear indication that the Fed has moved to relax credit policy. The federal funds rate is the rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, and is closely watched to determine a change in monetary policy. The rate late Friday was 7 9-16 percent, down from 8 percent late Thursday. A lowering of interest rates is viewed by credit market participants as a positive development because it generally increases the value of bonds. ``I think it's finally getting down there. Today's operation more clearly indicates they have eased,'' said Carol A. Stone, senior economist at Nomura Securities International Inc. Stone and others said the final test of whether the Fed has moved to ease interest rates will be if the federal funds rate remains around the 7{ percent level after this weekend. The Fed's target had been 7} percent. ``The timing of the easing is important. It puts additional pressure on banks to reduce their prime lending rate'' during the crucial holiday shopping season, said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities Inc. Traders said release early in the day of the government's monthly measure of consumer prices, which showed a relatively low inflation rate for prices of key retail goods, provided the Fed with impetus to lower rates. Prices excluding the volatile food and energy components - the so-called core rate - were up a more moderate 0.3 percent in October, the same as in September but under the 0.5 percent rise in August, the government said. The report of only moderate inflation was another factor giving the credit markets a lift because inflation generally erodes the value of bonds. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, short-term maturities rose 1-16 point to 5-32 point, intermediate maturities were up 3-16 point to 17-32 point and long-term issues rose 21-32 point to ~ point, according to the Telerate Inc. financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 3.93 to 1,172.63. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.30 percent as the discount fell 1 basis point to 7.08 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.37 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.02 percent. Yields on one-year bills were down to 7.26 percent as the discount fell 7 basis points to 6.80 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds rose \ point to 91 11-32. The average yield to maturity was down to 7.48 percent from 7.52 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Multimedia Technology a Big Theme at Computer Show
DOC.TEXT: Three-D graphics, blaring dance music and MTV-like images lured convention-goers at the Comdex computer show this week as nearly every major computer maker promoted ``multimedia'' - the marriage of computing, graphics and television. But some industry-watchers say the hype may be premature, since the multimedia market is small and has yet to find its bearings. That didn't stop IBM from driving home the point that it is serious about multimedia. A breakfast gathering sponsored by the world's largest computer company for several hundred computer dealers and other industry insiders was a multimedia show in itself. As the lights dimmed in the basketball stadium where the group assembled, smoke filled the air and a green laser streaked across the ceiling. Then, from the stadium's balcony, an inflated IBM ``spaceship'' the size of a small car floated across the ceiling and hovered above a stage. The ship sent down a ``transporter'' signal modeled after TV's ``Star Trek,'' and an IBM executive appeared in the mist to the sound of eerie music. Meanwhile, outer-space scenes flashed on giant screens. IBM later demonstrated a more practical use for multimedia with a computer program that spiced up a high school English lesson on the poem ``Ulysses.'' On a computer screen it depicted the text of the poem along with a ``window'' featuring pictures of several actors. When an on-screen arrow was moved to one of the photos, a video clip of the actor reading the poem appeared in another window. The program also featured video clips of critics discussing the poem and its historical background. Mike Braun, IBM's vice president for multimedia, called the technology ``the next wave of the computer revolution.'' ``It's technology that will push the computer into our everyday lives,'' he said. IBM demonstrated another use of multimedia, a program that electronically ``ages'' a person's photograph on the computer screen. For this demonstration it used a photo of Bill Gates, the 35-year-old chairman of software giant Microsoft Corp., who happened to be in the audience. IBM said the program is designed for law-enforcement authorities to simulate the aging of a suspect or a missing child. At a Comdex panel discussion on multimedia, industry officials listed a number of current and future uses for the technology, including corporate training programs, point-of-sale merchandise displays, education programs and entertainment. ``Some people learn better visually,'' said Nick Arnett, editor of an industry newsletter on multimedia. The panelists showed videotapes depicting several uses of multimedia. In one, used by Volvo dealers, a customer can see combinations of colors and wheel covers on a car depicted on a computer screen. In a program for interior designers, the color scheme of a room can be altered on a screen, the furniture moved around and even the effects of various types of lighting can be depicted. A third demonstration showed how a magazine could be represented in multimedia. The magazine's pages could be ``turned'' on screen, the articles could be read by a narrator and photographs and graphics could be enlarged or rotated. This electronic ``magazine'' also could highlight key words and provide an outline of the articles. ``What we're allowing the reader to do is get into that magazine,'' said John Colligan, president of Authorware, a maker of multimedia software. But despite multimedia's promise, even those involved in it admit the market has yet to find its place or to earn much money. ``Right now it's a lot of effort but not much return,'' said William Nisen, president of OWL International, another company developing multimedia software. A key to multimedia's popularity could be the development of long-promised high-definition television, Nisen said. That would allow vastly sharper images and compact-disc-quality sound on TV sets. If those future TVs also are based on digital technology rather than today's analog, multimedia would get a further boost because a digital TV essentially would be a computer, said Richard Shaffer, editor of Technologic Computer Letter, an industry newsletter. In a telephone interview, Shaffer said computer companies are being driven toward multimedia by the fear that as computer technology becomes cheaper, they could lose the emerging home computer market to consumer electronics companies. With multimedia, computer makers hope to stake their claim in any home entertainment and information market that will be based on multimedia, he said. ``The potential for an entertainment medium is enormous,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Equimark Annouces New Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Equimark Corp. on Friday said Gary W. Fiedler would become the company's new chairman and chief executive officer. Fiedler, 46, was to assume his duties immediately, replacing Alan Fellheimer, who resigned. For the past three years, Fiedler has been chairman and chief executive officer of Hogan Systems Inc., a Dallas company that supplies technology services to banks. He also has held executive positions at Mellon Bank, Wells Fargo Bank and First Interstate Bancorp. Equimark announced in September that Fellheimer, 47, would resign to practice law. His wife, Judith, had resigned as Equimark vice chairman earlier in the year. Equimark, based in Pittsburgh, is a diversified financial services institution with about $3.5 billion in assets. Its principal subsidiaries are Equibank and The Liberty Financial Group Inc., which operate banks in Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Executives and Politicians Hopeful For Atlantic City's Future
With AM-Trump
DOC.TEXT: Casino executives and politicians are touting Atlantic City as a good place to do business in spite of the financial troubles facing Donald Trump and the resort's dozen casinos. They also said Trump's bartering on an overdue $47 million bond payment underscores the overdependence on junk bonds - high-interest paying notes - in a weak economy that witnessed the collapse of the 1980s junk bond market. ``I think Atlantic City is a good place to invest in right now,'' said state Sen. William Gormley. ``Nobody said it was going to happen overnight. It does take decades.'' ``If what had happened were isolated to Atlantic City, you would have to rethink where we are going,'' said Mayor Jim Whelan. ``This is a problem that is national and international.'' Whelan said the city would recover when the economy improves and that in preparation it must repair its tattered image. But any indication of an economic upturn seems a long way off. Atlantic City has 12 casinos, and no new gambling halls are in the planning. The last one to open - the Trump Taj Mahal on April 2 - reached an agreement Friday to restructure the $675 million in notes on which an interest payment was due Thursday. Trump's deal with investors of the mammoth casino will briefly put it under bankruptcy-court protection and give them a 50 percent stake. The deal also allows Trump to remain as chairman. ``The concept of junk-bond financing included the knowledge that junk bond financing was always present,'' said Ed Tracy, director of Trump's three Atlantic City casinos and one non-casino hotel. ``Unfortunately today that isn't true ... You can't boil it down and say the Taj Mahal was a huge mistake. ``It can weather a bad economy for a long period of time,'' said Tracy, who said the upcoming year would prove difficult for each of the city's 12 casinos. The industry, which according to state figures is saddled with more than $3 billion in debt, is working to repay it at a time when the casinos have posted flat numbers all year. The poor showing is partly due to a declining economy and gamblers' weariness with the resort, analysts say. But several casino officials said the city would rise above its troubled present and enjoy a prosperous future. Thomas Carver, president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, said the industry and city are experiencing tough times, but would survive. He reiterated his belief that an expanded airport would broaden the city's base. Since taking office in January, Gov. Jim Florio and his staff have promised to help strengthen the casinos. Florio has said he is committed to upgrading Atlantic City International Airport to bring more air passengers to the resort. ``We can accomplish so much. We're in our embryonic stage,'' Carver said. ``Twelve years is not a long period of time.''

Donald Trump and investors in his Taj Mahal casino agreed Friday to a restructuring of the gambling parlor's debt that will briefly put it under bankruptcy-court protection and give bondholders half ownership of the glitzy Atlantic City property. Some details of the arrangement were still to be worked out, but bondholder representatives said it contained several incentives for Trump to improve the performance of the Taj Mahal, which has been unable to break even since its April 2 opening. The deal was reached more than 12 hours after Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment on $675 million worth of high-yield junk bonds used to finance the Taj Mahal. ---

The Manville trust fund will make staggered payments to victims of asbestos diseases based on severity of illness under a tentative settlement of tens of thousands of claims nationwide, lawyers said. The agreement, announced Friday and expected to be completed over the weekend, would mark a major breakthrough in a two-decade-old effort to compensate workers made sick by inhaling asbestos fibers in products made by U.S. companies. The deal would have to be approved by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein, who earlier this year ordered the Manville trust overhauled. The trust has 130,000 claims pending. ---

Consumer inflation slowed slightly in October and the country's trade deficit narrowed, but economists attributed these seemingly upbeat developments to the near certainty that the nation has slid into a recession. Also on Friday, President Bush wrapped up a week of hastily called meetings with his economic advisers and leading U.S. business executives as the administration scoured for ways to alleviate the pain from any economic downturn. Bush received a generally bleak assessment of the economy's prospects from the executives, leading the president to acknowledge the possibility of a recession for the first time. ---

CBS' ``60 Minutes'' will fire three producers at year's end, and ABC News will close its Frankfurt, Germany, bureau and three Central American offices, network officials said. CBS will make the ``60 Minutes'' cuts to restructure the top-rated series' staff, not because of economic conditions that have forced what the network calls ``a belt-tightening'' in its news division, a spokesman said Friday. The move was ordered after Harry Reasoner, one of the show's first correspondents, announced he would reduce his workload, said spokesman Roy Brunett. ---

Union employees of United Press International have accepted a 35 percent, 90-day pay cut in what company and union officials described as an effort to keep the financially troubled news service going while its owners seek a buyer. Chris Dahl, secretary-treasurer of the Wire Service Guild, said 62 percentof those voting on Friday approved the reduction. Milt Capps, a UPI vice president and spokesman, said the guild members approved the pay cut ``in order to keep UPI alive while we seek a buyer.'' ---

Phone company stocks took a pounding after MCI Communications Corp. said its financial performance could falter due to stepped-up competition from AT&T, the economic slump, a cost-cutting program and a recent acquisition. The decline on Friday was accelerated by a number of Wall Street stock analysts, who lowered their earnings forecasts for the nation's No. 2 long-distance phone company. MCI stock lost more than a quarter of its value. Though the news appeared to favor American Telephone & Telegraph Co., the stock price of the dominant long-distance company also suffered. ---

Northwest Airlines Chairman Alfred Checchi reportedly is exploring a buyout of Eastern Airlines using up to $150 million in pension funds of Eastern's union pilots. The Saint Paul Pioneer Press said Friday that officials of the Eastern Air Line Pilots Association have said union leaders are agreeable to a Northwest acquisition. The officials also said their leaders are willing to pitch the idea of lending Checchi the pension funds, the paper reported. ---

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd. is seeking a $600 million bridge loan to help alleviate a short-term liquidity squeeze brought on by tough market conditions, bankers said. Murdoch and other senior News Corp. executives presented their proposals to creditors earlier this week in Sydney and at a meeting Thursday in London with British and European bankers. Australian-based News Corp. is trying to line up support for a new credit facility of $6.5 billion to replace much of its existing debt, bankers said on Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity. ---

Beverly Enterprises Inc., the nation's largest nursing home chain, has been found guilty of unfair labor practices in a ruling organized labor called a major victory that could affect other corporate giants. The Fort Smith, Ark.-based chain said the ruling, handed down by an administrative law judge on Friday, would be appealed to the National Labor Relations Board. At issue was a 1987 NLRB case in which the government accused the company of engaging in 40 illegal acts ``designed to defeat'' workers' rights to unionize. ---

The stock market eked out a small gain Friday in an advance restrained by selling pressure on long-distance telephone issues. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 5.20 to 2,550.25, stretching its gain for the week to 61.64 points. Bonds rose sharply amid clear-cut signs that the Federal Reserve has moved to lower interest rates. The dollar declined broadly and gold prices were mixed. Oil fell below $30 a barrel on the futures market.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Casinos Post Third-Quarter Results; Taj Mahal Loses $11 Million
With AM-Trump Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's three casinos posted mixed numbers in the third quarter with the Taj Mahal losing $11 million, Trump officials said Friday. The Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino posted a net gain while Trump Castle Casino Resort By the Bay recorded a net loss in figures submitted to the state Casino Control Commission, said a financial source in the Trump Organization. The Taj Mahal recorded revenues of $128.46 million and a net loss of $11.04 million, the source said. The third-quarter results come the same day Trump and bondholders in the Taj Mahal reached a restructuring agreement that will briefly put Atlantic City's largest casino under bankruptcy court protection. The bondholders will receive 50 percent ownership and reduced interest payments. Trump missed a $47.3 million interest payment Thursday on $675 million worth of high-yield junk bonds used to finance the gaming hall. The Taj Mahal made an average $1.4 million a day in gross revenues for the quarter, about the amount that analysts said it needed to break even. But the casino's gross operating profits were dragged down by $26.51 million in interest expense. The April 2 opening of the casino also drew business from Trump's other two properties and the other nine casinos in the city. Trump Castle Casino Resort recorded a net loss of $7.72 million on total revenues of $69.03 million for the three-month period ended Sept. 30. Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino recorded a net profit of $5.44 million on net revenues for the three months of $82.96 million.
